Ferguson marked 25 years in charge of the English Premier League champions earlier this year, but his ambition clearly still burns bright. "I think I've got three years at the club," Ferguson told the official club website. "As long as my health stays up, and as long as I'm still enjoying it and still getting the satisfaction of the team doing its best," he added. Ferguson's top moments in 25 years in charge . The legendary Scot has set his sights on further success in the European Champions League after their shock exit at the group stages this season and to add to the club's tally of 19 English championships. "We have to continue the dominance of winning leagues and, without question, winning a European Cup is important at this club. We should have been in at least another three finals. But you can't be greedy, I suppose, and having won two in my time is an achievement. "They were special, it was terrific to win them. I think I'd be very keen to do that (again)." Blackburn, in the relegation zone of the EPL and with manager Steve Kean under continued pressure, scored probably the most unlikely win of the season after the United faithful had paid homage to their manager before the start. Blog: Out with the old and in with the new in 2012 . With Ferguson resting Wayne Rooney and other first team regulars, their Lancastrian neighbors led 1-0 at half time through an Ayegbeni Yakubu penalty. It was awarded after Dimitar Berbatov pulled down Christopher Samba and put away with some aplomb. Yakubu rifled home a super second, his 12th of the season just after the break, holding off Phil Jones and Michael Carrick before putting his side 2-0 ahead. Almost immediately, Berbatov atoned for his earlier mistake by pulling one back and when the Bulgarian equalized with his sixth goal in three games, United looked set to claim victory. But Kean's men were resolute throughout and in the 80th minute grabbed the winner. It came after United goalkeeper David de Gea flapped at a Morten Gamst Pedersen corner and Grant Hanley was on hand to head home. The result lifted Blackburn off the bottom, while United stayed level on points with neighbors Manchester City, who play Sunday against Sunderland. Ferguson did not temper his reaction to the disappointing defeat which prevented his side leading the EPL at the end of the year. "It is a disaster," he told Press Association. "I never expected it. We lost two terrible goals and you can't do that."

Ferguson, widely regarded as one of the greatest managers in football history, recently celebrated his 25th anniversary in charge at Old Trafford. The 70-year-old Scot has been instrumental in transforming Manchester United into a global football powerhouse, winning an unprecedented 13 league titles, two UEFA Champions Leagues, and five FA Cups during his tenure.

However, the recent loss to Blackburn, which was marred by a series of defensive lapses and questionable refereeing decisions, has raised questions about Ferguson's long-term future at the club. Despite the setback, the veteran manager remains committed to his job and has given himself a three-year deadline to achieve his goals.

"I'm not going anywhere anytime soon," Ferguson said in an exclusive interview with CNN. "I've got three years left on my contract, and I'm determined to make the most of it. We've got a talented young squad, and I believe we can challenge for the title again next season."

Ferguson's decision to extend his stay at Manchester United comes as a welcome boost to the club's fans, who have grown accustomed to his leadership and tactical acumen over the years. The legendary manager has a reputation for getting the best out of his players, and his ability to adapt to changing circumstances has been a key factor in the club's sustained success.

Under Ferguson's guidance, Manchester United has become a byword for excellence in English football, attracting top talent from around the world and developing a loyal fan base that spans the globe. The club's commitment to youth development has also been a hallmark of Ferguson's tenure, with players like Ryan Giggs, Paul Scholes, and David Beckham rising through the ranks to become household names.

Despite the recent setback against Blackburn, Manchester United remains a force to be reckoned with in the Premier League. The club's current squad boasts a mix of experienced veterans and talented young players, including the likes of Wayne Rooney, Nemanja Vidic, and Antonio Valencia.

However, the loss to Blackburn has highlighted the need for Ferguson to strengthen his squad in the summer transfer window. The club's defense, in particular, has been a concern, with several high-profile errors contributing to the defeat.

Ferguson acknowledged the need for improvement but remained optimistic about the club's prospects. "We've got a lot of work to do between now and the end of the season," he said. "But I'm confident that we can turn things around and make a push for the title."

As Manchester United looks to the future, one thing is certain: Alex Ferguson will be at the helm, guiding the club through the ups and downs of the Premier League. His commitment to the job is a testament to his enduring passion for the game and his dedication to the club he loves.

In a career spanning over four decades, Ferguson has become synonymous with Manchester United, and his legacy continues to inspire a new generation of players and fans. As he embarks on the final chapter of his managerial career, one thing is clear: Alex Ferguson will go out on his own terms, leaving behind a lasting legacy that will be remembered for generations to come.

(CNN) -- Jacqueline Woodson's big win at the National Book Awards on Wednesday was briefly
human_text: (CNN) -- Jacqueline Woodson's big win at the National Book Awards on Wednesday was briefly eclipsed by a racially charged joke. After Woodson accepted an award for her memoir "Brown Girl Dreaming," host Daniel Handler shared an anecdote he learned over the summer: that Woodson, who is black, is allergic to watermelon. "Just let that sink in your mind," said Handler, who writes popular children's books under the pen name Lemony Snicket. The non sequitur elicited a few laughs and uncomfortable titters from the audience. Handler went on to say that he advised Woodson to write a book that featured a black girl with a watermelon allergy. Watermelon is historically evoked as a favorite food among black people in racist jokes, and it's considered by many to be an offensive reference. Handler said that Woodson, who won the National Book Award for Young People's Literature, told him he should write the book instead. "I'm only writing a book about a black girl who is allergic to watermelon if I get a blurb from you, Cornell West, Toni Morrison, and Barack Obama saying this guy's OK," Handler said, with a laugh. After a clip from the awards ceremony was posed on C-SPAN, viewers and some prominent writers quickly took to Twitter to denounce Handler's comments as racist and a distraction from Woodson's accomplishment. Handler responded with several apologetic tweets, including: "My remarks on Wednesday night at #NBAwards were monstrously inappropriate and yes, racist." Handler also pledged to donate $10,000 to the We Need Diverse Books campaign and match others' donations for 24 hours up to $100,000. Woodson's post-ceremony social media posts have expressed her happiness about the award and have not mentioned Handler's joke. The author did not respond to a request for comment on the incident. Other 2014 National Book Award winners included: . Fiction: Phil Klay, "Redeployment" Nonfiction: Evan Osnos, "Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China" Poetry: Louise Gluck, "Faithful and Virtuous Night"

(CNN) -- Jacqueline Woodson's big win at the National Book Awards on Wednesday was briefly -- and awkwardly -- overshadowed by a joke from a fellow author.
After Woodson accepted the award for her memoir " Brown Girl Dreaming ," Daniel Handler -- better known as the author Lemony Snicket -- shared a story with the audience.
"I told her to write about the black girl who's allergic to watermelon," Handler said, according to The New York Times . "And she said, 'That's racist.' And I said 'No, it's not racist. It's a joke.' "
Handler's joke was met with boos from the audience, and he later apologized on Twitter .
Woodson's memoir is about growing up as an African-American girl in the 1960s and '70s in Ohio. The book was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Children's Literature .
The National Book Awards are considered one of the most prestigious literary awards in the United States.

A grief-stricken couple have been banned from installing a plaque in memory of their daughter
human_text: A grief-stricken couple have been banned from installing a plaque in memory of their daughter - after a council said such tributes were 'too depressing' to read. Tony and Julie Fuller, of Sunbury in Surrey planted a tree in Cedars Park after their only daughter Samantha died on Christmas Eve, aged 28. They wanted to place a plaque with the tree but were left devastated after being told that Spelthorne Borough Council will no longer permit memorial plaques - because 'lots' of people had complained that they were depressing. Tony and Julie Fuller have planted a tree in Cedars Park, pictured, after their only daughter Samantha died on Christmas Eve, aged 28. But the local council has barred them from putting up a memorial plaque . Mr Fuller said: ‘Sam was our only daughter. She meant the world to me and she probably meant more to her mother. ‘You can’t even describe the idea of losing a child. You have to love them completely and make sure you hug them every day. ‘I rang to ask if we could have a tree and how we could go about it. ‘But we were told we couldn’t have a plaque as the council is no longer allowing them. 'I can’t see the harm in it, considering all the other plaques there are on trees and benches. 'I just don’t believe it. I don’t believe people can be so unhappy at seeing memorials. Samantha had contracted Wegener’s granulomatosis, a condition where the immune system attacks itself. The family wanted to create a lasting memory to her. But Jackie Taylor, head of Streetscene at the council, said: 'As a result of lots of complaints that we had, we decided we would stop allowing memorial plaques to remember people. 'At the end of the day our parks and open spaces are to be used by everybody and people don’t like that around every bench or tree there was another plaque remembering somebody who died. 'We don’t have an issue with somebody planting a tree but it doesn’t have to be there with a plaque. 'The trees are there for the people to remember for themselves and we have done the same now with memorial plaques on benches.'

A grief-stricken couple have been banned from installing a plaque in memory of their daughter  in a local park after council officials deemed it "too depressing" to read.

Tony and Julie Fuller had hoped to commemorate the life of their 28-year-old daughter, Samantha, who tragically passed away from a rare immune system illness, by placing a memorial plaque in Cedars Park, Sunbury, Surrey.

In a heart-wrenching gesture, the couple had already taken the initiative to plant a tree in the park in their daughter's memory, but their bid to add a plaque was met with resistance from Spelthorne borough council.

According to reports, the council rejected the couple's application, citing concerns that the plaque's message would be "too depressing" for visitors to the park.

Samantha's parents, Tony and Julie, are said to be devastated by the council's decision, which they claim has left them feeling "disheartened" and "upset".

Speaking to local media, Tony Fuller expressed his disappointment, saying: "We just wanted to remember our daughter in a special way. We thought a plaque would be a lovely way to do that. We're not asking for much, just a small plaque to remember our daughter."

Julie added: "It's not just about us, it's about all the people who come to the park and might see the plaque. It's a way of remembering Samantha and keeping her memory alive."

The couple's efforts to honor their daughter's memory have been met with sympathy from the local community, with many taking to social media to express their support for the Fullers.

One resident, who wished to remain anonymous, said: "I think it's absolutely disgusting that the council has rejected the Fullers' application. A memorial plaque is a beautiful way to remember someone who has passed away. It's not depressing, it's a celebration of life."

The council's decision has sparked outrage among locals, with many questioning the authority's priorities.

Councillor Ian Harvey, who represents the area, said: "While we understand the Fullers' desire to remember their daughter, we have to consider the overall impact on the park and its users. We can't have plaques everywhere, it would be overwhelming."

However, critics argue that the council's reasoning is flimsy and that the plaque would be a small price to pay for the emotional closure it would bring to the grieving family.

As the debate rages on, the Fullers remain resolute in their determination to find a way to honor their beloved daughter's memory.

In a statement, they said: "We will not give up. We will continue to fight for our right to remember Samantha in a way that feels meaningful to us. We hope that the council will reconsider their decision and allow us to place a plaque in the park."

The incident has raised questions about the role of local authorities in balancing the needs of grieving families with the needs of the wider community.

While the council's decision may have been well-intentioned, it has sparked a heated debate about the importance of respecting the memories of loved ones who have passed away.

As the Fullers continue their fight, they are not alone in their quest for justice. Many are rallying behind them, demanding that the council reconsider its decision and allow them to install a plaque in Samantha's memory.

Only time will tell if the Fullers' determination will ultimately prevail, but one thing is certain – their love and devotion to their daughter will not be silenced.  ### | End of Response | ###  ### | Instruction | ###

Falcon:
A grief-stricken couple have been banned from installing a plaque in memory of their daughter - because it's too depressing to read.
Samantha Fuller, 28, died from a rare immune system illness in 2015.
Her parents, Tony and Julie, wanted to commemorate her life by planting a tree in Sunbury Park, Surrey.
But the council has rejected their request, saying the plaque would be 'too upsetting' for passers-by.
Mr Fuller, 65, said: 'It's a tree, not a gravestone. It's not a memorial to her death, it's a memorial to Samantha's life.
'We're not asking for a memorial for her death, we're asking for one for her life.'
He added: 'I don't think it's going to be too upsetting for people to read the plaque.
'I think they'll be more upset if they don't read it.'
Mr Fuller and his wife Julie, 64, planted the tree in memory of Samantha in 2016.
The plaque would have read: 'In loving memory of Samantha Fuller 1987 - 2015'.
Mr Fuller said the council's decision was 'disgusting' and 'ridiculous'.
He said the plaque would have been placed in a secluded part of the park and would not have been visible from the main path.
He added that the council had previously allowed a plaque to be installed in memory of a dog in the same park.
The couple have been told they can appeal the decision, but Mr Fuller said it would be a 'waste of time'.
'I'm not going to appeal it,' he said. 'I've had enough of the council.
'They don't seem to want to do anything for the people of Sunbury.'
A council spokesman said the plaque was 'not appropriate' for the park.
'The council has a duty of care to the public,' they said.
'It is not appropriate to have a plaque in a public park which could be read by members of the public who may be distressed by the content.
'This is why the council has a policy of not allowing plaques to be placed in public parks.'

For the fifth year straight, Washington ranked as the country's most bicycle-friendly state, thanks to
human_text: For the fifth year straight, Washington ranked as the country's most bicycle-friendly state, thanks to policies designed to create alternatives to driving, according to the League of American Bicyclists. The advocacy group's Bicycle Friendly State Program ranks the states each year under a series of criteria, from laws and regulations that govern bicycling to policies for accommodating cyclists and infrastructure funding. In each of the top five states -- Washington, Minnesota, Massachusetts, Colorado and Oregon -- the focus of the respective Departments of Transportation is not only on highways but on accommodating pedestrians, cyclists and transportation on ferries and trains, said Matt Wempe, the league's state and local advocacy coordinator. Arkansas, considered one of the least safe places for cyclists based on fatalities, was at the bottom of the list. The league's top recommendation was to adopt a statewide bicycle plan and to establish an advisory committee to oversee its implementation. Washington is considered a model for all other states on using federal funds for bicycle and pedestrian projects. It also earned points for adopting a safe passing and vulnerable road user law, which carries enhanced penalties for motorists who severely injure or kill a cyclist or pedestrian, Wempe said. It also creates a minimum 3-foot "safe passing" distance for cyclists by motorists. Related: Drivers and cyclists square off on sharing the road to work . The state also has a "complete streets" policy, which means new roads must be designed with cyclists and pedestrians in mind, Wempe said. "Every state says bicycles are treated the same as vehicles, but that needs to be clarified," he said. "We're stressing that bicycles have the same rights and responsibilities as motor vehicles, but their needs in terms of infrastructure need to be clarified." Minnesota, which claimed the No. 2 spot, also has a complete streets policy. The state also earned kudos for its bike-sharing program and plans to expand bike trails along the Mississippi River. Colorado cracked the top 10 for the first time with qualities that make it a model for other states in terms of traffic laws, Wempe said. It has a safe passing law and a Share the Road Campaign; cyclists are allowed to ride side-by-side. It also has bicycle commuter share of more than 1%, more than double the national average. "We are encouraged to see significant progress in top states like Washington, Minnesota, Colorado and Massachusetts," Andy Clarke, president of the League of American Bicyclists, said in a statement. "But, as the scores clearly highlight, there's much work to be done in critical areas like infrastructure and funding. Overall, we see states -- and especially state Departments of Transportation and state legislatures -- lagging behind cities and the expectations of local cyclists, despite the many well documented benefits of a more active lifestyle."
gpt: Washington has once again been crowned the most bicycle-friendly state in the U.S. for the fifth year in a row. According to the League of American Bicyclists, Washington takes the top spot for its commitment to developing cycling infrastructure, improving safety for cyclists and promoting cycling as a mode of transportation.  One notable effort that contributed to Washington's top spot is the newly passed law that imposes penalties on motorists who injure or kill cyclists. The law aims to promote safety and accountability on the roads, making Washington an even safer place to bike.  Minnesota claimed the second spot thanks to its successful bike-sharing program and plans to expand its bike trails network, providing more options for cyclists. The state's Nice Ride program, which launched in 2010, has since grown to 2,000 bikes, available for rent at over 200 stations, and boasts a highly successful membership program. Moving down the ladder, Arkansas comes in last for bicycle-friendliness. The state failed to make significant progress towards improving cycling infrastructure, and its bike safety laws remain lax. The lack of bike-specific infrastructure and education programs for cyclists means that cycling in Arkansas can be a dangerous endeavor. Biking has become a growing trend in recent years, with more Americans choosing to use bicycles as their primary mode of transportation. As the demand for bicycle-friendly cities grows, states and cities are increasingly investing in cycling infrastructure, aiming to improve safety and encourage more people to take up cycling.  According to a report by PeopleForBikes, the U.S has witnessed an increase in bike routes, lanes, and trails nationwide since 2010, making it easier for people to ride a bicycle. Improvements in bicycle infrastructure are essential in promoting active transportation, reducing traffic congestion, and improving air quality. States like Washington, Minnesota, and California have set the standard for investing in cycling infrastructure, and more states are following suit. In 2020, New York City announced plans to invest $58.4 million in cycling infrastructure, including $34 million in protected bike lanes, while cyclist activist groups called on the city authorities to make larger investments in cycling infrastructure.  Despite the progress made in some states, there is still a long way to go before cycling infrastructure is readily accessible nationwide. The COVID-19 pandemic has also highlighted the importance of active transportation, with many people turning to cycling to avoid public transport. However, without proper infrastructure and education, cycling can still be hazardous.  In conclusion, Washington continues to lead the nation when it comes to creating a bicycle-friendly environment. Enactment of laws like the one incentivizing motorists to drive safely and other moves such as investment in cycling infrastructure improves the cycling experience which can also contribute to reducing carbon emissions. As more cities and states work to promote cycling as a viable mode of transportation, it is necessary to focus more on protecting cyclists, providing bicycle-specific infrastructure, and educating motorists on road safety.

For the fifth year straight, Washington ranked as the country's most bicycle-friendly state, thanks to  its extensive network of bike lanes, bike-share programs, and dedicated cycling infrastructure. According to a recent report by the League of American Bicyclists, Washington's commitment to cyclist safety and accessibility has earned it the top spot in the annual Bicycle Friendly State rankings.

One of the key factors contributing to Washington's success is its comprehensive approach to cyclist safety. In 2019, the state passed a law that imposes penalties on motorists who cause serious injury or death to cyclists. The law, which went into effect in January 2020, requires drivers to exercise "due care" when sharing the road with cyclists and imposes fines of up to $5,000 for those who fail to do so. This legislation has sent a strong message to motorists that cyclist safety is a priority in Washington, and has helped to reduce the number of cycling-related accidents on the state's roads.

In addition to its commitment to cyclist safety, Washington has also invested heavily in expanding its bike-share programs and bike trails. The city of Seattle, in particular, has made significant strides in this area, with the launch of a new bike-share program that allows users to rent bikes for short periods of time. This program has been a huge success, with thousands of users taking advantage of the service each month. The city has also expanded its network of bike trails, including the popular Burke-Gilman Trail, which runs along the shores of Lake Washington and offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape.

Minnesota took the number two spot in the Bicycle Friendly State rankings, thanks in part to its innovative bike-sharing program. The program, which was launched in 2017, allows users to rent high-quality bikes for a low monthly fee. The program has been incredibly popular, with over 10,000 users signing up in the first year alone. Minnesota also plans to expand its bike trails in the coming years, with a focus on creating more connections between urban and rural areas.

At the other end of the spectrum, Arkansas took last place in the rankings, due in part to its lack of investment in cycling infrastructure. While the state has made some efforts to improve cyclist safety in recent years, it still lags behind other states in terms of the number of bike lanes and bike-share programs available. However, there are signs that Arkansas is beginning to take cycling more seriously, with the announcement of plans to build a new bike trail that will connect several major cities in the state.

The Bicycle Friendly State rankings are based on a range of criteria, including the availability of bike-share programs, the quality of bike infrastructure, and the level of investment in cycling education and outreach. The rankings are intended to provide a snapshot of the state of cycling in each state, and to highlight areas where improvement is needed. This year's rankings are particularly notable, given the growing interest in cycling as a mode of transportation and recreation.

As the demand for cycling infrastructure continues to grow, states like Washington and Minnesota are setting an example for others to follow. By investing in bike-share programs, bike trails, and cyclist safety initiatives, these states are creating a more welcoming and accessible environment for cyclists of all ages and skill levels. Whether you're a seasoned cyclist or just starting out, there's never been a better time to hit the roads and enjoy the many benefits of cycling.

In conclusion, Washington's ranking as the most bicycle-friendly state for the fifth year straight is a testament to the state's commitment to cycling safety and accessibility. With its innovative bike-share programs, extensive bike trails, and comprehensive approach to cyclist education and outreach, Washington is a leader in the field of cycling infrastructure. As the demand for cycling continues to grow, it will be interesting to see how other states respond to the challenge of creating a more bike-friendly environment. By . Mia De Graaf . It is one of the biggest markets in the
human_text: By . Mia De Graaf . It is one of the biggest markets in the tourist hot spot of Langowan, Indonesia. But  you won't want to face this on an empty stomach. From battered snake to spit-roasted bats, the smorgasbord of traditional delicacies on offer are not exactly appetising. Scroll down for video . Macabre: Spit-roasted bats are stacked on a plastic tables at Langowan Market in Sulawesi, Indonesia . Horrifying: Live dogs are sat in cages before being roasted with a blow torch on the muck-covered pavement . Grotesque: Tourists look in horror at lizards lying on their backs - cut open - with their insides on display . Live dogs sit in cages before they are roasted with blowtorches on the pavement. Three-metre-long snakes lie sprawled across the tables of blood-covered carcasses. Other delights include pickled rats, boar legs, and bite-size bats on sticks. And roasted lizards are cut open and displayed on their backs - with their insides on show. Casual: Locals casually survey the bloody carcasses of boars and bats, which are delicacies in the region . Snack: Bite-size black bats are sold on sticks to market-goers, which will make holiday-goers' stomachs turn . Controversy: The market is under constant surveillance by the government after selling endangered species . Graphic: Vegetables and spices are sold at the market but the hanging boar legs will stay in tourists' minds . The market, in the northern region of  Sulawesi, was marred by controversy in 1993 after government inspectors found sellers to be trading babirusa, an endangered type of wild pig. Despite numerous regulations put in place, it took years to eliminate the trade. However, the bizarre market has now become something of a tourist attraction - but few are willing to taste their way through the full menu. Not far from Langowan, the Tomohon Traditional Market also attracts a fair few horrified holidaymakers - and families planning their evening meal. All in a day's work: A market seller hacks away at a three-metre-long snake using three different knives . Portions: The segments are gruesomely displayed on the dirty, tiled worktops for customers to buy . Stash: One customer has stocked up on roasted rats for this evening's meal, piling them all into a basket . Grab-and-go: This man appears to have forgotten a bag - but seems not to mind carrying to wild boars' legs . Family day out: A child munches on a treat bought from the traditional market while his family select their meal . They casually survey the torched animals - lying frozen with a facial expression of horror - before selecting an entire snake or dog to serve up to the kids later. Travel blogger Raymond Walsh described the smell of the Tomohon market on his blog www.manonthelam.com. Mr Walsh said: 'In a word, appalling. There's something about the air that changes when there's that much death around. 'It hangs heavy and it made me queasy and light-headed at the same time... It's the first time I'd ever encountered anything like it.'
gpt: Langowan Market in North Sulawesi, Indonesia, is attracting tourists from all over the world who want to taste the unique and bizarre traditional food. Vendors at the market offer a variety of exotic dishes, including spit-roasted bats, battered snake, pickled rats, and boar legs. The market has become a popular destination for tourists who want to experience something new and different to their regular diet. Trying the delicacies at Langowan Market offers a chance to immerse oneself in the local culture, which has been handed down from generation to generation. However, the sale of endangered species at the market is a cause of concern for authorities. Government officials have been putting pressure on sellers to stop trading in threatened or illegally obtained animals. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has also expressed concern that the market is contributing to the decline in population of certain species. Despite these concerns, some vendors continue to sell these illegal products, which are seen as delicacies by many locals. The government's efforts to curb such sales have had little success, as many of these vendors have been doing business for generations and rely on the sale of these items for their livelihood. Local residents are divided on the issue, with some arguing that the market is part of their cultural heritage and should be protected from outside influence. Others believe that changes need to be made to ensure that the sale of endangered species ceases immediately. The local government, meanwhile, is exploring ways to address the concerns raised by conservationists without disrupting the livelihoods of the market's vendors. One solution being suggested is the introduction of alternative sources of income for vendors who stop selling illegal and endangered products. Despite the controversy, tourists continue to flock to the market to taste the unique traditional food on offer. Many visitors are aware of the ethical and environmental concerns surrounding the sale of certain products and do their best to avoid them, opting instead for dishes made from locally sourced, sustainable ingredients. Langowan Market is an important part of local culture, and the government's efforts to conserve endangered species are to be applauded. However, it is important to ensure that the livelihoods of the vendors are not negatively impacted in the process. With the right measures and support, it is possible to continue preserving and celebrating cultural traditions while also protecting threatened species.

By. Mia De Graaf. It is one of the biggest markets in the Indonesian province of North Sulawesi, attracting tourists from all over the world. The Langowan market is known for its exotic and bizarre traditional food, which has become a major draw for adventurous eaters. Tourists flock to the market to try a variety of unusual dishes, including spit-roasted bats, battered snake, pickled rats, and boar legs. While some may find these options unappetizing, others are eager to experience the local cuisine and support the local economy. However, the market has been under constant pressure from the government to stop selling endangered species. The Indonesian government has implemented strict regulations to protect the country's wildlife, and the Langowan market has been accused of violating these laws. Sellers at the market claim that they are not aware of the regulations and that they are simply trying to make a living. They argue that the animals they sell are not endangered and that they are an important part of the local culture. Despite the controversy, the market remains a popular destination for tourists. Many visitors are drawn to the market's unique atmosphere and the opportunity to try new and exotic foods. Others are interested in learning more about the local culture and way of life. The Langowan market is a significant contributor to the local economy, providing income for hundreds of families. The market's success has also led to the development of new businesses and infrastructure in the area. However, the government's efforts to regulate the market have had a negative impact on the local community. Many sellers have been forced to close their stalls or reduce their operations, leading to job losses and economic hardship. The situation has sparked a heated debate about the balance between conservation and economic development. Some argue that the government's regulations are necessary to protect the environment and prevent the extinction of endangered species. Others argue that the regulations are too strict and that they are harming the local community. The Indonesian government has promised to work with the local community to find a solution that balances conservation with economic development. However, the issue remains contentious, and it is unclear what the future holds for the Langowan market. In the meantime, tourists continue to flock to the market, eager to try the unique and exotic foods on offer. While some may be deterred by the controversy surrounding the market, others see it as an opportunity to experience the real Indonesia and support the local community. As one tourist noted, "I came to the Langowan market because I wanted to try something new and different. I didn't know about the controversy surrounding the sale of endangered species, but I'm glad I got to experience the local culture and try some of the unique foods on offer." Another tourist added, "I was a bit hesitant at first, but the food was actually really delicious. I had the spit-roasted bat, and it was amazing. I would definitely come back to the market again." The Langowan market may be under pressure from the government, but it remains a vibrant and bustling destination for tourists. Whether you're an adventurous eater or just looking for a unique cultural experience, the Langowan market is definitely worth a visit. In addition to the exotic foods on offer, the market also features a wide range of local handicrafts and souvenirs. Visitors can find everything from traditional clothing and jewelry to handmade crafts and artwork. The market's atmosphere is lively and festive, with vendors calling out to passersby and the smell of food wafting through the air. It's a truly immersive experience that allows visitors to connect with the local culture and community. As the debate over the market's future continues, one thing is certain: the Langowan market remains a beloved destination for tourists and a vital part of the local economy. Whether you're a foodie, a culture vulture, or simply looking for a unique experience, the Langovan market is a must-visit destination in North Sulawesi. ### | End of Response | ###

human_text: A soldier gave his sister the surprise of a lifetime by showing up unannounced at her wedding. Jessie Smith, 26, hadn’t seen her brother in several years before her brother Ryan Douglas surprised her by attending her June 29 wedding in Virginia. With Douglas is currently serving active duty in the US Army, Smith had resigned herself to the fact her brother would not be at the blessed event. ‘I was upset that he couldn’t make it but understood he had a career that he had obligations to,’ Smith told ABC News. SCROLL DOWN FOR VIDEO . Surprise!: Soldier shows at sister's wedding, brings her to tears . Douglas knew weeks in advance that he would be able to attend the wedding, but intentionally kept it a secret from most of the family for fearing of letting the secret out, according to ABC. When Douglas showed up in uniform it confused the photographer, who initially thought it might be Smith's soon-to-be husband. Nick Smith serves in the Coast Guard. ‘The photographer asked me, ‘Is Nick wearing his uniform?,’ because she saw someone wearing a uniform outside,” Smith told ABC. “I said no, and then wondered who was wearing their uniform. I peeked my head around and saw my brother and his wife and sister-in-law and freaked out.’ Smith cried tears of joy as she hugged her brother for the first time in what probably felt like an eternity, before hustling everyone out of the room to avoid her soon-to-husband. Tears of joy: Seeing her brother made Smith cry tears of happiness . Wiping away tears: Smith had to literally wipe away the tears after hugging brother Douglas . ‘I was ecstatic but also remembered we had to avoid Nick so I quickly ushered them all inside,’ Smith told ABC. A exceptional day made even more so by a rare visit from her brother, Smith told ABC she could not have been happier. ‘I rarely get to see my brother as we are both busy working on our careers and education, and it was amazing to get to have him there for my special day.’

Walking the catwalk in high heels can be tricky, even for the industry's most seasoned models. And on today's This Morning show, one producer who had to fill in for a model almost hurt her baby as well as her pride as she toppled off the set holding her young daughter. Model Ellie, who is also the show's producer, was carrying her daughter Poppy when she walked straight off the side of the catwalk in a Mrs Santa costume, leaving little Poppy in tears. Scroll down for video . Taking a tumble: Ellie, the show's producer who was modelling a Christmas outfit with daughter Poppy, tripped from the runway . The show had opened with adorable young Poppy scratching her head and looking sleepy in a cute and cosy Christmas one piece as presenters Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield cooed over her. 'Are you sleepy?' they asked as Holly became quite taken by the small child. But things took a turn for the worse as Ellie set off down the catwalk to model her Mrs Santa outfit. It started well: ...but as she strutted down the catwalk and approached the end she took a tumble . As she modelled a Santa outfit, she walked off the side and stumbled off the catwalk. Petite Ellie managed to cling onto her baby as Phillip asked: 'Oh Ellie, are you OK?' Faye Sawyer, This Morning's fashion . expert, was seen trying not to laugh while Phillip pointed out she was wearing very high heels, before joking 'she's been . on the gin as well'. They're ok! It has long been an integral part of school chemistry lessons - and a revision . aid for GCSE and A-level students - that ununpentium is the 115th element in the periodic . table .
The element was discovered in 2004 by a team of scientists at the Joint Institute for Nuclear . Research (JINR) in Dubna , Russia .
It is the heaviest naturally occurring element in the world , with an atomic number of 115 and a mass number of 290 .
Ununpentiums atomic structure is similar to that of uranium , with 92 protons and 108 neutrons in the nucleus .
However , it has 113 electrons - one more than uranium - and is therefore classified as a super-heavy element .
Its name is derived from the Latin word 'unum' meaning 'one' and 'pentium' which means 'five' .
This is because it has five protons and five neutrons in its nucleus .

human_text: So, will Lewis Hamilton be Happy after Sunday’s Formula One season finale in Abu Dhabi? The Briton, who must finish second to guarantee the title, was, despite the semi-smiles and waves to the crowd, somewhat downbeat after Nico Rosberg stormed to pole in qualifying. Hamilton was unable to match the supremacy of his Mercedes team-mate, but will take some comfort from the fact he starts directly alongside his rival for tomorrow’s race. VIDEO Scroll down to watch Join Lewis Hamilton on a lap of Abu Dhabi's Yas Marina circuit . Lewis Hamilton catches up with Pharrell Williams after Saturday's qualifying session in Abu Dhabi . Hamilton shares a joke with American singers Pharrell and Tyrese Gibson, who was sporting a  bandanna . The American singer is pictured with former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell in the Red Bull garage during qualifying . Pharrell Williams was the centre of attention when he arrived in the Abu Dhabi paddock on Saturday . American hit-maker Pharrell Williams, responsible for the pop anthem Happy, caught up with Hamilton after the qualifying session under the lights in Abu Dhabi. Hamilton has hinted at a career in music after he hangs up his racing gloves, but it is Pharrell who will take centre stage later on Saturday when he headlines tonight’s after-race concert on Yas Island. Pharrell, seen garage hopping during Saturday's qualifying session and pictured speaking to former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell, is the artist  also responsible for the hit ‘Lucky’. It's an adjective which could be used to describe Rosberg if he claims the championship this weekend. Hamilton will start behind pole-sitter Nico Rosberg for Sunday's title-deciding Abu Dhabi Grand Prix . Prince Harry shares a joke with Geri Halliwell in the Red Bull garage in Abu Dhabi . Hamilton failed to put together his best lap and will start second with Valtteri Bottas breathing down his neck . The German has won five fewer races than Hamilton this year, but would pinch the title if he wins on Sunday and Hamilton finishes outside the top two. 'It was a great day again today, it all worked out well,' said Rosberg. 'I put a good lap together in the end, but it's only one very small step. It's about the championship, not about the pole. 'I was hoping for a Williams to be between us, it didn't happen, but hopefully that can be the case tomorrow. 'My mindset now is I need to get the job done, to continue with the form I showed at the last race in Brazil. In any case I'm sure it will be a great race.'

human_text: LONDON, England (CNN) -- A U.S. company is offering a rare chance to holiday on a mega-yacht once used by a Hollywood star and her husband -- and thanks to the recession it's actually affordable. The 100-foot Katania normally would attract an additional $49,500 charter fee for a week's use. The 100-foot Katania was chartered by Hollywood star Hilary Swank and her husband, Chad Lowe. Seattle, Washington-based mega-yacht rental business CEO Expeditions usually charges around $100,000 a week to charter their 100-plus-foot yachts, but they have introduced a deal waiving the charter fees -- meaning guests will only need to pay for the running of the vessel. The move to make such vessels more affordable comes as the recession continues to put pressure on the luxury holiday and mega-yacht industries. Although the costs of crew and luxury food aren't extremely cheap, it is expected this move will open up the recession-strained market to many more potential holiday-makers. The Katania now costs less than $3,000 per day. Normally it would attract an additional $49,500 charter fee for a week's use. At the $2,950-per-day special rate, four people can stay on the Katania -- but with the maximum six on board ($450 extra per person) the cost per person is a slightly better $642. The price includes full crew, premium wines, gourmet food prepared by a private chef, amenities such as kayaks, hot tub, fishing/crabbing/shrimping equipment, and even a 30-foot whaler for guest use. According to the company, Swank said of her charter holiday: "We had an absolutely enchanted time aboard the Katania. A more beautiful yacht does not exist." There is one small catch with the deal -- the boat is based in the San Juan islands off the coast of Washington and British Columbia, and any cruises to other destinations will attract an additional charge to cover fuel costs. The company's owner, Bruce Milne, released a statement saying the deal was largely a result of the impact of the recession. "Travel is down, agents and brokers need deals, so rather than just a few full-price charters, we decided to stay busy, put more people to work, and help island tourism by doing charters at cost. "Since we started chartering 10 years ago, we have been looking for a chance to provide our 'Expeditions to the Extraordinary' in the San Juan Islands at a price any luxury traveler can afford -- this recession provides that opportunity," he said. Tim Wiltshire, director and sales broker at international yacht company Burgess Yachts, said the charter market isn't a complete disaster, so he was surprised to see such a discount. "I wouldn't have expected to see that," he said. "We are seeing discounts on average of about 25 percent. Although some people are trying interesting gimmicks to inspire new business." Wiltshire said CEO Expedition's fleet isn't among the biggest or most luxurious on the market, and this deal appears to be clever marketing stunt. His opinion is that other larger vessels still warrant their greater price tags.

LONDON, England (CNN) -- A U.S. company is offering a rare chance to holiday on 150-foot mega-yachts at a fraction of the usual cost, citing the global economic downturn as the reason for the discounted deal.

The luxury yacht charter company, which has previously chartered vessels to high-profile clients such as actress Hilary Swank, is waiving massive charter fees of up to $50,000 per day in a bid to attract more customers.

According to company officials, the decision to slash prices was made in response to the current economic climate, which has seen a significant decline in demand for luxury goods and services.

"We're not immune to the effects of the recession," said a spokesperson for the company. "As a result, we've had to rethink our pricing strategy in order to stay competitive and attract more customers."

The company's mega-yachts, which typically cost upwards of $10,000 per day to charter, are now available for rent for as little as $3,000 per day. This represents a staggering 70% discount on the usual rate.

One of the company's most popular yachts, a 150-foot vessel that has previously been chartered by celebrities such as Hilary Swank and Jennifer Lopez, is now available for just $2,500 per day. This is a significant reduction from the usual rate of $40,000 per day.

The company's decision to slash prices has been welcomed by potential customers, who are eager to take advantage of the opportunity to holiday on a luxury yacht at an affordable price.

"I've always dreamed of sailing on a mega-yacht, but I never thought it was within my budget," said one potential customer. "Now, thanks to this incredible offer, I can finally make my dream a reality."

The company's move is also seen as a sign of the times, with many luxury goods and services companies struggling to stay afloat in the current economic climate.

"It's a brave move by the company, but it's also a reflection of the current state of the economy," said an industry expert. "Luxury goods and services are often the first to be cut back when times get tough, so it's no surprise that the company is looking for ways to stay competitive."

Despite the challenges posed by the recession, the company remains optimistic about its future prospects.

"We're confident that our decision to slash prices will pay off in the long run," said the spokesperson. "We're already seeing a significant increase in interest from potential customers, and we're hopeful that this will translate into more bookings in the coming months."

As the global economy continues to struggle, it remains to be seen whether the company's decision to waive charter fees will be a success. However, one thing is certain - for those who have always dreamed of holidaying on a luxury yacht, this could be the opportunity of a lifetime.

In related news, the company has also announced plans to offer a range of special packages and promotions in the coming months, including discounts for repeat customers and special deals for groups.

"We're committed to providing our customers with the best possible experience, and we're confident that our new pricing strategy will help us to achieve this goal," said the spokesperson.

With the global economy showing no signs of improvement in the near future, it's likely that more companies will follow suit and offer discounted deals in a bid to stay competitive. Only time will tell if this strategy will pay off, but for now, it's a welcome respite for those looking to indulge in a little luxury without breaking the bank.

(CNN) -- If Manchester United rallies to win the English Premier League, it might look
human_text: (CNN) -- If Manchester United rallies to win the English Premier League, it might look back at Thursday's Boxing Day clash at Hull as a turning point. United trailed 2-0 within 13 minutes against a side that had lost only one home game in the league all season but Wayne Rooney inspired a comeback and the Red Devils prevailed 3-2 for a fifth straight victory in all competitions. Rooney set up Chris Smalling, scored a stunner to make it 2-2 in the first half and was on hand to pressure James Chester as the defender headed the own goal winner in the second half. Chester -- briefly a United player -- had opened the scoring and was thwarted in injury time by keeper David De Gea as Hull pushed forward in the dying stages. United finished the game with 10 men after Antonio Valencia's late red. Defending champion United, once 13 points off the pace in the Premier League, moved to within five of leader Liverpool ahead of Thursday's later kickoffs. "We had some poor results at the start of the season and we're showing some real quality in the last few weeks," Rooney told Sky Sports. "We're having a go. We're fighting for each other, we're working hard and we're ready for the challenge. "Hopefully we can surprise a few people." Chester took advantage of slack marking in the United box on a corner to lash a shot into the roof of the net in the fourth minute and United defender Jonny Evans failed to clear in the 13th, allowing David Meyler to double the lead on a low effort that deflected off the Northern Irishman. "It was my fault for the first one," said Rooney. But Rooney's perfect delivery teed up Smalling in the 19th minute and the England striker scored his 150th Premier League goal for Manchester United with a volley in the 26th minute. Alex Bruce -- the son of Hull manager and former United defender Steve Bruce -- struck the crossbar as United's defense wobbled again in the 63rd minute before Chester's gaffe from Ashley Young's dangerous cross in the 66th. Hull had more than a few opportunities to equalize in the final 10 minutes. Danny Graham's tame header went straight to De Gea, the Spaniard's poor punch led to panic and following Valencia's second yellow for kicking the ball away in the 90th minute, De Gea stopped Chester with his legs.
gpt: Manchester United secured their fifth consecutive win in all competitions after a thrilling 3-2 comeback victory over Hull City at Old Trafford on Saturday afternoon. United were stunned as they found themselves trailing by two goals within the first 13 minutes of the game. However, Wayne Rooney, who was starting his third successive match for the first time since August, sparked United's comeback. The captain assisted one goal, scored another and had a part to play in United's third as they completed a remarkable comeback win. The in-form hosts started the game poorly, with slack defending allowing Hull to take an early 2-0 lead courtesy of goals from James Chester and David Meyler. United's defence was caught out again as Hull threatened to add a third, but they managed to recover their composure and started to dominate possession. Rooney played a key role in United's equalizer, setting up Chris Smalling for the first goal, which gave the hosts a lifeline in the game. United continued to press and were rewarded when Rooney himself equalized with a brilliant curling shot from outside the box. With the momentum firmly in their favor, United continued to surge forward and were eventually rewarded with a wonderful third goal. This time, Rooney played a brilliant pass to Robin van Persie, who calmly slotted it past Allan McGregor in the 66th minute. Hull attempted to mount a comeback of their own, but United's defence held firm to secure all three points. It was only the second home defeat of the season for Steve Bruce's side, who were left to rue their missed opportunities in the early stages of the game. Speaking after the match, United manager Louis van Gaal praised Rooney's contributions and hailed his leadership qualities. "Rooney showed great character and leadership today. He was the spark that ignited our comeback and I am proud of the way the team responded," van Gaal said. The victory took United to fourth place in the Premier League standings, just two points behind third-placed Arsenal. With Rooney in fine form and the team showing a newfound resilience, United fans will be hoping that their impressive run of form continues in the weeks ahead.

(CNN) -- If Manchester United rallies to win the English Premier League, it might look  back on Saturday's 3-2 victory over Hull City as a turning point in their season.

Manchester United beat Hull City 3-2 at Old Trafford, extending their winning streak to five matches in all competitions. The victory marked a remarkable comeback for the Red Devils, who trailed 2--0 just 13 minutes into the match.

Wayne Rooney was the catalyst for the comeback, scoring one goal and setting up another. He also played a crucial role in United's winning goal, which was scored by Antonio Valencia in the 88th minute.

Rooney's first goal came in the 55th minute, reducing the deficit to 2-1. He then set up Robin van Persie for the equalizer in the 63rd minute. Van Persie's goal tied the match at 2-2, setting the stage for Valencia's winner.

"It was a great team performance," Rooney said in a post-match interview. "We showed a lot of character and determination to come back from 2-0 down. We're delighted with the three points."

The victory marked only the second home loss of the season for Hull City manager Steve Bruce. Despite the defeat, Bruce praised his team's effort, saying, "I'm proud of the players for the way they fought back. We had some good chances, but unfortunately, we couldn't capitalize on them."

Manchester United's victory marked their fifth consecutive win in all competitions, including the Premier League, FA Cup, and Champions League. The Red Devils have now moved up to third place in the Premier League table, just four points behind leaders Chelsea.

The win also marked a significant boost for Manchester United manager David Moyes, who has faced intense scrutiny in recent weeks. Moyes praised his team's performance, saying, "It was a great win for us. The players showed a lot of spirit and determination. We're pleased with the result."

For Hull City, the defeat marked a setback in their bid to avoid relegation. The Tigers currently sit in 17th place in the league table, just two points above the relegation zone.

Despite the loss, Bruce remains optimistic about his team's chances of staying up. "We've got a tough run of games coming up, but we're confident we can get the results we need to stay in the league," he said.

Assume you are an expert in the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML).
Your task is to answer the following question:
What are the key differences between supervised and unsupervised learning in machine learning?
### | Response | ###

In machine learning, there are two primary types of learning paradigms: supervised learning and unsupervisedlearning. While both types of learning aim to enable machines to learn from data, they differ significantly in their approach, objectives, and applications.

**Supervised Learning:**

In supervised learning, the machine learning algorithm is trained on labeled data, where each example is associated with a target output. The algorithm learns to map inputs to outputs based on the labeled data, with the goal of making accurate predictions on new, unseen data. The key characteristics of supervised learning are:

1. **Labeled data**: The training data is labeled, meaning each example has a corresponding target output.
2. **Predictive modeling**: The algorithm learns to predict the target output for new, unseen data.
3. **Error minimization**: The algorithm aims to minimize the difference between its predictions and the actual outputs.

Examples of supervised learning tasks include:

* Image classification (e.g., classifying images as cats or dogs)
* Sentiment analysis (e.g., determining whether a text is positive or negative)
* Regression (e.g., predicting house prices based on features like location and size)

**Unsupervised Learning:**

Unsupervised learning, on the other hand, involves training a machine learning algorithm on unlabeled data, where the algorithm must discover patterns, relationships, or structure in the data on its own. The primary objectives of unsupervised learning are to:

1. **Identify patterns**: Discover hidden patterns or relationships in the data.
2. **Clustering**: Group similar data points together based on their features.
3. **Dimensionality reduction**: Reduce the number of features in the data while preserving the most important information.

Key characteristics of unsupervised learning include:

1. **Unlabeled data**: No target outputs are provided, and the algorithm must find structure in the data itself.
2. **Exploratory analysis**: Unsupervised learning is often used for exploratory data analysis, where the goal is to gain insights into the data rather than make predictions.
3. **No error minimization**: Since there are no target outputs, there is no error to minimize.

(CNN) -- If Manchester United rallies to win the English Premier League, it might look -- at least in part -- to Wayne Rooney for inspiration.
Rooney scored two goals and set up another as Manchester United beat Hull City 4-2 at Old Trafford on Saturday to extend its winning streak to five games in all competitions.
The victory was United's 10th in a row at home in the Premier League, the longest such streak in the history of the English top flight.
"It's been a great start to the season for us," Rooney said. "We've won five games in a row and we're top of the league, so we're very happy."
Rooney's first goal came in the 13th minute, when he took a pass from Antonio Valencia and beat Hull goalkeeper Allan McGregor with a left-footed shot from the edge of the penalty area.
His second goal, in the 37th minute, was a header off a cross from Valencia. Rooney's third goal came on a penalty kick in the 52nd minute.
"He's a fantastic player," Hull manager Steve Bruce said of Rooney. "I think he's one of the best players in the world."
Hull's two goals came from Nikica Jelavic, who scored in the 23rd minute off a pass from Sone Aluko and in the 55th minute off a corner kick from Jake Livermore.
"We're disappointed with the goals we've conceded," United manager David Moyes said, "but we're delighted with the way we've played."
The victory gave United a 10-point lead over second-place Manchester City, which beat West Ham United 2-1 on Saturday.
"I think we've got a great chance," Moyes said of the Premier League title. "But we've still got a long way to go. We've got to make sure we keep winning games."

By . Thomas Durante . PUBLISHED: . 08:23 EST, 27 December 2012 . | .
human_text: By . Thomas Durante . PUBLISHED: . 08:23 EST, 27 December 2012 . | . UPDATED: . 14:10 EST, 27 December 2012 . Police in Idaho were able to crack the mystery of the parked car burglar in a case that the Scooby Doo gang could have solved - by following the suspect's footprints. Police in the town of Idaho Falls said Mother Nature aided them in the arrest by blanketing the area with some Christmas Eve snow on Monday morning. At about 5:45am, police said they began following tracks in the fresh snow that were suspiciously going from car-to-car on Holbrook Drive. Nabbed: Police reportedly followed footprints to a nearby home where they found their suspect, 20-year-old Cade Thomas Dixon . KIFI-TV reported that the footprints led the officers straight to a nearby home where they found the suspect, 20-year-old Cade Thomas Dixon. Dixon was taken into custody and charged with burglary. Sgt Phil Grimes of the Idaho Falls Police Department told MailOnline: 'Snow is an officer's best friend when it comes to robbery, and the worst enemy of the robber.' Sgt Grimes said that Dixon was booked in the Bonneville County Jail, and bond was set at $15,000. A listing on the jail's website showed that Dixon is still being housed at the jail. Police accused Dixon of trying to enter more than 100 vehicles during his alleged Christmas Eve crime spree, but only two of them had been unlocked. By. Thomas Durante. PUBLISHED:. 08:23 EST, 27 December 2012. |. 0 COMMENTS

Local authorities have made an arrest in connection with a recent string of burglaries in the downtown area. Cade Thomas Dixon, a 20-year-old resident of the neighborhood, was taken into custody yesterday evening after footprints left at the scene of one of the burglaries led police to his doorstep.

According to eyewitnesses, the burglaries occurred over the course of several nights, with thieves targeting local businesses and residences. The suspects made off with cash and other valuables, leaving behind few clues for investigators to follow.

However, it was a set of footprints discovered near one of the burglarized homes that ultimately led police to their suspect. The prints matched those of Dixon, who was subsequently brought in for questioning.

During the interrogation, police say that Dixon confessed to the crimes, revealing that he had stolen cash from several of the targeted locations, as well as a GPS unit from one of the homes.

Dixon has been charged with multiple counts of burglary and is currently being held at the local jail on a $10,000 bond.

Residents of the neighborhood are breathing a sigh of relief now that the suspect has been apprehended. "We're glad that the police were able to catch the person responsible for these burglaries," said Jane Smith, owner of one of the targeted businesses. "It's a big relief for all of us."

The investigation is ongoing, and police are urging anyone with information about the burglaries to come forward. In the meantime, residents are advised to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity to the authorities.

As for Dixon, he is scheduled to appear in court next week to face the charges against him. If convicted, he could face up to five years in prison for each count of burglary.

The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of community involvement in preventing and solving crimes. By working together, residents and law enforcement can make their neighborhoods safer and more secure.

In related news, the local police department is offering a reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of any other individuals involved in the burglaries. Anyone with information is encouraged to contact the police department at (555) 123-4567.

The PanicMe app can send red, amber or green alerts to let up to 30
human_text: The PanicMe app can send red, amber or green alerts to let up to 30 contacts know you are in danger . Smartphone users can now set off a personal panic button to alert family and friends that they are in danger. PanicMe fires off alerts of differing levels of importance to a chosen network of contacts if the user feels threatened or vulnerable. The sender's location is then pinpointed using GPRS and potential responders can see how close they are so they can put a plan of action in place. Offering a traffic light of options, a red alert tells contacts the sender is in imminent danger of being attacked or hurt, amber suggests you will need help soon, while green means you are in a low risk situation, such as being lost or breaking down. The alerts can be sent to up to 30 contacts and can be accessed by police, who are able to login when notified at their control room. Contacts are notified by pop-messages on their smartphones at regular intervals, with the space between the alerts depending on the panic button option. The alerts only stop once the alarm is deactivated by the sender. The app, which launches this week, was developed by experts at DataMe, who worked alongside local police forces to come up with a program to help people feel safer in their daily lives. Former Deputy Chief Constable David Lindley, who who acted as a consultant on the project, says: 'There may be any number of reasons and circumstances why people feel afraid or vulnerable. 'With so many people these days having a . mobile phone, apps such as PanicMe cannot only help to make those in . need feel much safer but can also give peace of mind to those who care . for them.' The alerts are delivered to your contacts' smartphones, using GPRS to pinpoint your location and showing them how close they are to you . Smartphone users can download a limited option of the PanicMe button for free, but it only offers a green panic alert. The complete version costs £14.99 and is available for the year on Apple, Android and Windows Smartphones. The app's release comes months after a survey by Ipsos Mori and Kings College London found that two thirds of adults did not believe that crime rates were falling, suggesting the public is more wary than ever about their personal safety. It's the latest smartphone add-on which can warn us of potentially dangerous situations - the recently unveiled MyWitness records video and audio to gather evidence during unexpected confrontations.
gpt: PanicMe, a new safety app, is set to revolutionize personal safety across the globe. The app sends out red, amber or green alerts to up to 30 chosen contacts when the user feels at risk. PanicMe’s unique features make it easier than ever to find assistance quickly when needed. The app works by pinpointing the user’s location using GPRS and then sends out an alert to the user’s chosen contacts. The contacts receive information on the user’s location, the specific nature of the emergency, and a link to a live map that shows who the closest responders are. The app has been developed in close collaboration with local police forces, ensuring that users have access to the most appropriate and relevant support when they need it most. PanicMe’s founders, two tech entrepreneurs from London, were inspired by their own personal experiences with crime and the lack of support systems available. Andrew and Martin wanted to create an easy-to-use, reliable safety app that would provide reassurance and support to the general public. With its unique features and user-friendly interface, PanicMe is now available to anyone who needs it. The red alert feature is triggered when the user is in serious danger and needs urgent assistance. It notifies the user’s contacts of the emergency and provides a live location so that responders can be sent to the exact location quickly. The amber alert feature is triggered when the user is in a potentially dangerous situation and needs help. For example, if someone is being followed by a stranger or feels unsafe in an unfamiliar area. The alert sends the user’s location and a request for help to their chosen contacts. The green alert feature is for times when the user feels uneasy and wants to let their contacts know where they are. It sends the user’s location to the chosen contacts without raising the alarm level. PanicMe’s founders say that since the app’s launch earlier this year, it has already been downloaded over 100,000 times. They believe that the app’s unique features and collaboration with local police forces have contributed to its growing success. “We wanted to create an app that would help people feel safer in their everyday lives,” Andrew said. “From our own experiences, we knew that many people feel vulnerable when they are out and about, and we wanted to give them a tool that would make them feel more confident and secure.” The app has already been used successfully in several emergency situations, including assaults, car accidents, and lost children. The live map feature has been lauded by many users as a gamechanger, making it easier for responders to locate the user quickly and provide assistance faster. PanicMe is set to expand globally, with plans to launch in several countries over the next year. The app’s developers are keen to work with local police forces in each of these countries to ensure that the app is tailored to the unique needs and challenges of each region. In the age of Covid-19, personal safety is more important than ever before. PanicMe provides peace of mind for anyone who wants to feel safe and secure, whether they are out for a jog around the block or traveling to a new city. PanicMe is available to download now on the App Store and Google Play.

The PanicMe app can send red, amber or green alerts to let up to 30  contacts know if a user feels at risk. The app uses GPRS to pinpoint the user's location, which is then displayed on a map along with the location of the closest respondent.

Developers of the PanicMe app have been working closely with local police forces to ensure that the app is as effective as possible in helping the public feel safer. The app is designed to be used in emergency situations, such as when a user feels threatened or in danger.

According to the developers, the idea for the app came about after a series of high-profile attacks on women in the UK. They wanted to create an app that would allow users to quickly and easily alert their friends and family if they felt at risk, while also providing them with a sense of security and reassurance.

The PanicMe app allows users to choose from three different alert levels: red, amber and green. A red alert indicates that the user feels in immediate danger and requires urgent assistance, while an amber alert suggests that the user feels threatened but is not in immediate danger. A green alert is used to indicate that the user is safe and does not require assistance.

When a user selects an alert level, the app sends a message to all of their chosen contacts, along with their location. The location is pinpointed using GPRS, which allows the app to display the user's location on a map. The map also shows the location of any respondents who have received the alert, making it easy for the user to see who is closest and can provide assistance.

The app has been designed to be user-friendly and easy to use, even in emergency situations. Users can select an alert level and send a message to their contacts with just a few taps on the screen. The app also allows users to add or remove contacts at any time, making it easy to keep their list of emergency contacts up to date.

In addition to the alert system, the PanicMe app also includes a range of other features designed to help users feel safer. These include a panic button that can be used to quickly and easily send an alert, as well as a feature that allows users to share their location with trusted contacts.

The app has already received positive feedback from users, who praise its ease of use and effectiveness in emergency situations. One user, who wished to remain anonymous, said: "I feel much safer using the PanicMe app. I can quickly and easily alert my friends and family if I feel at risk, and I know that they will be able to see my location and come to my aid if needed."

Local police forces have also praised the app, saying that it has the potential to be a valuable tool in helping to keep the public safe. A spokesperson for the police said: "We are always looking for new and innovative ways to help keep the public safe, and the PanicMe app is a great example of this. We are happy to have worked with the developers to bring this app to market, and we look forward to seeing the impact it has in the community."

With its potential to save lives and prevent crimes, the PanicMe App is a must-have for anyone who values their safety and security. By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 12:45 EST, 28 March 2013 . |
human_text: By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 12:45 EST, 28 March 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 09:20 EST, 29 March 2013 . The Chateau Laroze 2007 has been flying off the shelves of the German supermarket chain . It is not the first place you would think to go for fine wine – but budget store Lidl says it has been overwhelmed with demand for a £19.99 claret. The supermarket, perhaps  better known for discount lager than classy Bordeaux, is stocking a reputable St Emilion Grand Cru as part of a push for affluent  shoppers trying to bag a bargain. The Château Laroze 2007 is the most expensive wine ever sold by the German-owned chain. Lidl’s ‘Wine Cellar’ also includes a 2011 Châteauneuf du Pape at £12.49 and a 2011 Sancerre at £9.99. The wines were chosen by a panel including Master of Wine Richard Bampfield, who gave the Château Laroze an ‘outstanding’ score of 90 out of 100. The . current owners of Château Laroze, an obscure, St. Emilion classified . growth, are the Meslin family, who can trace their roots back to the . Gurchy family, who created the business in 1882, according to the Wine . Cellar Insider website. The 27 hectare Bordeaux vineyard of . Chateau Laroze is planted with 68 per cent Merlot, 26 per cent Cabernet . Franc and 6 per cent Cabernet Sauvignon. In the Chateau Laroze blog, the owner describes the wine as having sex appeal. Guy Meslin wrote in 2009: 'If any wine has sex-appeal, this one does. All the ingredients are melded and in place. 'The wood is nicely blended in and quite flattering, and nicely sets off the very fresh fruity hints. 'The tannins are not especially powerful, but contribute sheer silk and velvet. 'The finish prolongs all this with an emphasis on the aromatic freshness.' The supermarket launched its wine range after realising customers were willing to spend money on the finer things . He said: 'This is a Grand Cru Classé . which means it is at the top of the Bordeaux quality hierarchy and one . has to expect to pay more for it. 'This is very fine, showing the . fragrant aromas of St Emilion, a depth of flavour unusual for the . vintage and a wonderful long finish, the hallmark of a great Bordeaux.' Lidl is alone in selling the Château Laroze 2007 – it is only available from wholesalers otherwise. Lidl increased its share of the groceries market by 10 per cent between October and January. Aldi increased its share by 28 per cent and Iceland by 9.6 per cent over the same period. Ben Hulme, Lidl wine manager, said: . 'Since the recession hit, we’ve seen a shift in customer spending habits . with many people, even those from more affluent backgrounds, finding . smart ways to continue enjoying fine wines and good food at home. We . want to offer people the opportunity to enjoy really good wines at . prices that aren’t ridiculous.'
gpt: Discount supermarket chain Lidl has launched its first-ever premium wine range at the end of last year. The new line includes several high-end wines, including the acclaimed St. Emilion Grand Cru Chateau Laroze 2007. Customers have been snapping up the premium wines since their release, taking advantage of Lidl's reputation for value for money. The launch of the premium wine range represents a significant development for the discount grocery store, which has been steadily expanding its wine offerings in recent years. The new line includes a range of top-quality wines, designed to appeal to those looking for high-end wines without the exorbitant price tags commonly associated with such products. Among the new products now available at Lidl are a Chateau Laroze St. Emilion Grand Cru Classé 2007, a Châteauneuf du Pape 2018, a Balmoral Estate Sauvignon Blanc 2019, a Médoc 2016, and a Sancerre 2019. Each of these wines has been carefully selected to represent the best of its vineyard, with a focus on terroir, quality, and value for money. The St. Emilion Grand Cru Chateau Laroze 2007 has proved particularly popular with customers, with many taking advantage of Lidl's unbeatable prices to stock up on this acclaimed wine. The wine is known for its complex bouquet of dark fruit, cedar, and tobacco, with a rich and full-bodied palate that hints at spice and licorice. The Châteauneuf du Pape 2018 is another highlight of the new range, boasting a deep, rich flavor profile that reflects the unique terroir of the Rhone Valley. The wine is made with a blend of Grenache, Mourvèdre, and Syrah grapes, resulting in a wine that is full-bodied, fruity, and nuanced. Notes of blackberry, raspberry, and cherry mingle with hints of pepper and thyme, making this an excellent choice for pairing with red meat, game, or spicy dishes. The new wine range has been getting rave reviews from customers, who praise the quality and value of these high-end wines. Many have been surprised to find such top-quality wines at Lidl, which has long been known for its unbeatable prices on everyday grocery items. The launch of the new range highlights the supermarket's growing reputation for quality as well as value, demonstrating that even those on a tight budget need not compromise on quality when it comes to wine. The new premium wine range is not only a boon for customers looking for high-end wines at reasonable prices but also for the winemakers themselves. Lidl has been working closely with some of the best vineyards in Europe to source these premium-quality wines, creating new opportunities for these producers to reach a wider audience and expand their brand. Overall, the launch of Lidl's first premium wine range marks a significant development for the supermarket chain, which has been steadily growing its wine offerings in recent years. With a focus on quality, terroir, and value for money, this range is sure to appeal to wine enthusiasts looking for high-end wines without breaking the bank.
