human_text: Harassed? 90s Playgirl model Daniel Sawka is suing his former employer ADP after he says he suffered years of ridicule from employees because of his nude photos . A company that helps businesses handle personnel issues denies it forced one if its employees out of his job after it was discovered he had posed nude in Playgirl magazine. Daniel Sawka filed a federal civil rights lawsuit in May 2013 against Roseland, New Jersey-based ADP Inc. alleging sexual harassment. The company responded in a court filing Monday. Sawka worked as a regional sales manager for ADP, which offers workforce management services, including payroll services and human resources management, for other companies and says it has more than 610,000 clients around the world. Sawka, who worked for ADP in Windsor and later in Milford, alleges he was subjected to constant jokes and ridicule at work after a woman in his office discovered he had posed nude in the early 1990s in a lumberjack-themed spread for Playgirl and found the photos online. Jokes included 'a comment about homosexual men viewing the photos and what they would be doing while viewing the photos,' according to the lawsuit. '(ADP) employees would say 'timber' or 'lumberjack' in reference to the plaintiff and the plaintiff's photos.' Sawka, 49, said his co-workers continued to download the pictures at work even after he implored them not to and to 'leave me alone.' He said company employees brought the issue up during a dinner in New York honoring Sawka for his job performance and during a company outing to a New York Yankees baseball game. He said he went to the company's personnel department in February 2011 and was promised the company would take appropriate actions. His body was joked about, reports ABC News, including his genitals' and one comment was made about 'what homosexual men viewing the photos would be doing while viewing the photos.' He alleges the company failed to end the ongoing sexual harassment and he was 'constructively discharged,' a legal term meaning the conditions were so intolerable he was forced to leave the job in March 2011. 'The sexual harassment ... that included managers participating in the sexual harassment, condoning it, and failing to stop it caused (Sawka) to be treated unequally when compared to similarly situated sales managers,' the lawsuit says. The company, in its response, denies there was a 'pattern and practice' of jokes, sexually charged comments and ridicule. It also says it 'exercised reasonable care to prevent and correct promptly any alleged harassing behavior.' Sawka, who lives in Durham, is seeking damages for lost pay and benefits and emotional distress. A telephone call seeking comment from his attorney on Monday was not immediately returned. Sawka is suing ADP for 'sexual harassment ... that included managers participating in the sexual harassment, condoning it, and failing to stop it' and wants back and front pay, bonuses, personal days, lost pension/retirement benefits, and emotional distress .

By. Matt Blake. PUBLISHED:. 11:48 EST, 21 June 2012. |. 0 COMMENTS

A harrowing video has emerged from the besieged Syrian city of Homs, showing the devastating impact of the ongoing conflict on its residents.

The unverified footage, which was posted online last Friday, was captured by a daring filmmaker who zipped through the city's largely empty streets on a scooter, capturing the full extent of the destruction.

As he navigated the desolate landscape, the only sounds that could be heard above the rumble of the scooter's engine were the constant bursts of machine gun fire, which seemed to be coming from all directions.

At one point, the videographer stopped to assist a group of younger men, who were struggling to transfer a badly injured comrade from the trunk of a car into the back of a truck. The scene was a poignant reminder of the human cost of the conflict, which has been raging in Syria for over a year.

The video, which was posted by the anti-Assad news site Sawtbeirut.com, provides a stark glimpse into the reality of life in Homs, a city that has been under siege by government forces for months.

Rows of burned-out cars line the streets, while rubble and debris are scattered across almost every road. In one particularly striking image, a dining set can be seen perched precariously on the edge of a third-floor balcony, a grim reminder of the many families who have been forced to flee their homes.

The footage also captures the desperation and fear that seems to grip the city's residents, many of whom appear to be living in a state of constant terror.

Throughout the video, the sound of gunfire and explosions can be heard in the background, creating a sense of tension and unease that is impossible to shake.

Despite the danger, the videographer appears to be undaunted, continuing to film as he navigates the city's treacherous streets.

The video has sparked widespread outrage and condemnation, with many calling for an immediate end to the violence in Syria.

The United Nations has estimated that over 10,000 people have been killed in the conflict so far, with many more injured or displaced.

The international community has been criticized for its slow response to the crisis, with some accusing world leaders of failing to take decisive action to bring an end to the bloodshed.

As the situation in Syria continues to deteriorate, it remains to be seen whether the international community will finally take the necessary steps to address the crisis.

In the meantime, the people of Homs continue to suffer, caught in the midst of a conflict that seems to show no signs of abating.

The video provides a powerful reminder of the human toll of the conflict, and serves as a stark warning of the dangers of inaction in the face of such a grave humanitarian crisis.

It is a testament to the bravery and determination of the videographer, who risked his life to capture the truth of the situation in Homs.

As the world watches, it is clear that the people of Syria are in desperate need of our help and support.

The international community must come together to find a solution to this crisis, and put an end to the suffering of the Syrian people.

Only then can we hope to see a return to peace and stability in the region, and an end to the devastating conflict that has gripped Syria for so long.

human_text: Hull manager Steve Bruce has defended under-fire Wigan chairman Dave Whelan, insisting he is not a racist. Whelan has been accused of making anti-Semitic comments as well as claiming there was 'nothing bad' in calling a Chinese person a 'chink' during an interview with the Guardian. That comes on the back of his controversial appointment of Malky Mackay as Latics manager at a time when the former Cardiff boss is under investigation by the Football Association for allegedly exchanging discriminatory texts with then colleague Iain Moody. Malky Mackay was appointed Wigan boss this week, despite the text and email scandal . Whelan has come under fire and has faced accusations of being racist in some quarters . Whelan, 77, has since apologised for causing offence and Bruce, who managed Wigan on two occasions under Whelan's watch, is willing to stand as a character witness. 'Maybe sitting on the fence might be the easiest thing to do but I've worked under Dave Whelan twice - I know him very, very well,' said Bruce. 'There's no racism in him at all. Sometimes words can be said which can be misplaced, they can be out there in the public domain, but certainly when I've worked with him there's been no sign of racism. But Hull boss Steve Bruce has defended Whelan and insisted that he is not a racist . 'He is without question one of the best chairmen I've worked for. What you see is what you get.' Bruce also described appointing Mackay as Uwe Rosler's replacement prior to the FA verdict as a 'brave' call. 'It's a big brave decision by him,' added Bruce. 'But he thinks that's the best thing for his football club. Being Dave he'll be single-minded enough to see that through.'

Meanwhile, the Football Association is investigating the text message exchanges between Mackay and Moody, who was once the head of recruitment for Cardiff City.

"I've never known him to be anything other than what he is, which is a lovely, lovely man.
"It's a shame he's had to go through what he's gone through, but I'm sure he'll come out the other side of it."

By . Harriet Arkell . PUBLISHED: . 06:58 EST, 22 November 2013 . | .
human_text: By . Harriet Arkell . PUBLISHED: . 06:58 EST, 22 November 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 06:59 EST, 22 November 2013 . Marijuana use in one of London's most notorious jails was so rife that visiting officials carrying out an inspection noticed their clothes smelt of it, a shocking new report has revealed. Inmates of A and B wings in Brixton prison in south London are said to have smoked so much cannabis that its distinctive smell tainted the clothes of guards and visitors from the Independent Monitoring Board (IMB). The IMB report said the easy availability of illegal drugs in the Category C prison, which only had one sniffer dog, was a 'major concern' and was to blame for 'gambling, indebtedness, bullying and intimidation' amongst inmates. Cannabis use is so widespread at Brixton Prison, pictured, that visitors' clothes smelt of it, a new report says . Referring to concerns over bullying at the jail, it said: 'The fuel for much of the bullying was the availability of illegal drugs – much more noticeable than when Brixton was a local prison. 'Cannabis was sometimes being smoked so much on A and B wings that officers’ and IMB members’ clothes smelt of it.' The report said the drugs were largely being brought into the prison by men who had gone out on temporary licence - on day or overnight release - and said there had been a 'significant failure' by prison authorities to address this problem. It went on: 'A major concern for the Board this year has been the availability of illicit drugs, mobilephones, and other items of contraband. 'This has led to gambling, indebtedness, bullying and intimidation, resulting, in some areas, in a significant deterioration of the generally harmonious regime in the prison.' Other concerns were the availability of the synthetic marijuana drug known as Spice, and prisoners using home-made hooch. The independent report said cannabis was being brought into the jail by inmates who'd been on day release . The independent report concluded that a staff shortage at the prison was to blame. It said: 'Brixton is having to shoulder the burden of a significant headcount reduction. The prison’s staff complement fell about four per cent in the year covered by this report. 'By January 2014 there will be a 17% reduction compared with September 2012. This is bound to weaken further the regime’s effectiveness'. The report said there should be more searches of both prisoners and visitors, and said a second sniffer dog should be brought in to help.
gpt: A new report has revealed the troubling prevalence of drugs at a Category C jail in the UK. Independent Monitoring Board visitors noted the smell of drugs on prisoners’ clothes in the A and B wings of the facility, prompting further investigation. The report goes on to highlight the various negative consequences of drug use within the prison walls. Cannabis in particular has been blamed for fueling incidents of bullying, gambling, debt, and intimidation amongst inmates. The drug is thought to have been brought in by men returning from day release. This alarming trend underscores the security challenges posed by prison drug use. Despite efforts to combat drug smuggling, prisoners continue to find ways to acquire and consume illegal substances. The shortage of staff at the Category C jail is cited as one factor contributing to the problem. The report suggests that more needs to be done to address the root causes of drug use, such as mental health issues and social exclusion. Additionally, it recommends increasing staffing levels to better monitor visitors and keep a closer eye on prisoners. While the report paints a grim picture of the state of affairs at the Category C jail, it also highlights some promising developments. For example, the prison has implemented a harm reduction program that provides inmates with clean needles and education on safe injection practices. These efforts are seen as an important step towards reducing the negative impacts of drug use within the facility. However, much work remains to be done to ensure the safety and well-being of prisoners and staff alike. The report’s findings serve as a call to action for prison authorities, policymakers, and the broader public to address the systemic issues that contribute to drug use in prisons. It is hoped that the report will spur greater investment in mental health services, education and training for staff, and more effective monitoring of visitors and prisoners. Only through a coordinated and collaborative effort can the scourge of prison drug use be successfully tackled.

By. Harriet Arkell. PUBLISHED:. 06:58 EST, 22 November 2013. |. 0 COMMENTS
Prisoners at a Category C jail were found to have easy access to drugs, a report has revealed.
Visitors from the Independent Monitoring Board (IMB) noticed a strong smell of cannabis on the clothes of some inmates during a recent visit to the jail.
The report, which was compiled by the IMB, stated that the easy availability of drugs had led to a range of problems, including bullying, gambling, debt and intimidation of other inmates.
It is believed that the drugs are being brought into the jail by men who are returning from day release.
The report also highlighted the shortage of staff at the jail as a contributing factor to the ease with which drugs are being smuggled in.
The IMB is an independent body that is responsible for monitoring the conditions and treatment of prisoners in the UK.
The board's report stated: "There is a significant problem with the availability of drugs within the prison, particularly in the A and B wings.
"The smell of cannabis was noticeable on the clothing of some prisoners during our visit."
The report went on to say that the availability of drugs was having a negative impact on the lives of prisoners, leading to problems such as bullying, gambling and debt.
It was also noted that the intimidation of other inmates was a major concern, with some prisoners being forced to hand over their earnings to those who had control of the drugs.
The report stated: "The ease with which drugs can be obtained has led to a culture of fear and intimidation within the prison.
"Prisoners are being bullied and intimidated by those who have control of the drugs, and this is having a significant impact on their mental health and well-being."
The IMB's report also highlighted the issue of staffing levels at the jail, stating that the shortage of staff was making it easier for drugs to be smuggled in.
It was noted that the jail was operating with a reduced number of staff, which was making it difficult for prison officers to effectively monitor the prisoners and prevent the smuggling of drugs.
A spokesperson for the Ministry of Justice said: "We take the issue of drugs in prisons very seriously and are committed to tackling the problem.
"We are working closely with the police and other agencies to identify and disrupt the supply of drugs into prisons.
"We are also taking steps to improve the security of our prisons, including increasing the number of staff and improving the use of technology to detect and prevent the movement of drugs."
The spokesperson added: "We are aware of the concerns raised by the IMB and are taking action to address them.
"We are committed to providing a safe and secure environment for prisoners and staff, and we will continue to work with the IMB and other agencies to tackle the problem of drugs in prisons." The IMB's report is just the latest in a series of concerns about the availability of drugs in UK prisons.
In recent years, there have been a number of high-profile cases of prisoners being caught with large quantities of drugs, and there have been calls for greater action to be taken to tackle the problem.
The issue of drug use in prisons is a complex one, and it is clear that it will take a concerted effort from all agencies involved to effectively tackle the problem.
In the meantime, the IMB's report serves as a stark reminder of the scale of the problem and the need for urgent action to be taken. ### | End of Article | ###.harriet.arkell@thesun.co.uk. A report by the Independent Monitoring Board (IMB) has found that drugs are easily available to prisoners at HMP Whitemoor in Cambridgeshire.
The IMB, which is an independent body that monitors conditions in prisons, found that drugs were being brought into the jail by visitors.
The report, which was published on Tuesday, said that cannabis was blamed for bullying and intimidation of prisoners, as well as debt and gambling.
It also said that drugs were thought to have been brought into the Category C prison by men who were coming back from a day release.
It added that the shortage of staff at the jail was also to blame for the drug problem.
It said: ‘The IMB is concerned about the availability of drugs to prisoners at Whitemoor.
‘There is evidence that drugs are brought into the prison by visitors, and that drugs are being used by prisoners.
‘The shortage of staff is a contributory factor to the drug problem.’
The report also said that there was a shortage of staff in the jail, which meant that there were not enough people to supervise the prisoners.
This, it said, meant that there was not enough supervision of the prisoners, which led to bullying, intimidation and debt.
It continued: ‘There is a shortage of trained staff in the prison.
‘This means that there is not enough staff to supervise prisoners, which leads to bullying and intimidation.
‘It also means that there are not enough trained staff to deal with debt and gambling.’
It added: ‘It is clear that there is a drug problem in the prison, and that it is being brought in by visitors.’
It said that the IMB was concerned about the lack of supervision of prisoners, and the lack of training of staff.
It went on: ‘We are concerned that there is insufficient supervision of prisoners.
We are also concerned that there are insufficient trained staff.
This means that prisoners are not being supervised, and that they are not being trained.
This is a serious problem, and we are concerned that it is not being addressed.’
It concluded: ‘Whitemoor is a Category C prison, which means that it has a high level of security.
It is also a Category A prison, which is the highest level of security in the prison system.
It has a high number of inmates, and it is a Category B prison, which has a low number of inmates.
This makes it a high-risk prison, and we believe that it should be closed.
We believe that the prison should be closed because it is a high risk prison, and because it has a large number of inmates.’

highlights: Police officer to be freed in Illinois, Indiana shootings . Analysis of computer shows he was at home at time of crimes . Brian E. Dorian was being held on $2.5 million bail . One person was killed and three wounded in shootings south of Chicago .
prompt:
### | Instruction | ###
Your role is a professional news journalist.
Your task is to write a detailed news article based on the given highlights.
The article should be at least 534 words and 24 sentences.
Incorporate the following key highlights: Police officer to be freed in Illinois, Indiana shootings . Analysis of computer shows he was at home at time of crimes . Brian E. Dorian was being held on $2.5 million bail . One person was killed and three wounded in shootings south of Chicago .
Begin with the most important details, followed by context and supporting information.
Provide a clean, standalone response without extra instructions or editorial comments.
### | Response | ###
(CNN) -- A police officer jailed on a first-degree murder charge in a two-state shooting
human_text: (CNN) -- A police officer jailed on a first-degree murder charge in a two-state shooting rampage was on his computer at the time of shootings and could not have committed them, prosecutors said Tuesday evening. Brian E. Dorian, 37, was to be released on his own recognizance Tuesday night, and charges against him will be formally dismissed Wednesday, Will County State's Attorney James W. Glasgow announced. "I feel horrible that Brian Dorian went through this," said Glasgow, adding that evidence at the time and identification in lineups merited the charges. "At no time did we stop looking for exculpatory evidence." A forensic analysis of Dorian's home computer and its activity put Dorian at home at the time of the shootings, authorities said. The officer also told them he was watching sports programs and using e-mail. John Dorian, the officer's father, told CNN affiliate WLS he was "relieved" and "never doubted his son." Police now are looking at other leads in the shootings. Earlier in the day, Dorian appeared in court via a hookup from the Will County Jail. He did not speak but his attorney entered a not guilty plea, WLS reported. Several friends and relatives wore T-shirts bearing the message "Free Brian." "There's an innocent man sitting behind bars and somebody else is running around out there knowing that he got away with it. It's not fair," Jill Aggen, a friend of Dorian, told WLS. "No doubt in my mind. He's not capable of it." Dorian, an officer with the Lynwood Police Department, was arrested Friday in the killing of one person and the wounding of three others in the spree, which occurred south of Chicago, Illinois. He was held on a probable cause warrant, and bail was set at $2.5 million. Dorian, who according to WLS has been on medical leave for an injured shoulder the past year, was taken into custody Friday at his residence, said authorities. The shootings began about 10:30 a.m. October 5 at a construction site near Beecher, Illinois. The gunman killed one worker at the site and wounded two others, police have said. An hour later and about 10 miles away in Lowell, Indiana, authorities believe the same gunman opened fire again -- this time on a local farmer. Keith Dahl was shot in the left shoulder, arm and elbow, and then was robbed. Dahl told Lake County (Indiana) Sheriff's Detective Robert Martinez that the gunman approached him on his farm and started a conversation about bees before beginning to shoot. The gunman was believed to be using a revolver -- possibly a Colt .38-caliber or .357 Magnum -- because no shell casings were found at either scene, Lake County Sheriff Rogelio "Roy" Dominguez said.
gpt: A police officer who had been detained in connection with shootings in Illinois and Indiana is set to be released after a computer analysis showed that he was at home at the time of the crimes. Brian E. Dorian, a 37-year-old former police officer, had been held on a $2.5 million bail after being implicated in the shootings, which took place in the vicinity of Chicago. One person was killed and three others were injured in the shootings. Dorian, who had been employed as a police officer before being fired following the shootings, had maintained his innocence throughout the ordeal. He had argued that he was not present at the scene of the crime when the shootings occurred. After a thorough computer analysis, it was determined that Dorian was, in fact, at home at the time of the shootings. This information was instrumental in securing his release from custody. Dorian's lawyer, Jeffrey Tomczak, was pleased with the decision. "We're grateful to the computer analysis that showed conclusively that Brian Dorian was at home when the crimes were committed," Tomczak said. The shootings took place over a period of several days in the south of Chicago, in areas such as Crete and Beecher. The attacks had initially been blamed on a police impersonator, which led to widespread fear and concern among the residents of the area. The shootings left one man dead and three others injured, including a farmer who was shot while working in his field. The shootings had caused a great deal of anxiety in the community until Dorian's arrest. While Dorian had been detained, he had maintained his innocence and had pleaded with authorities to investigate further in order to clear his name. His family had also been vocal in their support, insisting that Dorian had nothing to do with the shootings. Dorian's release comes as a relief to both him and his family, as well as to the community at large. The true perpetrator of the shootings has yet to be identified, but authorities continue to investigate the matter. In conclusion, the release of Brian E. Dorian after computer analysis showed he was at home during the time of the shootings south of Chicago, is a positive development for all parties involved. While the true perpetrator remains at large, Dorian can now return to his life outside of custody thanks to the advanced technology used in the investigation.
Llama3.1:
(CNN) -- A police officer jailed on a first-degree murder charge in a two-state shooting  spree that left one person dead and three others wounded will be freed after an analysis of his computer showed he was at home during the time of the crimes.

Brian E. Dorian, a 32-year-old police officer from Illinois, was arrested last week and charged with first-degree murder and attempted murder in connection with the shootings, which occurred in Hammond, Indiana, just south of Chicago.

According to court documents, Dorian allegedly shot and killed one person and wounded three others in a series of shootings that took place over the course of several hours. The victims were identified as a 35-year-old man and three women, aged 25, 28, and 30.

Dorian was being held at the Lake County Jail in Crown Point, Indiana, on a $2.5-million bond. However, his lawyers argued that the evidence against him was circumstantial and that he had an alibi for the time of the shootings.

An analysis of Dorian's computer, which was conducted by a forensic expert, revealed that he was at home in Illinois at the time of the killings. The expert testified that Dorian's computer was connected to the internet at 9:45 p.m. on the night of the shootings, and that it remained connected until 10:15 p.m.

Prosecutors had argued that Dorian's phone records and GPS data placed him in the vicinity of the shootings at the time they occurred. However, Dorian's lawyers pointed out that the data was not conclusive and that it was possible for Dorian to have been in the area without actually committing the crimes.

The judge in the case ultimately agreed with Dorian's lawyers and ruled that there was not enough evidence to hold him on the charges. As a result, Dorian will be released from jail pending further investigation.

The release of Dorian has sparked outrage among the families of the victims, who are demanding justice for their loved ones. "We are shocked and disappointed by the decision to release Brian Dorian," said a family member of one of the victims. "We believe that he is guilty and that he should be held accountable for his actions."

The case has also raised questions about the reliability of forensic evidence and the use of technology in criminal investigations. "This case highlights the importance of careful analysis and interpretation of digital evidence," said a forensic expert. "It's not always as clear-cut as it seems, and it's up to the experts to make sure that the evidence is accurate and reliable."

The investigation into the shootings is ongoing, and authorities are still searching for any additional evidence that may link Dorian to the crimes. In the meantime, Dorian's release has left many in the community feeling uneasy and uncertain about the outcome of the case.

As the investigation continues, many are left wondering how a police officer could be accused of such a heinous crime and yet be released from jail due to a technicality. The case has sparked a heated debate about the justice system and the need for greater transparency and accountability.

In a statement, the police department where Dorian works said that they are cooperating fully with the investigation and that they take the allegations against Dorian very seriously. "We understand the concerns of the community and we want to assure them that we are doing everything in our power to ensure that justice is served," said a spokesperson for the department.

The case is a stark reminder of the complexities and challenges of modern law enforcement, where technology and forensic evidence play a critical role in solving crimes. As the investigation into the shootings continues, many are holding their breath, hoping that justice will be served and that the truth will finally come to light.
Falcon:
(CNN) -- A police officer jailed on a first-degree murder charge in a two-state shooting -- one of which left one person dead and three wounded -- will be freed on bond, a judge ruled Friday.
Brian Dorian, 29, was being held without bond since his arrest last month on charges of murder, attempted murder and aggravated discharge of a firearm in connection with the shootings in Indiana and Illinois.
Dorian, a police officer with the Chicago suburb of Oak Lawn, Illinois, was released on a $250,000 bond, according to the Cook County State's Attorney's Office.
He will be required to wear an electronic monitoring device and is not allowed to have any contact with the victims or witnesses in the case, the office said in a statement.
He is scheduled to appear in court for a preliminary hearing on March 7.
According to court documents, Dorian is accused of shooting and killing a man and wounding three others in two separate incidents.
In the first incident, Dorian allegedly shot and killed a man in the parking lot of a McDonald's restaurant in Crestwood, Illinois, on February 5.
The victim, 29-year-old Brian R. Johnson, was pronounced dead at the scene, according to a statement from the Cook County Medical Examiner's office.
The second incident occurred in the early morning hours of February 6, when Dorian allegedly opened fire on a group of people at a gas station in Chicago Heights, Illinois, according to court documents.
One person was killed in that shooting and three others were wounded, according to Cook County Sheriff's Office spokesman Frank Bilecki.
Bilecki said Dorian's gun was recovered at the scene of the Chicago Heights shooting.
The Chicago Heights Police Department said Dorian was off-duty at the time of the shooting.
He was charged with one count of murder, one count of attempted murder and one count of aggravated unlawful use of a weapon, according to Bilecki and court records.
The Cook County state's attorney's office did not immediately respond to CNN's request for comment.

Xiaoming Tsui was rescued after an anonymous tip-off was posted online .

Ms Tsui's son and daughter, who are in their 50s, have been arrested and are being questioned by police .
They are suspected of trying to kill their mother by starving her and leaving her to die .
Neighbours said they had not seen Ms Tsui for several days .

"She is very quiet and keeps to herself . She is a very good neighbour ."

She added: "I've never seen her son or daughter . I don't know who they are ."
A third neighbour, who asked not to be identified, said she had not seen the Tsui family for more than a week .
He said: “I don’t know them . I’ve never seen them .
“I’ve only seen her son and daughter . They are very nice people .”

human_text: By . Tara Brady . A death metal band is living up to the type of music it creates by risking suffocation and playing in an airtight, soundproof steel box. The band called Unfathomable Ruination perform with the doors of the steel box open . Security guards close the door and lock members of the death metal band inside the box . This performance art involves one sound-proof steel cube and a metal band that plays inside until oxygen runs out . The band will be performing three times a week until August 1 in London's financial district and much like the offices around it, passers-by cannot hear or see what is going on inside. According to the musicians, conditions inside the cube are extremely hot, but they feel it is worth it all in the name of art. Daniel Herrera, Unfathomable Ruination’s guitarist, said: ‘These are extreme conditions and we play extreme music so this our connection.’ The band play first with the doors open and then with the doors closed. The band play first with the doors open and then with the doors closed until the oxygen runs out in the box . The idea was the creation of artist Joao Onofre (pictured) standing in front of the band . According to the artist behind the piece, the box is a symbol of the 'boxy' offices in the area where people work. Onofre said: 'In this corporate architecture you do not see what is going on inside. The same thing is happening here.' So how long can a death metal band play in an airtight, soundproof box - the band lasted 14 minutes the first time they played and have so far reached the 19 minute mark.

The exhibition, which runs until August 1, features works by some of the world's leading artists, including Portuguese artist João Onofre, who created the piece featuring the band.

Onofre's work, titled "Untitled (2019)," is a large-scale installation that sees the band performing on a raised platform in the middle of a busy street.

human_text: Freda Murphy probably didn't think she needed to rely on a holy intervention to get the floor of her Birmingham home fixed. But that's exactly what she got. When the mother-of-five took a picture of her Erdington bathroom for insurers, she was stunned to discover the outline of a face she believes to be Jesus, with a tear falling from the right eye, present. But the spooky imprint is far from the first unexplained happening to occur at her 100-year-old home. Scroll down for video . Freda Murphy claims an image of Jesus appeared in a photograph she took at her Birmingham home . Mr Murphy says she can make out eyes, a nose, mouth, long hair and a beard in the imprint which appears in the photograph she took of her bathroom floor . Ms Murphy has been so rattled by things that go bump in the night, she’s called in a spiritualist. During her 19 years at the house, the 52-year-old and her family have encountered ghosts, heard babies cry in the night, and have even been prodded in their sleep. A baby is believed to have died at the property during the war. Ms Murphy said, on one occasion 'a mist, like a cloud, appeared above my head while I was hoovering. So much has gone on here. A lot of people have been frightened.' But she said the image of Christ is the strangest of the strange encounters the family have experienced. Ms Murphy explained: 'We’d just had the floor laid down and I was taking a picture for my solicitor. Ms Murphy says her family have encountered ghosts, heard babies crying and even been prodded in their sleep, in their haunted home . 'The floor was totally clear. When I looked at the image, it sent a shiver down my spine. I could makeout eyes, a nose, mouth, long hair and beard. A lot of people have said it looks like Jesus.' In another scene straight from a horror movie, Ms Murphy's sick soon claimed to have had a very personal encounter with the unknown. Ms Murphy said: 'As he lay in bed, massive beams of light bounced off the walls. He said he also felt something touching him.' She said the spiritualist had confirmed the family's suspicions about their house being haunted, saying, 'there was an awful lot of activity going on in the house'. Ms Murphy added: 'No one can explain it. And no one can tell us what it means.' Despite the scary happenings, Ms Murphy said she was 'not scared any more' and her family, including her children who are aged between 14 and 30, aren't going to move.
gpt: A family in Birmingham, UK, has been left terrified after a spooky image appeared in a photograph taken for insurers. The picture, which was taken during a routine inspection of the property, seems to show a ghostly figure lurking in the background. According to the family, this is not the first time they have encountered ghosts in their home. They reportedly called in a spiritualist who confirmed that there was "an awful lot of activity going on" at the property. The family, who have asked not to be named, say they have experienced a range of spooky incidents since moving into the house seven years ago. These include doors slamming shut on their own, objects moving by themselves, and strange noises such as footsteps and whispers. The photograph was taken by an inspector from the family's insurance company, following a claim for water damage. The family say they did not notice the spooky figure in the background until they were reviewing the images later. "It was really creepy," one family member told reporters. "We showed it to our friends and they all noticed the figure straight away. It's definitely not something we expected to see." The family's experiences have attracted the attention of paranormal investigators and ghost hunters, who are keen to explore the property for themselves. However, the family say they are not keen on the idea and just want to be left alone. "We're all terrified," another family member said. "We don't know what's going on in this house, but we know it's not good. We just want to find a way to get rid of whatever it is." The spiritualist who visited the property said that there was "a lot of negative energy" present and that the family needed to take steps to protect themselves. This could involve cleansing rituals, such as smudging with sage or using protective crystals, as well as keeping the home clear of clutter and negative emotions. The family say they are willing to try anything to rid their home of the spooky goings-on. They have even considered moving out, but are worried that the problem may follow them to their new home. This is not the first time that Birmingham has been in the news for spooky goings-on. The city is home to a number of reportedly haunted locations, including the famous "black monk" of HMP Birmingham and the spooky corridors of Aston Hall. For now, the family are still living in their haunted home, trying to cope with the spooky incidents that seem to be a regular occurrence. Whether they will be able to rid themselves of their unwanted housemates remains to be seen.

Freda Murphy probably didn't think she needed to rely on a holy intervention to get 100,000 pounds from her insurance company when she took a photo of a ghostly apparition in her living room. However, that's exactly what happened.

The image, which appears to show a shadowy figure standing in the corner of the room, was taken as part of an insurance claim for damage caused by a burst pipe. It was meant to be a routine inspection, but it turned out to be something much more extraordinary.

Murphy's family has been experiencing strange occurrences at their Birmingham home for some time now. Doors slamming shut, objects moving on their own, and disembodied voices are just a few examples of the paranormal activity they've encountered.

"It's been going on for years," Murphy said in an interview. "At first, we thought it was just the usual creaks and groans of an old house, but then we started to notice that things were moving on their own. Doors would slam shut, and we'd hear footsteps in the middle of the night."

The family has tried to brush it off as mere coincidence, but the frequency and intensity of the events have become too much to ignore. That's when they decided to call in a spiritualist to help them understand what's going on.

"I've been investigating paranormal activity for over 20 years, and I can tell you that this house is a hotbed of activity," said spiritualist, Jane Smith. "There's an awful lot going on here, and it's not just your run-of-the-mill poltergeist. This is something much more complex and sinister."

Smith believes that the ghostly apparition captured in the photograph is just the tip of the iceberg. She thinks that the house may be a hub for interdimensional activity, where spirits from other realms are trying to communicate with the living.

"It's not uncommon for houses like this to be portals to other dimensions," Smith explained. "The energy here is palpable, and it's attracting all sorts of entities. We're not just talking about your average ghost; we're talking about entities from other realms, dimensions, and planes of existence."

While the idea of interdimensional activity may seem far-fetched to some, Murphy and her family are convinced that something supernatural is at play. They're not sure what it is or how to stop it, but they're determined to get to the bottom of it.

"We just want to know what's going on and how to make it stop," Murphy said. "We're tired of living in fear of what might happen next. We just want to be able to walk into our own home without feeling like we're walking into a horror movie."

As for the insurance company, they're still trying to wrap their heads around the situation. They've never dealt with a case like this before, and they're not sure how to proceed.

"We're taking this very seriously," said a spokesperson for the insurance company. "We're working closely with the family and the spiritualist to try and understand what's happening. We'll do everything in our power to support them and find a resolution to this situation."

For now, the Murphy family remains trapped in a living nightmare, unsure of what the future holds or how to escape the clutches of the paranormal activity that's taken over their home. human_text: (CNN) -- China's Olympic adventure may be over, but new age chanteuse Sa Dingding is one global export that in many ways echoes the Beijing Olympic fantasy of "One World. One Dream." Sa Dingding's music should find a home on the iPods of millions of chill-out world music fans. Born to a Mongolian mother and Han Chinese father, she sings in Mandarin, Tibetan, Sanskrit, and the rare dialect of Lagu, while fusing chill-out beats and floaty instrumentation played on zither, horse head fiddle and bamboo flute. Already hugely popular in China, she has been finding similar success farther afield: Her first album sold 2 million copies in Southeast Asia, and she has appeared on MTV. Earlier this year she won a BBC Radio 3 World Music Award as well as performing at the Royal Albert Hall in London. Her linguistic skills and musicianship were honed from a young age. Born in Inner Mongolia in 1983, she spent three years until the age of 6 with her grandmother, living a nomadic life in northern China, where her imagination and creativity were allowed to roam free. "We actually lived in a small city between grassland and the big city. In spring time, we move to the grassland. And in winter time, we moved back to the city,"she told CNN's Talk Asia. "The whole memory of my childhood is in one word: Play. I just played everywhere on the grassland. And there a lot of interesting things happened which affected the ... life of mine." Later she became a student of Buddhism and yoga as well as becoming a multi-instrumentalist, releasing her first album at the age of 18. Melding different musical cultures and ethnic influences, notably Tibetan, has also caused a certain amount of discussion, especially on her own position toward the status of Tibet within China. "From a musician's point of view, Tibetan culture and its music cannot be seen as an isolated subject... lots and lots of other ethnicities have added their colors on the Tibetan culture. So I see the Tibetan culture nowadays as an integral part of the greater Chinese culture," she said. Aiming to avoid controversy, organizers of the Glastonbury festival dropped her from this year's lineup. "I don't quite understand the reason behind [it]. To me, art and music really belong to the whole world and they shouldn't be limited by boundaries. So I really hope that I could join Glastonbury next year," she said. Until then further explorations in language and music beckon, and there have been recent collaborations with house music DJ Paul Oakenfold and French chill-out duo Deep Forest in Europe. "It's very amazing because when I had to return to China, they drove me to the airport and told me: 'Life is full of miracles. When you first arrived here, these three songs didn't exist. But now you're leaving, and we have three wonderful new songs.'"

However, the musician's path to success has not been without controversy. He recently made headlines after being dropped from the lineup of the prestigious Glastonbury Festival, one of the biggest music festivals in the world, where he was slated to perform in front of a massive crowd. The decision to drop him was made due to concerns over the controversial nature of his music, which blends cultural elements from his Mongolian and Chinese heritage with electronic beats and modern instrumentation. Despite being disappointed with the decision, the musician has taken it in his stride, showing resilience and determination to continue pursuing his passion for music. In a recent interview, he stated that he was not surprised by the controversy surrounding his music, as he believes that his unique blend of ethnic and modern styles challenges people's preconceived notions about what music should sound like. Many of his fans have come out in support of him, calling the decision to drop him from the line-up "disappointing" and "short-sighted." They see his music as a celebration of diversity and an expression of his cultural heritage, and believe that he deserves a platform to share his talent with the rest of the world. The musician's success in South East Asia has not gone unnoticed, and many music critics have praised his ability to bridge cultural divides and create music that appeals to a diverse range of audiences. His debut album was a resounding success, featuring a range of songs that showcased his talent for blending traditional Mongolian and Chinese folk music with modern beats and electronic sounds. Despite the setback at Glastonbury, the musician is not deterred, and is currently working on a follow-up album that promises to be even more impressive than his debut. He has stated that he is keen to keep exploring the possibilities of fusing different styles of music together, and hopes to continue challenging people's ideas about what music should sound like. Overall, the half-Mongolian, half-Chinese musician is a rising star in the music industry, known for his unique blend of ethnic and modern styles. His debut album was a massive success, and despite facing controversy and setbacks, he remains determined to continue pursuing his passion for music and sharing his talent with the world.

(CNN) -- China's Olympic adventure may be over, but new age chanteuse Sa Dingding is 2008's hottest export. Born to a Mongolian mother and a Chinese father, this half-breed singer-songwriter has taken the music world by storm with her unique blend of ethnic influences and chill-out beats.

Sa Dingding's rise to stardom began with the release of her debut album last year. The album, which combines traditional Mongolian and Chinese instruments with modern electronic production, was an instant hit in South East Asia. In fact, it sold over two million copies in just a few short months, making her one of the best-selling artists in the region.

But Sa Dingding's success hasn't come without its challenges. Her music has been deemed too controversial by some, including the organizers of the prestigious Glastonbury Music Festival. Despite being one of the most anticipated acts of the festival, Sa Dingding was dropped from the line-up just days before the event was set to begin.

"I was shocked and disappointed when I found out I had been dropped," Sa Dingding said in an exclusive interview with CNN. "I had been looking forward to performing at Glastonbury for months, and to have it taken away from me was devastating."

Despite the setback, Sa Dingding remains optimistic about her future in the music industry. "I believe that my music has the power to bring people together and transcend cultural boundaries," she said. "I'm not going to let one setback hold me back from achieving my dreams."

Sa Dingding's music is a true reflection of her mixed heritage. Growing up, she was exposed to a wide range of musical influences, from traditional Mongolian throat singing to modern Chinese pop. "My mother would sing traditional Mongolian songs to me when I was a child, and my father would play Chinese classical music on his erhu," she recalled. "I think that's where my love of music first began."

As she grew older, Sa Dingding began to experiment with her own music, combining traditional instruments with modern electronic beats. The result was a unique sound that blended the best of both worlds. "I wanted to create music that was authentic and true to my roots, but also accessible to a wider audience," she explained.

Sa Dingding credits her parents with encouraging her to pursue her passion for music. "My parents were always very supportive of my music, even when I was just a child," she remembered. "They saw how much joy it brought me, and they encouraged me to keep pursuing my dreams."

Today, Sa Dingding is one of the most successful musicians in South East Asia, with a devoted fan base and a string of hit albums under her belt. But despite her success, she remains humble and grounded. "I'm just grateful to have the opportunity to share my music with the world," she said.

When asked about her plans for the future, Sa Dingding smiled mischievously. "I'm working on a new album right now, and I'm really excited about the direction it's taking," she revealed. "It's going to be a bit more experimental than my previous work, but I think it's going to be my best album yet."

As for the controversy surrounding her music, Sa Dingding takes it all in stride. "I know that my music may not be to everyone's taste, but I'm not going to compromise my artistic vision to appease others," she said firmly. "I'm proud of what I do, and I'm confident that my fans will continue to support me no matter what."

In the end, Sa Dingding's story is one of perseverance and determination. Despite facing setbacks and criticism, she remains committed to her art and her vision. The 26-year-old singer, who is half Mongolian and half Chinese, has just released her debut album, "Sa Dingding," which has sold more than two million copies in Southeast Asia.
The album's first single, "Half Mongolian, Half Chinese," has been a huge hit in China, where it has sold over 1.5 million copies.
"I'm very proud of this album," she told CNN. "It's my first album and I'm very happy with it."
The album is a mix of ethnic influences and chilled-out beats.
"My music is a mixture of Chinese, Mongolian and Western music," she said. "I think it's very unique."
Sa's music has been described as "chill-out beats" and she has been compared to the likes of Norah Jones and Sarah McLachlan.
But the singer, who has been dubbed "China's answer to Norah Jones," has also been accused of being too controversial.
She was dropped from the line-up of this year's Glastonbury festival in the United Kingdom after she was deemed too "controversial" by the organizers.

"It was my first time at Glastonbury and I was really looking forward to it," she added. "But I understand why they made the decision."
Sa, who was born in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, said she was proud of her Mongolian heritage.

highlights: British Airways says it has cancelled all flights until 31 December . French government has urged its citizens to leave Sierra Leone . World Health Organisation does not recommend any ban on travel or trade .

British Airways is suspending all of its flights between London and two West African nations
human_text: British Airways is suspending all of its flights between London and two West African nations for the rest of the year as the region struggles to contain the worst ever outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus. The airline initially said it was halting its service between Heathrow Airport and Liberia and Sierra Leone until the end of August due to ‘the deteriorating public health situation in both countries’, but it confirmed that it is extending the suspension until 31 December. The decision was announced by the Foreign & Commonwealth Office in an updated travel advisory for Britons. Grounded: British Airways has extended its flight ban for two countries dealing with an Ebola outbreak . In a statement provided to MailOnline Travel, British Airways said: ‘The safety of our customers, crew and ground teams is always our top priority and we will regularly reassess the routes in the coming months. ‘Customers with tickets on those routes are being offered a full refund or a range of rebooking options.’ British Airways, the national flag carrier for the UK, normally operates four flights a week between Heathrow Airport and Monrovia, Liberia, with a stopover in Freetown, Sierra Leone. Air France has suspended its flights to and from Sierra Leone, and the French government has urged French nationals to leave Sierra Leone amid concerns about the epidemic that has killed more than 1,400 people in four countries. Several airlines have stopped flying into and out of Guinea, Liberia, Sierra Leone and Nigeria as they grapple with the worst outbreak since the virus was first detected in 1976. British Airways followed the lead of Emirates, which became the first major international airline to cancel flights, and African carriers Arik and ASKY. Epidemic: More than 1,400 have died during the worst Ebola outbreak since the virus was first detected . Kenya Airways and Korean Air Lines have also halted flights to the region. The current outbreak is believed to have started in Guinea last December. The World Health Organisation said the risk of transmission of Ebola virus disease during air travel is low and it does not recommend any ban on international travel or trade. The FCO is encouraging people to refer to the National Travel Health Network and Centre’s website before travelling to the affected countries, but it has not implemented any travel restrictions. The FCO issued a warning on its website: ‘You should carefully assess your need to travel to these countries. If you do decide to travel, you should make sure you have adequate arrangements in place for onward travel/exit and have adequate emergency health provision.’ Ebola is spread by close contact with organs or bodily fluids from an infected person or animal – living or dead – and there is no proven cure or vaccine. The highly transmissible virus causes haemorrhagic fever that kills as many as 60 per cent to 80 per cent of the people it infects in Africa.

British Airways is suspending all of its flights between London and two West African nations  until the end of the year amid growing concerns over the spread of the Ebola virus.

The airline announced yesterday that it would be cancelling all flights to and from Sierra Leone and Liberia until 31 December, citing the need to protect the health and safety of its passengers and staff.

The move comes as the World Health Organisation (WHO) continues to monitor the outbreak of the deadly disease, which has claimed the lives of over 5,000 people in West Africa since the start of the year.

The WHO has reported that the number of new cases of Ebola has been declining in recent weeks, but the organisation has warned that the situation remains fragile and that more work needs to be done to contain the outbreak.

Meanwhile, the French government has issued a warning to its citizens, urging them to leave Sierra Leone as soon as possible due to the high risk of contracting the disease.

In a statement, the French foreign ministry said that the situation in Sierra Leone was "extremely serious" and that the risk of infection was "very high".

However, the WHO has stressed that there is no need for countries to impose travel restrictions or trade bans in response to the outbreak.

The organisation's director-general, Dr Margaret Chan, said that such measures would be counterproductive and would only serve to exacerbate the economic and social impacts of the outbreak.

"We do not recommend any travel or trade restrictions," Dr Chan said. "These measures would have a devastating impact on the economies of the affected countries and would make it even harder for them to respond to the outbreak."

Instead, the WHO is urging countries to focus on strengthening their healthcare systems and improving their ability to detect and respond to cases of Ebola.

The organisation is also working with governments and international partners to provide support and resources to the affected countries, including training for healthcare workers and the distribution of personal protective equipment.

The Ebola outbreak has had a significant impact on the global economy, with many countries imposing travel restrictions and trade bans in an effort to prevent the spread of the disease.

However, these measures have been widely criticised as being ineffective and counterproductive, and the WHO has called for a more coordinated and evidence-based approach to responding to the outbreak.

In the meantime, British Airways' decision to suspend its flights to Sierra Leone and Liberia has been welcomed by health experts, who say that it will help to reduce the risk of the disease spreading to other parts of the world.

"This is a sensible decision," said Dr Jeremy Farrar, director of the Wellcome Trust. "The risk of Ebola spreading to other countries is very real, and airlines have a responsibility to protect their passengers and staff."

The suspension of flights is likely to have a significant impact on trade and commerce between the UK and Sierra Leone and Liberia, with many businesses relying on air travel to transport goods and people.

However, the British government has said that it will do everything it can to support the affected countries and to help them to recover from the outbreak.

"We are working closely with the WHO and other international partners to support the response to the Ebola outbreak," said a spokesperson for the Department for International Development. "We will do everything we can to help the affected countries to recover and to rebuild their economies."

As the situation continues to unfold, one thing is clear: the Ebola outbreak is a complex and multifaceted crisis that requires a coordinated and evidence-based response from governments, international organisations, and the private sector.

British Airways is suspending all of its flights between London and two West African nations - Sierra Leone and Liberia - due to the outbreak of the Ebola virus.
The airline said in a statement: "British Airways has suspended all flights to and from Freetown, Sierra Leone, and Monrovia, Liberia, until further notice.
"The airline will continue to monitor the situation and will resume flights as soon as it is safe to do so."
The move comes after the World Health Organisation (WHO) said it did not recommend any travel or trade bans in response to the outbreak.
In a statement, the WHO said: "There is currently no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission of Ebola outside of West Africa.
"There is no justification for measures that unnecessarily interfere with international traffic or trade."
The Sierra Leone government said it was "deeply concerned" by the WHO's statement.
It said in a press release: "The government of Sierra Leone is deeply concerned by the WHO statement that there is currently no justification for travel or trade restrictions in relation to the Ebola outbreak in West Africa."
It added: "Sierra Leone will continue to work closely with the WHO and the international community to ensure that the Ebola outbreak is contained."
The French government has also urged its citizens not to travel to Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea.
A statement from the French foreign ministry read: "In view of the current situation, the French government recommends that its citizens do not travel to these three countries."
The statement added that the French embassy in Sierra Leone would remain open.
The World Health Organisation has said there is no need to ban travel or trade to the affected countries.
The organisation's director-general, Dr Margaret Chan, said there was "no justification" for measures that interfere with international travel or trade.

highlights: A former Apple employee found that Facebook was draining battery . Background processes on iPhones run by the app eat up as much as 5% . This keeps the app updated and gives you push notifications . But turning it off is a good way to prolong your phone's life .
prompt:
### | Instruction | ###
Your role is a professional news journalist.
Your task is to write a detailed news article based on the given highlights.
The article should be at least 450 words and 26 sentences.
Incorporate the following key highlights: A former Apple employee found that Facebook was draining battery . Background processes on iPhones run by the app eat up as much as 5% . This keeps the app updated and gives you push notifications . But turning it off is a good way to prolong your phone's life .
Begin with the most important details, followed by context and supporting information.
Provide a clean, standalone response without extra instructions or editorial comments.
### | Response | ###
By . Jonathan O'Callaghan . A quickly draining battery can be a pain for many
human_text: By . Jonathan O'Callaghan . A quickly draining battery can be a pain for many iPhone users. But it turns out one of the most popular apps might be to blame. A former Apple Store Genius has unearthed evidence that the Facebook app is eating away at your phone’s juice. Is Facebook draining your battery? A former Apple Store employee has discovered that the popular third-party app runs processes in the battery that can decrease your phone's juice . According to Scotty Loveless from Overthought.org: 'I just got the iPhone 5s about two weeks ago, and thought my battery was draining a little too quickly. ‘Being the nerd that I am, I decided to run the app Instruments from Xcode, Apple’s developer tool, in order to see what the problem was. ‘During this testing, Facebook kept jumping up on the process list even thought I wasn’t using it. ‘So I tried disabling Location Services and Background App Refresh for Facbook.' Doing this, Loveless noticed that his battery percentage increased from 12% to 17%. Disable Background App Refresh for apps other than Facebook. Turn off push email. Stop push notifications from apps you don't use frequently. Turn on airplane mode when you haven't got a signal anyway. Stop closing apps, as your phone uses more battery each time it opens them again. ‘I have confirmed this behaviour on multiple iPhones with the same result,’ continues Loveless. ‘Bad, Facebook, bad.’ Fortunately, as Loveless points out, there is an easy fix. Navigating to Settings > Privacy > Location Services will enable you to turn off Location Services for Facebook. Then go to Settings > General > Background App Refresh to turn that functionality off for Facebook. One of the reasons for this might be that Facebook is introducing more features as it bids to become your number one communications service. This isn’t the first time Facebook has been caught causing phone users trouble, though . Previously in January MailOnline reported that the app was reading your texts, which the company claims is required for security reasons. You can turn off Location Services for Facebook within the iOS Settings menu to save battery life . Heading into your settings will also allow you to turn off 'Background App Refresh' for Facebook, saving more battery life but at the expense of not getting constant updates .
gpt: A former Apple employee has discovered that Facebook may be the culprit behind your phone's quickly draining battery life. The social media giant's background processes on iPhones have been found to consume as much as 5% of your phone's battery, even when you are not actively using the app. While this feature keeps the app updated and enables push notifications, it may be worth disabling to help prolong your phone's battery life. The discovery was made by Matt Galligan, a former employee of Apple, who tweeted about his findings. He noted that he had disabled Facebook's background processes on his iPhone and found a significant improvement in battery performance. The background processes, also known as Background App Refresh, allow apps to update in the background even when you are not using them. This feature is convenient for keeping your apps up-to-date and receives push notifications when new content is available. However, these processes can also drain your phone's battery faster than usual. The issue is not exclusive to Facebook, and many other apps with background processes can have a similar effect on your phone's battery. Galligan, however, found that Facebook was one of the largest culprits responsible for draining phone batteries. Disabling Facebook's Background App Refresh feature is relatively easy to do. To turn off the feature, go to 'Settings' on your phone, then 'General,' and then 'Background App Refresh.' This will take you to a screen where you can either disable the feature for all apps or select specific apps to turn off. Disabling the feature may lead to longer battery life and a smoother performance of your iPhone. The discovery has come as a surprise to many iPhone users who have been struggling with the issue of fast-draining battery life. The ease with which this problem can be resolved has been well received by many, while others have criticized Facebook for not optimizing their app for better battery performance. In conclusion, Facebook's Background App Refresh feature has been responsible for draining the batteries of many iPhone users. Disabling the feature is an easy way to prolong your phone's battery life and can lead to better overall performance. It is a simple step that may help solve the problem of fast-draining batteries that trouble many iPhone users.
Llama3.1:
By. Jonathan O'Callaghan. A quickly draining battery can be a pain for many  iPhone  users, but a former Apple employee has shed some light on why this might be happening. It turns out that Facebook is one of the main culprits behind this issue.

According to a former Apple employee, who wished to remain anonymous, Facebook's background processes on iPhones can consume as much as five percent of the device's battery life. This may not seem like a lot, but it can add up over time, especially if you're an avid user of the social media platform.

So, what exactly are these background processes doing? Essentially, they're keeping the app updated and giving you push notifications. This means that even when you're not actively using Facebook, the app is still running in the background, eating away at your battery life.

But don't worry, there's a simple solution to this problem. Turning off the "Background App Refresh" feature for Facebook can help prolong your phone's battery life. To do this, go to Settings > General > Background App Refresh, and toggle off the switch next to Facebook.

It's worth noting that this issue isn't unique to Facebook. Other apps, such as Instagram and Twitter, also have similar background processes that can drain your battery. However, Facebook seems to be one of the biggest offenders.

This news comes at a time when many iPhone users are looking for ways to extend the life of their devices. With the constant stream of new features and updates, it's no wonder that batteries are taking a hit. But by taking a few simple steps, such as turning off background app refresh, users can help prolong their phone's battery life.

In an interview with The Verge, the former Apple employee explained that Facebook's background processes are designed to keep the app updated and give users push notifications. However, this comes at a cost, as the app continues to run in the background, consuming battery life.

The employee also noted that this issue is not unique to Facebook, but rather a common problem with many social media apps. "It's not just Facebook," the employee said. "A lot of social media apps do this. But Facebook is definitely one of the worst offenders."

So, what can you do to avoid this issue? For starters, you can turn off background app refresh for Facebook and other social media apps. You can also consider using a battery-saving feature, such as Low Power Mode, which can help reduce battery consumption.

Another option is to use a third-party app, such as Battery Doctor, which can help you monitor and manage your battery life. These apps can provide you with detailed information about which apps are consuming the most battery life, allowing you to make informed decisions about which apps to keep running in the background.

Ultimately, the key to extending the life of your iPhone's battery is to be mindful of which apps are running in the background and to take steps to limit their battery consumption. By following these simple tips, you can help keep your phone's battery healthy and prolong its overall lifespan.

In conclusion, the findings of the former Apple employee highlight the importance of being aware of which apps are consuming our battery life. By taking a closer look at our phone's settings and making a few simple changes, we can help extend the life of our devices and avoid the frustration of a quickly draining battery.

The NTSB continues to rule out mechanical causes in a deadly Bronx train crash while
human_text: The NTSB continues to rule out mechanical causes in a deadly Bronx train crash while adding to the possibility that human error was involved. Federal safety investigators have all but eliminated mechanical problems as the cause of the December 1 derailment but added one more clue suggesting the engineer might not have been as attentive as he should have been. At 7:11 a.m. that Sunday -- about 11 minutes before the derailment -- the engineer did not dim the train's headlights as required when it passed another train, the National Transportation Safety Board said Monday. Engineer William Rockefeller Jr. acknowledged to investigators having a lapse in attention as the train approached a sharp curve, according Rockefeller's lawyer, Jeffrey Chartier, and his union representative.  The train's motion might have caused him to nod off -- a case of what the lawyer termed "highway hypnosis." Four people died and dozens were injured when the train, traveling at about 82 miles per hour, derailed on the curve, which has a 30 mph limit. The NTSB said Monday it believes that positive train control, a high-tech system that targets human error, could have prevented the crash.  The safety board has pushed the system for about 20 years.  Congress is requiring most major railroads, including Metro-North, to install the costly systems by the end of 2015. Railroad announces safety upgrades . The NTSB said it has completed its inspection of the train and found no anomalies. The "dead-man" switch -- a foot pedal that must be depressed to keep the train moving -- was also working, the board said.  Nor did it find problems with speed sensors, the brake control unit or the train's propulsion controller. The board reiterated that it found no problems with the tracks or the signal system. Finally, the board said it conducted a "site/distance" test and found no problems with visibility. "As a result, at this time, the NTSB believes that if positive train control technology was installed on this line and train, it would have required the engineer to slow the train to an appropriate speed or stop the train in the event the engineer did not do so, likely preventing the derailment," the board said in a statement. Investigators are still awaiting results of crew drug tests and cellphone records, the board said, and it is continuing interviews with passengers, Metro-North employees who were riding on the train and first responders. Train crash victim was 'pure goodness,' widow says .
gpt: Federal investigators looking into the tragic December 1 train accident in Washington have all but ruled out mechanical issues as the cause, according to a recent statement by the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB). The accident, which left four people dead and dozens more injured, occurred when Amtrak's southbound train 501 derailed while traveling over a newly constructed section of track, sending several train cars plummeting onto a busy highway below. Since the incident, investigators have been working tirelessly to determine the cause of the derailment. While it was initially rumored that the accident may have been caused by a problem with the track, it has since been confirmed that there were no issues with the newly constructed segment. Now, after weeks of investigation, the NTSB has revealed that the cause of the accident can likely be attributed to human error. Specifically, they found that the train's engineer failed to follow standard protocol when passing another train on the same track. According to the report, the engineer failed to dim the train's lights, as required by industry regulations.  The failure to dim the lights may have temporarily blinded the engineer of the other train, causing the tragic derailment. As a result, the NTSB has announced that it plans to work closely with Amtrak officials to ensure that proper safety protocols are followed in the future. In the wake of the accident, Amtrak officials have expressed their condolences to those affected and have reiterated their commitment to safety. The company has also announced that it will be conducting an internal review of its safety policies and procedures to ensure that similar incidents do not occur in the future. Meanwhile, the families of those killed or injured in the accident have expressed their frustration with the investigation, noting that more needs to be done to prevent future tragedies. They have called on Amtrak officials to take more decisive action to address safety concerns and have urged lawmakers to pressure the industry to increase safety standards. As the investigation into the accident continues, it is clear that there are still many unanswered questions. However, one thing is certain - this tragic event has served as a stark reminder of just how important it is to prioritize safety in the transportation industry.

By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 18:00 EST, 4 February 2013 . |
human_text: By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 18:00 EST, 4 February 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 03:36 EST, 5 February 2013 . French airstrikes targeted fuel depots and bases of Islamist extremists in northern Mali yesterday, as the military intervention turns away from cities and toward the radicals’ desert outposts. French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said on France-Inter radio yesterday that the strikes hit the Kidal region, near the border with Algeria, for the second night in a row. The extremists 'cannot stay there a long time unless they have ways to get new supplies,' he said. Intervention: A convoy of Malian troops makes a stop to test some of their weapons near Hambori, northern Mali, on the road to Gao, as the French led military operation continued, on Monday . Ready for action: French Troops dismount to secure a demining team clearing the road near Hambori, northern Mali, on the road to Gao, on Monday . French Mirage and Rafale planes also pounded extremist training camps as well as arms and fuel depots north of the town Kidal and in the Tessalit region. The French intervened in Mali on Jan. 11 to stem the advance of the al-Qaida-linked fighters, who had taken over much of the African country and enforced harsh rules on the population. After pushing extremists out of key cities, France is now pushing to hand over control of those sites to African forces from a U.N.-authorized force made up of thousands of troops from nearby countries. Frontline: French soldiers in a British made armored car lead a French supply convoy near Hambori, northern Mali, on the road to Gao, on Monday . Airstrikes: A convoy of French supplies reaches Gao, northern Mali, Monday, while French troops launched airstrikes on Islamic militant training camps and arms depots around Kidal and Tessalit in Mali's far north . 'In the cities that we are holding we want to be quickly replaced by the African forces,' Fabius said Monday. Asked whether the French could pull out of the fabled city of Timbuktu and hand it to African forces as soon as Tuesday, Fabius responded, . 'Yes, it could happen very fast. We are working on it because our vocation is not to stay in the long term.' But it is far from clear that the African forces - much less the weak Malian army - are ready to see the thousands of French troops, fighter planes and helicopters withdraw and take full responsibility, in case the Islamic extremists attempt a comeback from their desert hideouts.
