By. Daily Mail Reporter. PUBLISHED:. 18:00 EST, 4 February 2013. |  Updated:. 19:30 EST, 5 February 2013.

French warplanes have launched a series of airstrikes against extremist training camps and fuel depots in Mali, targeting the radical Islamist groups that have taken control of the north of the country.

Mirage and Rafale fighter jets were used in the operation, which was carried out in the early hours of yesterday morning. The strikes were aimed at disrupting the militants' ability to train and equip their fighters, as well as cutting off their supply lines.

The French military said that the operation was a success, with several key targets hit. However, the exact extent of the damage is not yet clear.

The airstrikes were the latest in a series of military interventions in Mali, which has been embroiled in a conflict with Islamist extremists for several years. The militants, who are affiliated with al-Qaeda, have taken control of a large swathe of the country, including the cities of Timbuktu and Kidal.

The French military intervention, which began on January 11, has been aimed at supporting the Malian army in its efforts to retake control of the north. The operation has been widely supported by the international community, with the United Nations Security Council passing a resolution authorizing the use of force to restore stability to the region.

The French military has been using a combination of air and ground forces to target the militants. In addition to the airstrikes, French troops have been working with Malian soldiers to retake key towns and cities from the extremists.

The operation has been complex and challenging, with the French military facing stiff resistance from the militants. However, the French military has reported several key successes, including the recapture of the town of Konna, which was a key stronghold of the extremists.

The airstrikes against the fuel depots and training camps are seen as a significant development in the conflict. The fuel depots are believed to be a key source of supply for the militants, and the destruction of the training camps will make it more difficult for them to recruit and train new fighters.

The French military says that the operation is ongoing, and that further airstrikes are likely in the coming days. The international community is watching the situation closely, with many countries providing support to the French military effort.

The conflict in Mali has raised concerns about the spread of extremism in the region, and the potential for the militants to establish a foothold in West Africa. The French military intervention is seen as a key part of the international effort to prevent this from happening.

In a statement, the French military said: "The operation is ongoing and will continue until the objectives have been achieved. The French military is working closely with the Malian army and other international partners to ensure the success of the operation."

The United Nations has welcomed the French military intervention, saying that it is a crucial step in restoring stability to the region. The UN Secretary-General, Ban Ki-moon, said: "The situation in Mali is extremely serious, and the international community must act quickly to prevent the spread of extremism."

The conflict in Mali is a complex and multifaceted issue, with a range of different actors and interests at play. However, one thing is clear: the French military intervention has marked a significant turning point in the conflict, and the outcome will have far-reaching consequences for the region.

As the situation continues to unfold, one thing is certain: the international community will be watching closely to see how the conflict develops, and what the ultimate outcome will be. The stakes are high, and the consequences of failure could be severe. But for now, the French military remains committed to its mission, and is determined to see it through to the end.
Falcon:
By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 18:00 EST, 4 February 2013 . | |
Airstrikes focused on radical's desert outposts, fuel depots and training camps.
The Mirage and the Rafale planes bombed extremist training camps and desert outposts.
The airstrikes were carried out by Mirage 2000 and Rafale fighter jets.
The strikes were carried out in the Adrar des Ifoghas mountains in the south-east of the country.
Al Qaeda's North African wing, known as Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), claimed responsibility for the attack.
AQIM said in a statement: 'The attack was carried out by a group of mujahideen from the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL).'
The group said the attack was in retaliation for the French military intervention in Mali.
French President Francois Hollande said: 'France will continue to support the Malian authorities in their fight against terrorism.'
He added: 'We will do everything to ensure the success of the Malian army in its fight against the terrorists.'
The French military intervention began on January 11.
It is the first time France has intervened militarily outside its borders since the end of the Algerian war of independence in 1962.
Algerian President Abdelaziz Bouteflika said the French intervention was a 'legitimate response' to the 'terrorist threat' posed by the Islamists.
He added that France's intervention in Mali was 'an act of solidarity' with the Malian people.
French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said the French military operation in Mali would last 'as long as necessary'.
He said the operation would continue until the Islamists were driven out of Mali's north.
The Islamists seized control of the northern two-thirds of Mali in March last year.
Mali's President Amadou Toumani Toure was forced to flee the country after the Islamists took control of the capital, Bamako.
He fled to neighbouring Burkina Faso, where he is now living in exile.
Al-Qaeda's North Africa chief, Mokhtar Belmokhtar, is believed to be leading the Islamists in the north.
He is a former member of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group, which fought against Muammar Gaddafi's regime in the 1990s.
He has also been linked to the 1998 bombings of the U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, which killed more than 200 people.

The Royal Navy launched an unarmed warhead in an awe-inspiring display of Britain's powerful nuclear
human_text: The Royal Navy launched an unarmed warhead in an awe-inspiring display of Britain's powerful nuclear deterrent. The Trident II was blasted into the sky by HMS Vigilant, a nuclear-powered Vanguard Class submarine, in the Atlantic just off the coast of Florida. The Navy has not test-fired a ballistic missile since 2009. Navy chiefs said the successful launch confirms the credibility of the UK's nuclear deterrent. Scroll down for video . Launch: A still taken from video of the missile firing from HMS Vigilant . Soaring: The missile streaks into the sky over the Atlantic Ocean . First Sea Lord Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope said: 'The Royal Navy has for over 43 years continuously operated the UK’s nuclear deterrent to stringent safety standards and HMS Vigilant’s latest test firing before she returns to the patrol cycle reflects that successful deterrence is based upon strong determination. 'One of the core roles of the Royal Navy, the Continuous At Sea Deterrent remains an enduring strategic capability, underpinning our nation’s commitment to the preservation of peace in our uncertain world.' News of the launch comes at the same time Defence Secretary Philip Hammond announced an additional £350M worth of funding for the next stage of design work for Successor, the future generation of UK nuclear-armed submarines. human_text: A simple saliva test was yesterday hailed as the holy grail in the early detection of deadly diseases such as cancer. It could also apply to dementia, Alzheimer’s, type 2 diabetes and auto-immune diseases, the researchers said. The study, the most comprehensive analysis ever conducted of a particular type of molecules in human saliva, reveals that saliva contains many of the same disease-revealing molecules that are in blood. A simple saliva test could be the best new way to test for early signs of cancer and other diseases, researchers have claimed (file image) Dentists may soon be able to take saliva samples to analyse for disease. The report’s lead author Dr David Wong, a dental expert at the University of California in Los Angeles, said the research could lead to self-diagnostic devices. 'If we can define the boundaries of molecular targets in saliva, then we can ask what the constituents in saliva are that can mark someone who has pre-diabetes or the early stages of oral cancer or pancreatic cancer - and we can utilise this knowledge for personalised medicine. 'If you don’t look in saliva, you may miss important indicators of disease. There seems to be treasure in saliva, which will surprise people. ‘This could indicate that wearable gear that informs you whether you have a disease – even before you have any symptoms – is almost here,’ he said. Many of the molecules visible in cancer patients' blood could be identified in saliva, researchers discovered (file image of a human cancer cell) Dr Wong's laboratory discovered that some of the same RNA that is inside human cells are also present in saliva and can be used to detect diseases - a surprising finding, he said, because enzymes in saliva can degrade RNA, making the mouth “a hostile environment. The new research involved analysing 165 million genetic sequences, details of which are published in the scientific journal Clinical Chemistry.

The research, conducted by a team of scientists at the University of Alberta in Canada, tested a particular type of molecule found in saliva and discovered that many of the same indicators found in blood are present in the mouth as well. The study involved examining the levels of extracellular vesicles (EVs) in saliva, which are small sacs containing molecules that can be exchanged between cells. The researchers found that these molecules can be used to track changes in inflammation, which is known to be a factor in a wide range of health conditions. By examining the levels of EVs in saliva, they were able to identify various health indicators and predict the progression of conditions such as Alzheimer's, dementia, and type 2 diabetes. The researchers believe that this new method of testing saliva could be a game changer in the diagnosis of these and other health conditions, as it is non-invasive and easy to administer. It could potentially replace the need for blood tests, which can be more expensive and require more equipment. Dr. Naweed Syed, a professor at the University of Alberta and co-author of the study, said, "We believe that this new method of testing saliva could revolutionize the way we diagnose and monitor a wide range of health conditions. By examinig these molecules in saliva, we can quickly and easily identify potential health issues and take appropriate action." There is still much work to be done in this area, as the researchers acknowledge that additional testing is needed to validate their findings. However, the potential benefits of this new testing method are clear. It could make it easier for healthcare providers to diagnose and monitor a wide range of health conditions, ultimately leading to better health outcomes for patients. Falcon:
A simple saliva test was yesterday hailed as the holy grail in the early detection - and treatment - of Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and dementia.
The test, developed by researchers at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), can detect the presence of particular types of molecules in the mouth.
These molecules are present in the blood of people with Alzheimer's, diabetes and type two diabetes.
The study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, found that the test could also be used to diagnose dementia and Alzheimer's.
"This is the first time we've been able to detect Alzheimer's in saliva," said the study's lead author, Dr. John Cirrito.
"It's a huge step forward in our understanding of the disease."
Dr. Cirrito said the test could be used to identify people at risk of developing Alzheimer's as early as their 30s.
He added that the test would also be able to identify people with the disease in their 40s and 50s, as well as those in their 60s, 70s and 80s.
The researchers tested the test on more than 1,000 people.
They found that those who had Alzheimer's had higher levels of the molecules in their saliva than those who did not have the disease.
They also found that those with the disease had lower levels of the same molecules in their blood.
Dr Cirrito said: "This is a major breakthrough in Alzheimer's research.
"We've known for a long time that Alzheimer's is a disease of the brain, but we've never been able to find a way to detect it in the body.
"Now we've found a way to do that, and it's going to change the way we think about Alzheimer's."
The researchers are now planning to test the test on a larger group of people to see if it can be used to detect the disease in its early stages.
They are also hoping to use the test to identify people who are at high risk of developing the disease.

According to a groundbreaking study published in the Journal of Clinical Oncology, researchers have discovered that certain molecules present in human saliva can serve as reliable indicators of various health conditions.

The new research, conducted by a team of scientists at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), involved analyzing the saliva of over 1,000 participants to identify specific biomarkers associated with different diseases. The findings revealed that many of the same indicators present in blood are also found in the mouth, paving the way for a non-invasive and cost-effective diagnostic tool.

One of the most significant breakthroughs of the study is the potential for early detection of cancer. The researchers found that certain molecules in saliva can detect the presence of cancer cells in the body, even before symptoms appear. This could revolutionize the way cancer is diagnosed and treated, allowing for earlier intervention and improved patient outcomes.

In addition to cancer, the study also identified potential biomarkers for heart disease and stroke. High levels of certain molecules in saliva were found to be associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, while others were linked to a higher likelihood of stroke. This could enable healthcare professionals to identify individuals at risk and take preventative measures to reduce their chances of developing these conditions.

Furthermore, the researchers believe that the saliva test could also be used to diagnose dementia and Alzheimer's disease. Early detection of these conditions is crucial, as it can significantly improve treatment outcomes and quality of life for patients. By identifying biomarkers in saliva, healthcare professionals may be able to detect these diseases at an earlier stage, allowing for more effective management and care.

The study's lead author, Dr. Maria Rodriguez, emphasized the significance of the findings, stating, "This research has the potential to transform the way we diagnose and treat various diseases. A simple saliva test could become a game-changer in healthcare, enabling us to detect conditions earlier and improve patient outcomes."

While the study's results are promising, further research is needed to validate the findings and explore the potential applications of the saliva test. However, the implications of this breakthrough are vast, and it is likely that we will see significant advancements in the field of diagnostics in the coming years. As the medical community continues to explore the possibilities of this new technology, one thing is clear: a simple saliva test could be the key to unlocking better health outcomes for millions of people around the world.

(Spoiler alert: They think she's just being Miley.) But while both those stars were shrugging their shoulders, another music legend was sharpening her claws. "I'm not old-fashioned," Cher told USA Today in an interview published Tuesday. "She could have come out naked, and if she'd just rocked the house, I would have said, 'You go, girl.' It just wasn't done well. She can't dance, her body looked like hell, the song wasn't great, one cheek was hanging out. And, chick, don't stick out your tongue if it's coated." EW: Paula Patton reacts to Miley Cyrus' VMAs performance . Ouch! It's one thing to slam Miley's choice of outfit or sexually-charged behavior; it's quite another to question the girl's talent itself. And coming from someone who knows a thing or two about rockin' it while wearing revealing outfits — not to mention clearly visible buttocks — that comment is harsher still. EW: Britney Spears defends Miley Cyrus on 'GMA', plus 4 other things we learned . Evidently, Cyrus is taking Cher's burn in stride. She hasn't responded to Cher's words on social media, choosing instead to keep touting the phenomenal success of "Wrecking Ball," her latest single. ("#1 on Billboard. #1 on iTunes. #1 on Spotify. #1 on Streaming. #1 on Digital songs. #1 most added to pop radio. #1 on VEVO," according to Miley.) And maybe it was the young star's high-road tactics — not to mention a barrage of criticism about her criticism — that prompted Cher to backtrack on Twitter yesterday. "What I should have said [is],"I didn't like it that much,but she's Pushing The Envelope,being an ARTIST !" the Oscar winner wrote. "She's Talented,& DIDNT COMMIT A FELONY[.]" Good points all, Cher — though some might argue that "flicking that tongue as deamons do" should be grounds for at least a time-out. (CNN) -- Reactions to Miley Cyrus at the VMAs: People are still having them! Earlier , the "We Can't Stop" singer took the stage at the 2013 MTV Video Music Awards to perform her new single, "Wrecking Ball."
Cyrus, 20, wore a flesh-colored two-piece outfit that left little to the imagination as she gyrated on a giant wrecking ball.
The performance was met with mixed reviews, with some calling it "disgusting" and "tasteless," while others said it was "amazing."
"Miley Cyrus' VMAs performance was the worst thing I've ever seen in my life," wrote one Twitter user. "I can't believe I just watched Miley Cyrus twerk on a wrecking ball," wrote another.
Cyrus later took to Twitter to backtrack on her performance, writing, "I'm sorry if I offended anyone. I didn't mean to hurt anyone's feelings. I just wanted to make people happy. I love you all."
The singer's performance wasn't the only controversial moment of the night.
Earlier in the show, Robin Thicke and Miley Cyrus performed their new song, "Blurred Lines." Thicke, 36, was joined on stage by a group of scantily clad women who danced suggestively to the song's lyrics: "I know you want it / So come and get it / If you think I'm sexy / Come and get me / Cause I'm feeling myself / And I wanna love myself / Tonight."
The performance sparked outrage on social media, with many calling it misogynistic and degrading to women.
"Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' is the most misogynistic song I've heard in a long time," wrote one user on Twitter. "It's 2013 and we're still objectifying women in music videos," wrote another user.
Thicke later apologized for the performance, writing on Twitter, "Last night was supposed to be fun and entertaining. I know I went too far. I am the first to admit it. I crossed the line. I made a bad choice. I apologize."
The VMAs weren't the first time Thicke has been accused of objectifying women. In 2010, the singer's song "Sex Therapy" was criticized for its lyrics, which included the line, "Let's get naked and do it on the sink."

highlights: Cocaine contributed to Billy Mays' death, says autopsy report . Mays died from heart disease; cocaine use played role in illness, report said . Mays died June 28 .
prompt:
### | Instruction | ###
Your role is a professional news journalist.
Your task is to write a detailed news article based on the given highlights.
The article should be at least 333 words and 12 sentences.
Incorporate the following key highlights: Cocaine contributed to Billy Mays' death, says autopsy report . Mays died from heart disease; cocaine use played role in illness, report said . Mays died June 28 .
Begin with the most important details, followed by context and supporting information.
Provide a clean, standalone response without extra instructions or editorial comments.
### | Response | ###
(CNN) -- An autopsy report issued Friday by Hillsborough County, Florida, cites cocaine as a
human_text: (CNN) -- An autopsy report issued Friday by Hillsborough County, Florida, cites cocaine as a contributing factor in the death of TV pitchman Billy Mays, who died in June at age 50. The Hillsborough County medical examiner's office said cocaine use contributed to Billy Mays' heart disease. "Mays died from a lethal arrhythmia of the heart caused by hypertensive and arteriosclerotic heart disease," the county said in a statement attributed to Dr. Leszek Chrostowski, the associate medical examiner who conducted the autopsy. "He further concluded that cocaine use caused or contributed to the development of his heart disease, and therefore contributed to his death," it added. The fact that toxicology tests detected only breakdown products of cocaine, not the drug itself, led Chrostowski to conclude that Mays had used cocaine "in the few days prior to death but not immediately prior to death." Cocaine is a stimulant that can raise blood pressure and thicken the wall of the left ventricle of the heart, one of the organ's four main pumping chambers. The autopsy also found low concentrations of ethyl alcohol "consistent with social consumption of a few beverages" as well as the narcotic drugs hydrocodone, oxycodone and tramadol. Mays had prescriptions for the drugs -- which were found in therapeutic or subtherapeutic concentrations -- to ease hip pain. In addition, the tests found evidence of two tranquilizers -- alprazolam (Xanax) and diazepam (Valium) -- which are commonly prescribed for a variety of ailments, including anxiety and insomnia. Both drugs were determined to be in therapeutic or subtherapeutic concentrations. Mays was found dead at his home near Tampa on June 28. Mays, with his booming voice, was famous for fronting products such as OxiClean and Orange Glo in TV commercials.

The report states that the excessive use of cocaine likely put a significant strain on Mays' heart and worsened his pre-existing heart condition. Mays' wife, who commissioned the autopsy, said in a statement that she hoped the report would help others learn from her husband's tragic demise. She urged people who struggle with addiction to seek help and get properly treated. Mays' passing sent shockwaves through the advertising industry, where he was a well-known and respected figure. He became a household name after appearing on several popular TV infomercials, most notably for OxiClean and Orange Glo cleaning products. He was known for his energetic and enthusiastic sales pitches, which made him a beloved figure to many. The news of Mays' drug use has saddened fans and colleagues alike, but it has also highlighted the dangers of substance abuse. The report underscores the need for more education and awareness about the risks of drug use, particularly for those with pre-existing health conditions. TV reporter Muntadhar al-Zaidi, shown in a file photo, was jailed after throwing his shoes at President Bush. Hundreds of students at Diyala University in Baquba carried banners demanding the release of Muntadhar al-Zaidi -- described by demonstrators as an "honorable Iraqi." Smaller protests emerged in the Anbar province city of Falluja and in two Baghdad locations -- Baghdad University in the northern part of the city and western Baghdad's Ameriya district. In those events, students also took to the streets. Al-Zaidi threw his shoes at Bush while Bush and Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki were holding a Sunday news conference after the president's surprise visit to Baghdad. The journalist was dragged to the ground, hustled out of the room and arrested. Watch Muntadhar al-Zaidi throw his shoes at Bush » . Dhirgham al-Zaidi, the shoe-thrower's brother, said the journalist hated the "material American occupation" and Iranian influence in Iraq. Asked about the incident by CNN's Candy Crowley, Bush said, "I didn't have much time to reflect on anything. I was ducking and dodging." He said the journalist was "looking for notoriety" and that authorities shouldn't overreact in their treatment of him. TV networks across the world continue to air the shoe-throwing scene, which has touched a nerve in the Arab world, where there has been an outpouring of support for al-Zaidi -- a correspondent for the Egyptian-based Al-Baghdadia TV. The network, which has been airing rolling live coverage about the incident, is urging his release and has invited guests who support him into its studio.  Watch Arab reaction to the incident » . Its crawls include messages of support from Iraqis and foreigners. Iraqis have been receiving short text messages of support on their cell phones, and some of the notes are short poems. Al-Baghdadia reported Tuesday al-Zaidi called one of his brothers and said he was in the custody of judicial authorities and will appear Wednesday in Baghdad's Central Criminal Court. He asked his defense team to meet him there, the network said. Web sites and Facebook pages devoted to al-Zaidi have also been posted.

BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- Protesters across Iraq Tuesday urged government authorities to free the TV  journalist who threw his shoes at U.S. President George W. Bush during a press conference in Baghdad.

Hundreds of students from the University of Baghdad carried banners demanding the release of Muntadar al-Zaidi, who was taken into custody by Iraqi security forces immediately after the incident.

Al-Zaidi, a correspondent for the Cairo-based Al-Baghdadia television network, hurled both of his shoes at Bush during a joint press conference with Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki at the International Zone in Baghdad.

Demonstrators described al-Zaidi as an 'honorable Iraqi' and called for his immediate release, saying he had acted out of patriotism and frustration with the U.S. presence in Iraq.

"I am proud of him," said one demonstrator. "He did what we all want to do, but we are afraid to do it."

Al-Zaidi's brother, Dargham, told CNN that the journalist hated American and Iranian influence in Baghdad and had been planning the shoe-throwing incident for months.

"He hated the American occupation and the Iranian interference in our country," Dargham said. "He wanted to express his anger and frustration in a way that would be noticed by the whole world."

Dargham also said that his brother was not motivated by a desire for fame or notoriety, but rather by a sense of patriotism and a desire to draw attention to the suffering of the Iraqi people.

However, White House officials disputed this account, saying that al-Zaidi's actions were clearly driven by a desire for notoriety.

"This was a stunt, plain and simple," said White House Press Secretary Dana Perino. "It was not a spontaneous act of protest, but rather a calculated attempt to get attention."

The incident has sparked a heated debate in Iraq about the role of the media and the limits of free speech.

Some Iraqis have praised al-Zaidi for his bravery and willingness to challenge the U.S. president, while others have condemned his actions as unprofessional and disrespectful.

The incident has also raised questions about the safety and security of journalists in Iraq, where many have been killed or injured while covering the conflict.

The Iraqi government has promised to investigate the incident and determine whether al-Zaidi will face charges for his actions.

In the meantime, al-Zaidi remains in custody, and his fate hangs in the balance.

As the debate rages on, one thing is clear: the incident has brought international attention to the plight of the Iraqi people and the complexities of the conflict in Iraq.

It remains to be seen how this incident will play out, but one thing is certain - it will not be forgotten anytime soon. BAGHDAD, Iraq (CNN) -- Protesters across Iraq Tuesday urged government authorities to free the TV "journalist" who threw his shoes at U.S. President George W. Bush during a news conference in Baghdad last week.
Demonstrators in the southern city of Basra and the northern city of Mosul carried banners demanding the release of 28-year-old Muntadar al-Zeidi.
Al-Zeidi, a reporter for the Al-Baghdadia satellite channel, was detained by Iraqi security forces after hurling his shoes at Bush during a Dec. 14 news conference at Baghdad International Airport.
"Al-Zaidi is an honorable Iraqi," said a protester in Basra, who gave his name only as Ahmed. "He is a hero."
"We want him to be released immediately," said another protester, who gave her name only as Fatima. "We don't want him to go to jail. We want him to come back to his family."
The demonstrators in Basra and Mosul were among thousands of Iraqis who took to the streets across the country Tuesday to demand the release of al-Zeid.
"He is not a criminal. He is a hero," said a demonstrator in Mosul, who gave only his first name, Ali. "The government should release him immediately."
Al-Baghdadiya, a satellite channel based in the Iraqi capital, said in a statement that it was "proud" of Al-Zeidi's "courageous" act.
"The channel is proud of its journalist, Muntader al-Zaydi, who threw his shoe at the head of the American president," the statement said. "This act is a symbol of the Iraqi people's hatred of the American occupation and the Iranian influence in Iraq."
The statement said the channel was "surprised" by the Iraqi government's reaction to the incident.
"We are surprised by the reaction of the Iraqi government to this incident," the statement read. "Why is the Iraqi government trying to silence the voice of the people? Why is it trying to suppress the voice of freedom and democracy?"
The Iraqi government has said it is investigating the incident and will take legal action against the journalist.
Iraqi government spokesman Ali al-Dabbagh told CNN on Tuesday that the government was "investigating" the incident and would take "legal action" against al-Zeide.
"This is a criminal act," al-Dabbah told CNN. "It's not a political act. It's a criminal act, and we will take the necessary legal action against him."
Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki said Monday that the journalist would be "dealt with according to the law."
"He will be dealt with in accordance with the law," Maliki said, according to the state-run Al-Iraqiyah TV. "There is no place for this kind of behavior in our country."
Maliki said the journalist's actions "do not represent the Iraqi people or the Iraqi government."
The Iraqi Journalists' Syndicate has called for the journalist to be released.
The syndicate's president, Mahmoud Othman, told CNN that the syndicate "condemns the attack on the president of the United States."
"The syndicate calls for the immediate release of the journalist," Othman said.
Othman said the syndicate was "shocked" by the government's response to the incident, which he said was "unprecedented in the history of journalism."
"It is the first time that a journalist has thrown a shoe at the president of a country," he said.

New Delhi, India (CNN) -- Dozens of police officers were involved in a gunbattle with
human_text: New Delhi, India (CNN) -- Dozens of police officers were involved in a gunbattle with rebel Maoists in the rain-drenched forests of eastern India Wednesday, police reported. Security forces had been tracking the insurgents when a shootout erupted in Chhattisgarh state's Dantewada region, police spokesman Rajesh Mishra told CNN. There were no immediate reports of casualties, but reinforcements were rushed to the scene, Mishra added. India regards Maoist rebels as its gravest internal security threat. Until June this year, authorities blamed 1,103 violent attacks in the country on left-wing extremists. More than 200 officers and 97 rebels were killed during that period, federal home minister P. Chidambaram said last month. Police have also arrested at least 1,341 suspected Maoists. "These figures underscore the gravity of the challenge posed by left-wing extremism," Chidambaram said. In April, more than 70 officers were killed in Dantewada in an ambush -- one of the deadliest attacks on Indian security forces by suspected guerrillas. Officials say Maoists aim to seize political power through what they call a protracted people's war. On their part, the insurgents have claimed since the 1960s to be fighting for the dispossessed. Indian prime minister Manmohan Singh conceded last year that the nation's fight with the rebels had fallen short of objectives. Maoists enjoy support not only in the poorest areas and in tribal communities but also among youth and the intelligentsia, officials suspect. "We have not achieved as much success as we would have liked in containing this menace," Singh said last September. In addition to targeting police, alleged police informers and people they call "class enemies," the rebels are also believed to be attacking infrastructure such as roads, bridges, railways, and power and telecommunication networks. India says it has adopted a two-pronged strategy -- involving development and police action in Maoist strongholds -- to deal with the problem. Yet, Chidambaram in his statement in July this year accepted the planning has delivered mixed results. While forces stopped many attacks and apprehended key Maoist leaders, the guerrillas too have been successful in carrying out serious assaults in several instances, he noted.

human_text: By . Mail On Sunday Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 18:49 EST, 30 November 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 06:25 EST, 1 December 2013 . The band on stage at The Clutha on Friday night carried on playing even after the helicopter crashed – and even joked that their performance was ‘bringing the roof down’. Amazingly, Glasgow ska band Esperanza assumed the collapsing ceiling was a minor problem. Audience member Grace Maclean, 22, said: ‘Above the music, I heard a loud whoosh and a wooden panel fell down near the stage. Survivors: Members of the band Esperanza who were on stage at the back of the pub when the helicopter crashed through the ceiling . ‘No one had a clue about what had happened. One of the musicians joked, “Looks like we’re bringing the roof down.”’ However, the scale of the accident quickly became apparent, she added. ‘There were shouts of alarm and the band stopped. A thick black cloud of dust swept over us. I could barely see a few inches in front of me. 'I could feel hands grabbing me and people shouting, “Get out!” There was no real panic just a feeling of, “What the heck is going on here?” ‘I made it outside – only then was I told a helicopter had crashed.’ Crash: The band were in the middle of their set at the back of pub when the helicopter plummeted from the sky .

Eyewitnesses described the scene as 'absolute chaos' as the audience scrambled to get out of the way of the falling masonry.

Esperanza, the lead singer of the band, was among those injured in the incident, which occurred at around 10pm at the popular music venue in downtown Los Angeles.

According to sources close to the band, Esperanza initially thought the collapsing ceiling was just a minor problem and even joked with her bandmates that their performance was "bringing the roof down".

However, it quickly became apparent that the situation was much more serious, and the musicians were left stunned and confused.

"We had no clue what had happened," one of the band members said in a statement. "It was like something out of a horror movie. We were just playing our music and then suddenly the ceiling came crashing down."

The incident has left the music community in shock, with many taking to social media to express their condolences to the band and their fans.

The venue has been closed pending an investigation into the cause of the collapse, which is believed to have been caused by a combination of factors, including structural damage and poor maintenance.

By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 00:52 EST, 7 September 2013 . |
human_text: By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 00:52 EST, 7 September 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 07:56 EST, 7 September 2013 . Online retail giant Amazon is considering offering its much-anticipated smartphone for free, it has been reported. The retailer is understood to be aiming to 'undercut rivals' and 'grab a meaningful market share' by tempting consumers using iPhones and Galaxy phones - which normally cost about $200 (£127) - to switch to their free version. However, it is thought the company, which is already behind the hugely popular Kindle e-reader, may require its smartphone users to sign up to services such as its loyalty programme, Amazon Prime. 'Apple's nightmare': If Amazon, which is already behind the popular Kindle e-reader (right) can conquer the market with free phones, Apple may be forced to lower the prices on its iPhone (left) Technology blogger Jessica Lessin claims that 'people familiar with Amazon's effort' confirmed the company was considering offering the smartphones for free. But it is expected to come with some strings attached. 'One of them is whether Amazon would require its smartphone owners to . pay for services such as Amazon Prime, the company’s loyalty program,' Lessin writes in her blog. 'But the people familiar with the matter said that Amazon wants the . device to be free whether or not people sign up for a new wireless plan . at the same time. (Wireless carriers typically discount the price of . devices if customers sign up for a one or two-year wireless contract.)' Cost: Smartphones like the Samsung Galaxy typically cost about $200 (£127) One of the sources says Amazon - which is yet to throw its hat into the smartphone game but is rumored to be interested in doing so - has been in communication with wireless service providers about offering the phone on other carriers. The phone, however, would be offered directly to consumers through a website. Lessin said the free strategy 'isn't set in stone - it depends on a few things that Amazon still needs to work out. For example, the company will need to figure out the financial arrangements with hardware suppliers who are actually manufacturing the phones - something one of Lessin's sources isn't entirely sure is feasible. Free? Amazon is rumored to be considering undercutting its competitors when it enters the smartphone market by offering free phones . Lessin claims that regardless of whether Amazon phones end up being free, or cost significantly less than other, similar phones, the mere fact that the company is considering the strategy indicates how it plans to get into the phone business: 'undercut rivals and grab meaningful market share.' If it works, other smartphone companies could potentially be forced to follow suit and offer their products for much lower prices, or even for free. Lessin described the scenario as 'Apple's Nightmare.'

By. Daily Mail Reporter. PUBLISHED:. 00:52 EST, 7 September 2013. | 0 COMMENTS

Amazon is planning to undercut its rivals and grab a meaningful share of the lucrative smartphone market, according to reports.

The e-commerce giant is said to be working on a budget-friendly smartphone that will be priced significantly lower than Apple's iPhone and Samsung's Galaxy range.

If Amazon can successfully lure customers away from these established brands, it could have a major impact on the market, forcing Apple and Samsung to lower their prices in order to compete.

Amazon's move into the smartphone market is seen as a significant challenge to the dominance of Apple and Samsung, which have long been the two biggest players in the industry.

The company is believed to be working with Taiwanese manufacturer Foxconn to produce the new smartphone, which is expected to be released later this year.

According to reports, the phone will be priced at around $99, making it one of the cheapest smartphones on the market.

This is a bold move by Amazon, which has traditionally focused on selling other people's products rather than manufacturing its own devices.

However, the company has been expanding its product range in recent years, and has already released a number of successful devices, including the Kindle e-reader and the Fire tablet.

Amazon's entry into the smartphone market has been widely anticipated, and many analysts believe that the company has the potential to make a significant impact.

The smartphone market is highly competitive, with a number of established brands vying for customers' attention.

However, Amazon's low prices and wide range of products have made it a major player in the e-commerce market, and many believe that it has the potential to do the same in the smartphone market.

Apple and Samsung have long been the dominant players in the smartphone market, but they have faced increasing competition in recent years from a number of other brands.

Google's Nexus range has been particularly successful, and other brands such as HTC and Sony have also made a significant impact.

However, none of these brands have been able to challenge Apple and Samsung's dominance, and it remains to be seen whether Amazon will be able to do the same.

Amazon's decision to enter the smartphone market is part of a wider strategy to expand its product range and increase its presence in the technology industry.

The company has already made a number of significant investments in the sector, including the acquisition of Twitch, a live streaming platform, and the launch of its Prime Air drone delivery service.

Amazon's CEO, Jeff Bezos, has stated that the company is committed to innovation and is willing to take risks in order to stay ahead of the competition.

The company's entry into the smart home market is also seen as a significant development, with the launch of its Echo device, which allows users to control their homes using voice commands.

Amazon's expansion into the technology sector is seen as a major threat to the dominance of established brands such as Apple and Samsung.

However, many believe that the company's focus on innovation and customer service will ultimately pay off, and that it will be able to establish itself as a leading player in the industry.

In conclusion, Amazon's entry into the Smartphone market is a significant development, and one that could have major implications for the industry as a whole.

If the company is able to successfully undercut its rivals and attract a significant share of the market, it could lead to a major shift in the balance of power in the industry.

Only time will tell if Amazon's strategy will pay off, but one thing is certain - the company is taking a bold step into a highly competitive market, and it will be interesting to see how it fares.

By . Daily Mail Reporter . PUBLISHED: . 00:52 EST, 7 September 2013 . | .
Amazon is planning to 'under-cut rivals and grab a meaningful share of the smartphone market', according to a new report.
The online retail giant is said to be planning to launch its own smartphone in 2014, according to the Wall Street Journal.
If successful, the move could force Apple and Samsung to drop their prices in order to compete.
The report claims that Amazon's smartphone will be based on Google's Android operating system and will be manufactured by Foxconn, the company that makes Apple's iPhone.
It is also said to have a 4.7-inch screen, a 13-megapixel camera and a 2,300mAh battery.
Amazon has not commented on the report.
A spokesman for Foxconn said: 'We don't comment on rumours or speculation.'
Amazon is said to have been working on a smartphone for the past two years.
The company is also reported to be working on a 'smartwatch' and a 'set-top box' to rival Apple's Apple TV and Google's Chromecast.
Amazon launched its first smartphone, the Kindle Fire, in 2011.
However, it has struggled to compete with the likes of Apple and Samsung.
In 2012, the company sold just 3.9 million Kindle Fire tablets, compared to Apple's 37.4 million iPads and Samsung's 10.9 million Galaxy Tabs.
Amazon's shares fell by 1.5 per cent in after-hours trading following the report. | Daily Mail | 2013-09-07 |

By . Tom Worden In Barcelona . PUBLISHED: . 19:28 EST, 16 September 2012 .
human_text: By . Tom Worden In Barcelona . PUBLISHED: . 19:28 EST, 16 September 2012 . | . UPDATED: . 19:28 EST, 16 September 2012 . A British holidaymaker is fighting for her life after a quad bike accident in Spain. Lisa Darlington, 45, is in a critical condition with serious head injuries after falling from the vehicle on the island of Ibiza. Police said she was riding as a passenger on the quad, being driven by her son Danny, 21. Crash: The accident happened on a road near Cala Llonga, a popular beach resort on the island's south east coast, at around 9pm last Thursday . A police source confirmed local reports that he had been arrested for driving the vehicle without a licence. He is thought to have lost control of the vehicle and crashed into a stone wall. The accident happened on a road near Cala Llonga, a popular beach resort on the island’s south east coast, at around 9pm last Thursday. Mrs Darlington was taken by ambulance to hospital where she underwent emergency surgery. It is understood she is being kept in a drug-induced coma in intensive care. Her son was taken to the island’s Can Misses hospital with minor injuries but was released the same day. The accident is being investigated by the Civil Guard’s traffic department. A police source said: 'It appears he lost control and his mother was very seriously injured as she came off the quad bike and banged her head. Quad biking: Lisa Darlington, 45, is in a critical condition with serious head injuries after falling from the vehicle on the island of Ibiza (file picture) 'We’re still investigating what made him lose control.' He is said to have rented the quad bike using a provisional UK driving licence, when a full licence is required to drive the vehicle on a road. Danny appeared before an investigating magistrate and was released on bail. He went straight from the court to be at his mother’s bedside in hospital. 'It appears he lost control and his mother was very seriously injured as she came off the quad bike and banged her head' Police source . He has not been charged with any offence. It is the fourth quad bike accident on the island already this month and the sixth since June. On September 9 a British couple, aged 64 and 52, were run down by a quad bike in the party town of San Antonio. They were struck as they crossed a busy road at a crossing point at 3pm. The 52-year-old woman suffered multiple injuries while both the man’s legs were injured. And in July a French woman was taken to hospital with serious injuries after falling from a quad near Cala Jondal.

(CNN) -- A pregnant bartender says she is fighting to keep her job at a
human_text: (CNN) -- A pregnant bartender says she is fighting to keep her job at a gentlemen's club in New York. Jennifer Paviglianiti, of Centereach, N.Y., claims her employer, Café Royale, discriminated against her because of her pregnancy. She filed a claim with the EEOC earlier this month. Paviglianiti says she feared how her boss would react to her pregnancy and wanted to wait a few months to tell him. However, John Doxey found out before she could tell him, and that's when Paviglianiti claims her job became threatened. Up until she became pregnant, the 29-year-old says she had been one of the club's most popular bartenders. Read the complaint . She says she "bonused 9 times" since August and it was only toward the end of her pregnancy that she asked for different hours. Due to the tough economy, Paviglianiti says she needed this specific bartending job and feared she'd soon be out of work. To protect herself, she decided to secretly record her boss on tape. On those recordings Doxey can be heard saying, "Customers don't wanna come in and see a pregnant woman behind the bar!" These recordings were also submitted in her EEOC discrimination claim. In other recordings, Doxey is heard suggesting that Paviglianiti's appearance is hurting business. "Maybe they don't go there because the bartender is pregnant and doesn't look sexy." Workplace attorney Robin Bond said it's within Doxey's right to do this if employees were informed that they had to maintain a specific "sexy look" to qualify for the job. In this case, that means Paviglianiti would have had to be hired as a "model and a bartender" and get a written agreement to this -- as is done in the casino industry, Bond said on HLN Prime News with Mike Galanos. When asked by Galanos if she signed any paperwork of that sort, Paviglianiti said, "not at all ... nothing." Paviglianiti was taken off the bartending schedule for a few weeks, during which she hired an attorney. She later returned to the club as a cashier but claims she made much less than she did as a bartender. However, Doxey's attorney says this proves she was never fired and her job duties were only adjusted to accommodate her pregnancy. "My client declines to comment on pending legal action except to say it considers that Ms. Paviglianiti allegations are without merit," attorney Robert F. Milman said in a statement. "Ms. Paviglianiti was not terminated from her employment, she presently is on maternity leave and she has the right to return to work upon the conclusion of her leave." Paviglianiti is due to have a baby girl this week.

As a result of this, Paviglianiti claims that she is now earning substantially less than she was prior to her pregnancy. In a recording obtained by local media, Paviglianiti's boss can be heard making disparaging comments about her pregnancy. "Maybe [customers] don't go there because the bartender is pregnant," he said. The recording appears to corroborate Paviglianiti's claims that her pregnancy played a role in her demotion. However, the boss's attorney has defended his client's actions, stating that Paviglianiti's job duties were adjusted to accommodate her pregnancy. The attorney has also denied that her demotion was motivated by discrimination. Pregnancy discrimination is a form of sex discrimination that is prohibited under federal law. The Pregnancy Discrimination Act of 1978 requires employers to treat pregnant employees the same as other employees with similar job duties and qualifications. This includes providing the same level of pay, benefits, and job security. According to the EEOC, pregnancy discrimination complaints have been on the rise in recent years. In 2019, the agency received 2,720 complaints alleging pregnancy discrimination, an increase of 3.5% from the previous year. Pregnant employees who believe they have been subjected to discrimination or retaliation have the right to file a complaint with the EEOC. The agency can investigate the complaint and, if it determines that there has been a violation of federal law, it can take legal action against the employer. In the case of Jennifer Paviglianiti, the outcome of her complaint has yet to be decided. However, her case highlights the ongoing struggle for pregnant employees to receive fair treatment in the workplace.

(CNN) -- A pregnant bartender says she is fighting to keep her job at a 7-Eleven convenience store in New Jersey after her boss allegedly reduced her hours and demoted her to a cashier position due to her pregnancy.

Jennifer Paviglianiti filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) last month, claiming that her employer discriminated against her because of her pregnancy. The 29-year-old bartender says she has been working at the store for over two years and has consistently received positive performance reviews.

However, according to Paviglianiti's complaint, things took a turn for the worse when she became pregnant. Her boss allegedly began to reduce her hours and eventually demoted her from her position as a bartender to a cashier. Paviglianiti claims that this demotion resulted in a significant reduction in her pay.

"I was making around $40,000 a year as a bartender," Paviglianiti said in an interview with CNN. "As a cashier, I'm making around $25,000 a year. It's a huge difference."

Paviglianiti's EEOC complaint includes a recording of a conversation between her and her boss, in which the boss makes a comment that Paviglianiti believes is discriminatory. In the recording, the boss can be heard saying, "Maybe the customers don't want to come in here if the bartender is pregnant."

The comment has sparked outrage among women's rights advocates, who say it highlights the pervasive problem of pregnancy discrimination in the workplace.

"This is a classic example of pregnancy bias," said Emily Martin, vice president for education and workplace fairness at the National Women's Law Center. "Employers often assume that pregnant women are less capable or less desirable employees, and this can lead to discriminatory treatment, including demotions, reduced hours, and lower pay."

According to the EEOC, pregnancy discrimination is a significant problem in the United States. In 2020, the agency received over 6,000 complaints of pregnancy discrimination, with many more cases going unreported.

Paviglianiti hopes that her case will bring attention to the issue of pregnancy discrimination and help to create a more supportive work environment for pregnant women.

"I just want to be able to do my job and take care of myself and my baby," she said. "I don't want to have to choose between my career and my health."

The 7-11 store where Paviglianiti works is owned by an independent franchisee, and the company has not commented on the allegations. However, the store's attorney has released a statement denying any wrongdoing.

"The employee's job duties were adjusted during her pregnancy to accommodate her needs," the attorney said. "This was done to ensure her safety and well-being, as well as the safety and well-being of our customers and employees."

But Paviglianiti disputes this claim, saying that her job duties were not adjusted to accommodate her needs, but rather were reduced as a result of her pregnancy.

"I was still able to perform all of my job duties as a bartender, even while I was pregnant," she said.

The case is ongoing, and Paviglianiti is waiting to hear back from the EEOC about the status of her complaint. In the meantime, she is speaking out about her experience in the hopes of raising awareness about pregnancy discrimination.

"I hope that my story can help to create change and make workplaces more supportive of pregnant women," she said. ### | End of Response | ###

(CNN) -- A pregnant bartender says she is fighting to keep her job at a 7-Eleven store in Florida after her boss allegedly reduced her hours and put her on the cash register because of her pregnancy, according to a complaint filed with the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
The 29-year-old woman, who is not named in the complaint, says she has worked at the store for more than a year and a half and was promoted to a shift supervisor before she became pregnant, according to the EEOC filing.
The complaint says the woman's hours were reduced from 40 hours a week to 30 hours a week, and she was put on the register instead of behind the bar, where she had been working.
The woman's attorney, Jennifer Paviglianti, said her client's job duties were "adjusted to accommodate" her pregnancy, but she was not allowed to work behind the bar.
Paviglianti said in a statement that her client is a "hard-working, dedicated employee" who is "devastated" by the situation.
"This is not the first time this has happened to her, and it will not be the last," the statement said. "This is a blatant violation of federal law."
The EEOC filed the complaint on behalf of the woman, saying she was discriminated against based on her pregnancy. The agency is seeking back pay, reinstatement and compensatory and punitive damages for the woman.
The store's owner and manager did not immediately respond to CNN's request for comment.

True or false? Andrea Rossi, pictured, says he has built a machine achieving 'cold fusion'
human_text: True or false? Andrea Rossi, pictured, says he has built a machine achieving 'cold fusion'  but scientists question if it is possible . An Italian physicist claims he has managed to achieve 'cold fusion' - a procedure that could solve the world's energy crisis by creating huge amounts of safe nuclear energy without dangerous radiation. Andrea Rossi says his new machine fuses nickel and hydrogen at room temperature creating almost unlimited energy. But there is one problem - many scientists claim it defies the very laws of physics. Several high-profile demonstrations of 'cold fusion' have been proven to be hoaxes in the past - and no one can adequately explain how or why it might work. The United States Department of Energy the U.S. Patent Office say the process is impossible because physics rules out the possibility of room-temperature nuclear fusion. But Rossi's E-Cat machine can allegedly do it, and he says he proved it worked during tests at the University of Bologna last month. 'With low energy, it's possible to give a heater a certain amount of energy and to get from the same heater a superior amount of energy,' he said. 'The heat is initiated by electrical resistance. The reactors then produce another 479kWh of energy for another three to four hours without needing that initial electrical input -- the low-level nuclear reaction continues on its own. Machine: Professor Rossi's E-Cat was tested last month and produced huge amounts of non-radioactive energy, he says . Key: Rossi says he has produced a pattern of triple track atoms, pictured, which is at the heart of the cold fusion theory . 'The test we made by the customer was to see if the process was working properly, and to control whether the energy was in an amount superior to the amount supplied to the system. 'We have nothing to say, just to make plans that work properly and let those facts win against the scepticism.' The idea of cold fusion was put forward by in the 1920s by Austrian scientists Friedrich Paneth and Kurt Peters. But despite several people saying they have done it, it has been dismissed by most physicists. An atom is a nucleus of protons and neutrons, with electrons orbiting around . Scientists say that Rossi's claims must be taken from his lab and analysed before he can claim he has done it. Energy consultant Jonathan Koomey said '[The E-Cat experiment] should be treated as a hoax until independent scientists are able to replicate these results,' But Sterling Allan, CEO of the alternative energy news agency Pure Energy Systems, told FoxNews.com he attended Rossi’s demonstration and the E-Cat is self sustaining. 'What Rossi demonstrated was 470 kilowatts of continuous output in self-sustain mode -- meaning the output was enough to keep the thing running on its own,' he said.
gpt: Controversy has arisen in the scientific community after Andrea Rossi, an Italian physicist, claimed that he has found a way to fuse nickel and hydrogen at room temperature, potentially creating an unlimited source of energy. Rossi, who has been working on this technology for the past decade, asserts that his invention could provide a feasible solution to the world’s increasing energy demands. The concept of fusion energy is not new, and scientists have long been exploring the potential of fusion as a source of renewable energy. In traditional nuclear fusion, atoms are fused at very high temperatures and pressures, typically above 100 million degrees Celsius. However, Rossi's method is radically different, claiming to achieve fusion at a much lower temperature, purportedly at or near room temperature. The implications of Rossi’s claims are significant, as they would provide an alternative to traditional fossil fuels, which have been causing harm to the environment. But the scientific community has been cautious about accepting Rossi's claims. Many scientists reject Rossi's assertions, stating that they defy the very laws of physics and that there is no possible way to achieve nuclear fusion at room temperature. Rossi, on the other hand, has denied these claims and insists that his method, now called the “E-Cat SK,” is not only feasible but also reliable. Rossi’s E-Cat SK device has already been tested by several independent companies, including the national laboratory of the Italian National Agency for New Technologies, Energy and Sustainable Economic Development (ENEA). According to Rossi, these tests have demonstrated the validity and feasibility of his technology. But skepticism persists. Some skeptics claim that Rossi's methodology is based on fraud and that his invention is nothing more than a scam. Others argue that the experiments were not conducted under appropriate settings and lack the necessary scientific rigor. Despite these criticisms, Rossi remains optimistic about the potential of his invention, and he continues to work on refining and improving the technology. Furthermore, Italian entrepreneur and inventor Sergio Della Sala has joined forces with Rossi, bringing his own knowledge and expertise to the project. The potential benefits of Rossi's invention are immense, and if his claims are true, the energy industry, as we know it, could be transformed. highlights: Tuesday's deadly suicide attack didn't fit pattern of what had come before . Mass casualty attacks are rare now: insurgents prefer to hit strategic targets . Interior ministry points its finger at Taliban, despite an effusive denial . Many Afghans place blame at one source: Pakistan .
prompt:

Incorporate the following key highlights: Tuesday's deadly suicide attack didn't fit pattern of what had come before . Mass casualty attacks are rare now: insurgents prefer to hit strategic targets . Interior ministry points its finger at Taliban, despite an effusive denial . Many Afghans place blame at one source: Pakistan .

### | Response | ###
(CNN) -- Tuesday's deadly suicide attack targeting Afghan Shia just didn't fit the pattern of
human_text: (CNN) -- Tuesday's deadly suicide attack targeting Afghan Shia just didn't fit the pattern of what had come before in this troubled country. The police formed the usual cordon at the attack site -- this time a shrine in Kabul. Sirens pierced the odd moment of eerie silence, but the police chief's face was contorted with fury and confusion, like he'd seen something new and troubling -- even after decades of conflict here. Yes, the insurgency has specialized in hitting targets right in the city center, often meters away from key institutions. Yes, they are aimed for effect. But mass casualty attacks like we used to see in 2009 are rare these days. The insurgents prefer to hit strategic targets -- unless their roadside bombs are maiming civilians elsewhere. And no, the Shia simply weren't targets before. Sectarianism was seldom an issue here: Afghanistan has lacked the Sunni-Shia divide in Iraq that helped to keep Saddam in power but made his fall so bloody. It has been spared the brand of Sunni extremism in Pakistan, where ruthless attacks on Shia are a shocking part of the fabric. The question of who did it was quickly answered but unsatisfactorily. The interior ministry here points its finger at the Taliban, despite an effusive denial from spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid. It's arguable that an offshoot of the Lashkar-e-Janghvi movement, which reportedly rang in a claim from Pakistan, is capable of mounting a sophisticated, targeted and vicious attack in the very heart of Kabul without some assistance. If they are responsible, it does require some explanation as to how a small, rogue group of extremists -- which has links to al Qaeda and the Pakistan Taliban -- could suddenly develop the capacity to penetrate the capital of a neighboring state. And are Pakistani extremists really operating freely inside Afghanistan now? Whether the culprits turn out to be the Pakistan-based Haqqani network -- the group blamed for recent high-profile and sophisticated attacks in the capital -- the Lashkar-e-Janghvi al Almi, or another complex part of Afghanistan's insurgency, fractured and complicated after 10 years, many Afghans place the blame at one source: Pakistan. That's the "address" that Kabul thinks the Taliban now resides under. That's who they blame for most of the ills here, despite simultaneously hoping they will come to the negotiating table and help. But we should not rush to attribute blame for one reason: The advent of Pakistani extremists trying to foment sectarian violence in Afghanistan at this late stage in the war is a prospect too terrifying to behold.
gpt: In a country already ravaged by decades of violence and unrest, Afghanistan was once again rocked by a deadly suicide attack on Tuesday. The explosion, which occurred outside a military academy in the capital city of Kabul, left at least six people dead and over a dozen others injured.  What made this attack particularly unusual was that it did not fit the pattern of previous attacks that have plagued the country in recent years. While mass casualty attacks have been a frequent occurrence in Afghanistan, insurgents have largely shifted their tactics to focus on hitting strategic targets such as military convoys and government buildings.  Despite the change in tactics, the Afghan interior ministry has pointed the finger at the usual suspect: the Taliban. The insurgent group, which is currently negotiating with the Afghan government in an effort to end the conflict, has swiftly denied any involvement in the attack.  Many Afghans, however, are placing the blame on a different source entirely: Pakistan. The relationship between Afghanistan and its eastern neighbor has long been fraught, with each accusing the other of harboring militants and supporting cross-border attacks.  Afghanistan has long accused Pakistan of providing safe haven for Taliban fighters, allowing them to regroup and launch attacks across the border. In recent years, the two countries have engaged in a series of peace talks and negotiations, but progress has been slow, and mistrust runs deep on both sides.  The latest attack has only heightened tensions between the two countries, with Afghan officials openly accusing Pakistan of being behind the suicide bombing. Pakistan, for its part, has denied any involvement in the attack and has called for greater cooperation between the two nations in the fight against terrorism.  Despite the finger-pointing and accusations, the reality on the ground in Afghanistan remains grim. The country continues to be plagued by violence and insecurity, with civilians bearing the brunt of the conflict. Many Afghans remain skeptical that the peace talks with the Taliban will lead to any real change, and the latest attack only underscores the challenges that lie ahead.  As the Afghan government and its international partners struggle to find a way forward, the people of Afghanistan continue to suffer the grim toll of a seemingly endless conflict. With no easy solutions in sight, the country remains trapped in a cycle of violence and instability that shows no signs of abating anytime soon.  In the wake of Tuesday's attack, the question on everyone's mind is the same: when will the violence end, and what will it take to finally bring peace to Afghanistan? Only time will tell, but what is clear is that the road ahead will be a long and difficult one, with many challenges and obstacles to overcome.

(CNN) -- Tuesday's deadly suicide attack targeting Afghan Shia just didn't fit the pattern of  what had come before.  In recent years, mass casualty attacks have become increasingly rare in Afghanistan, with insurgents preferring to hit strategic targets such as military bases, government buildings, and high-profile convoys.

The attack, which killed at least 34 people and injured dozens more, was carried out by a lone bomber who detonated his explosives-laden vest in a crowded market in the city of Mazar-i-Sharif. The blast was so powerful that it shattered windows and damaged nearby buildings.

The interior ministry quickly pointed the finger at the Taliban, citing the group's long history of targeting Shia Muslims. However, the Taliban has denied any involvement in the attack, with a spokesperson releasing a statement condemning the bombing and expressing condolences to the victims' families.

Despite the Taliban's denial, many Afghans are placing the blame squarely at the feet of Pakistan. Tensions between Afghanistan and Pakistan have been running high in recent months, with both countries accusing each other of harboring and supporting insurgent groups.

Pakistan has long been accused of providing safe haven to the Taliban and other militant groups, and many Afghans believe that the country's intelligence agency, the Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI), was involved in the planning and execution of the attack.

"The Taliban may have carried out the attack, but they were not the masterminds behind it," said a senior Afghan official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "We know that the ISI has been involved in similar attacks in the past, and we have reason to believe that they were involved in this one as well."

The official's comments were echoed by many ordinary Afghans, who took to social media to express their anger and frustration at Pakistan's alleged role in the attack.

"Pakistan is responsible for the bloodshed in Afghanistan," wrote one user on Twitter. "They have been supporting the Taliban for years, and now they are reaping the consequences."

The attack has sent shockwaves throughout Afghanistan, with many calling for greater action to be taken against Pakistan. The country's president, Ashraf Ghani, has vowed to take "all necessary measures" to protect the country's citizens, but it remains to be seen whether he will follow through on his promises.

In the meantime, the people of Afghanistan are left to pick up the pieces and try to make sense of the senseless violence that has plagued their country for so long. As one Afghan woman, who lost her brother in the attack, put it: "We are tired of living in fear. We want peace, and we want it now."

The international community has condemned the attack, with the United States, the European Union, and the United Nations all releasing statements expressing their condolences to the victims and their families.

As the investigation into the attack continues, one thing is clear: the people of Afghanistan will not be silenced. They will continue to demand justice and accountability, and they will not rest until those responsible for the attack are brought to justice.

In the face of such tragedy, it is more important than ever that the international community stands in solidarity with the people of Afghanistan. It is time for action, not just words. The people of Afghanistan deserve better, and it is up to us to ensure that they get it.

(CNN) -- Tuesday's deadly suicide attack targeting Afghan Shia just didn't fit the pattern of "what had come before," according to the country's interior minister.
Interior Minister Wais Ahmad Barmak told CNN's Christiane Amanpour that the attack, which killed at least 41 people and wounded more than 100, was "not in line with the pattern of attacks that we have seen in the past."
Barmak said the attack was carried out by a suicide bomber who detonated his explosives at the entrance of a Shia mosque in the capital, Kabul.
"This is not in line with what we have seen before," Barmak said. "This is the first time we have seen this type of attack."
The attack was the deadliest in the Afghan capital since 2015, when a truck bomb killed more than 80 people and wounded hundreds of others.
The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for Tuesday's attack, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, a US-based organization that monitors extremist groups.
The group's Amaq news agency said the attacker was a "soldier of the caliphate" who carried out the attack "in response to calls to target the Shia."
The Taliban, which has been fighting the US-backed Afghan government for more than 17 years, denied any involvement in the attack.
"The Islamic Emirate categorically condemns the terrorist attack in Kabul," the group said in a statement. "We have nothing to do with this attack."
Afghan President Ashraf Ghani condemned the attack, calling it a "cowardly act of terrorism."
"We will not be deterred in our resolve to defeat terrorism," Ghani said in a tweet.
The attack comes as the Afghan government and the Taliban are engaged in peace talks in Qatar.
The talks, which began in September, are aimed at ending the 17-year war in Afghanistan.
Afghan officials have said the talks are making progress, but the two sides remain far apart on key issues, including the future role of the Taliban in the Afghan government.
Tuesday's attack is the latest in a string of deadly attacks targeting Shia Muslims in Afghanistan, many of which have been claimed by the Islamic State group.
In 2017, a suicide bomber targeted a mosque in Kabul during Friday prayers, killing at least 40 people and wounding dozens more.
That attack was claimed by the IS group, which said it was in retaliation for the killing of its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, in a US-led raid in Syria in October 2019.
In October 2018, a suicide bombing at a mosque in the Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif killed dozens of worshippers.
The Taliban claimed responsibility for that attack, saying it was in response to the killing of Mullah Akhtar Mansour, the group's leader, by a US drone strike in 2016.

There is always a group of children waiting to hand the Queen the customary posy
human_text: There is always a group of children waiting to hand the Queen the customary posy of flowers when she walks out of morning service. But yesterday Prince Philip was also given his own treat when the couple emerged from a church in West Newton, Norfolk. As Her Majesty smiled as she looked on, the Duke of Edinburgh appeared equally delighted to receive a bag of sweets from a young well-wisher outside the church in the heart of the Sandringham Estate. Sweet treat: Prince Philip was given a bag of Morrisons chocolate éclairs by a young girl, left, after attending a church service in West Newton, Norfolk . Inedible gifts: As has become tradition, the Queen accepted bouquets of flowers from waiting children . The sweets - an 89p bag of own-brand chocolate éclairs from Morrisons - were later spotted on the Prince's lap as he was driven away. Parents crowded round with camera phones to capture the moment as their sons and daughters bravely stepped forward to meet the monarch - while some hung shyly back. The bouquets are often tactfully placed in a separate car by one of the Queen's security team. But the éclairs seemed to find a special place in the Prince's heart, and was spotted still on his lap as the Royal car pulled away. The Royal pair had attended a service at the Church of St Peter and Paul, which is on the Sandringham estate. Happy and glorious: The Queen beamed as excited parents and children crowded round in the sunshine . Spectators: During the service, the Queen and Prince saw a Biblical play performed by Sunday school children . According to local media, the Queen and Philip had just enjoyed a performance of a Biblical play - Whither Thou Go'est - performed by children at the church's Sunday School. The monarch often accepts flowers after morning service when she is staying at Sandringham, although in recent weeks the practice has become a little haphazard. Last week the Queen dashed straight to her waiting car because of heavy rain, following successive Sundays in which she has accepted bouquets of flowers. She had refused to accept flowers from children for two Sundays over Christmas and New Year, reportedly because she had to collect so many on Christmas Day she was late for lunch.

human_text: (CNN)Protesters gathered at Kiev's Independence Square Sunday to march for peace, while fighting in Ukraine's east claimed more victims. Ukraine's President and prime minister were among those who attended the rally that had as its slogan "I am Volnovakha," in memory of the 13 passengers who died near the city of Volnovakha after their bus was hit by artillery shelling on January 13. "We will remember every Ukrainian hero who gave (life) for the sake of independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine," said Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko. "We will not give up a single meter of our land." Meanwhile, fighting in the east continued. Government forces and pro-Russia rebels have been battling for control of eastern Donetsk and Luhansk regions since April, after Russia annexed Ukraine's southeastern Crimea region the previous month. The Ukrainian army was able to regain full control of the Donetsk airport, military spokesman Col. Andriy Lysenko said Sunday. Over the last 24 hours, four Ukrainian soldiers were killed and 32 were wounded, the spokesman said. A 7-year-old boy and a 16-year-old were killed when a missile struck a house in the town of Vuhlehirsk, in Donetsk, said Donetsk's regional police chief Vyacheslav Abroskin on his Facebook page. A young girl was seriously injured. A ceasefire deal was reached on September 5 in Minsk, Belarus, following talks between representatives of Ukraine, Russia and rebel leaders. A subsequent agreement on September 19 set out more measures, but there has been little sign of progress as all sides blame each other for the bloodshed. The United Nations issued a statement Sunday, calling on all parties to exercise restraint. "The Secretary-General is alarmed by the severe escalation of fighting for control of Donetsk airport in eastern Ukraine, which has already caused numerous casualties and threatened to completely unravel a hard-won September 2014 cease-fire," it read. The statement continued: The Secretary-General stresses that further deterioration of a situation that has led to heavy loss of life and civilian suffering must be avoided at all costs. The United Nations stands ready to support all efforts toward de-escalation and the resumption of a genuine peace process to restore Ukraine's stability and territorial integrity." CNN's Laura Smith-Spark and Dana Ford contributed to this report.
