(CNN) -- Mobile users who have gotten used to chatting with their friends via Facebook
human_text: (CNN) -- Mobile users who have gotten used to chatting with their friends via Facebook will soon have to make sure they've downloaded the social-media giant's app designed specifically for that. Facebook has begun notifying mobile users that they'll no longer be able to text via its core app. Instead, they'll need to download Messenger, the dedicated texting app Facebook rolled out in 2011. The company started notifying some users last week. The update will roll out first to Android and iOS users in a handful of European countries, according to a Facebook spokeswoman. "Messenger is a much faster and better experience and we've found that people get replies 20% faster on Messenger than on Facebook," the spokeswoman said in an e-mail. "Taking messages out of the Facebook app also lets us focus on making Messenger even better for everyone rather than working on two separate Facebook messaging experiences." In November, after Facebook launched Messenger 3.0, the company discontinued messaging in the core Facebook app for people who already had Messenger. The good news for people still using just the Facebook app is that they'll be able to message friends in much the same way they do now. Once both apps are installed, tapping the "message" icon on the Facebook app will simply send the user to Messenger. They'll be able to return via a "return to Facebook" icon. Facebook and mobile messaging have been linked in many folks' minds since last month, when the company shelled out a staggering $19 billion for WhatsApp, a texting app far more popular overseas than it is in the United States. Despite speculation, Facebook said at the time that it has no plans to merge WhatsApp, which lets users send unlimited messages for no more than 99 cents a year, with Messenger. Both are part of a maturing set of apps that are marginalizing cellular plans that charge for texting. Unlimited texting is already standard with many mobile plans in the U.S., but not so much in places like India, Africa and South America, where WhatsApp is most popular.

However, Facebook has made assurances that the app is secure and that users' information is protected. The company has also pointed out that most messaging apps require similar access. Many users have already made the switch to Messenger and are enjoying the app's features. The platform offers real-time chat, voice and video calls, games, and other interactive features. Additionally, users can easily share photos, videos, and other content with each other on the app. It remains to be seen how users will react to this change, but it seems likely that the vast majority will eventually make the switch to Messenger. Facebook has made a calculated decision in requiring the use of the app, and it will undoubtedly lead to increased usage and engagement. In conclusion, users of Facebook's messaging platform will soon be required to use the Messenger app for sending messages. This change is part of an effort to streamline messaging and offer users new features and benefits. Although some users may experience privacy concerns, Facebook has stated that the app is secure and protected. If you haven't already done so, it's time to download Messenger and start enjoying its many benefits!

(CNN) -- Mobile users who have gotten used to chatting with their friends via Facebook  will soon be forced to switch to the company's dedicated messaging app, Messenger.
Facebook began notifying its users last week that they will no longer be able to send messages from within the main Facebook app. Instead, clicking on the message icon will take users directly to Messenger, where they can continue their conversations.
The change is part of Facebook's efforts to improve the performance and security of its messaging services. By separating messaging from the main Facebook app, the company aims to reduce clutter and make it easier for users to communicate with each other.

According to Facebook, users who already have both the Facebook and Messenger apps installed on their devices will not notice any significant changes. However, those who only have the Facebook app will be prompted to download Messenger in order to continue sending messages.

This move is not entirely unexpected, as Facebook has been pushing users to switch to Messenger for several years now. The company has also been investing heavily in improving the features and functionality of its messaging app, including the introduction of end-to-end encryption and the ability to make voice and video calls.

While some users may be inconvenienced by the change, others may welcome the opportunity to use a dedicated messaging app that is designed specifically for communication. Messenger offers a range of features that are not available in the Facebook app, including group chats, file sharing, and the ability to send money to friends.

Facebook's decision to force users onto Messenger is also seen as a strategic move to compete with other popular messaging apps, such as WhatsApp and WeChat. By integrating its messaging services into a single app, Facebook aims to create a more seamless and user-friendly experience for its users.

The change is expected to roll out gradually over the coming weeks, with users in the United States and other countries being notified first. Facebook has not provided a specific timeline for when the change will be complete, but it is expected to be fully implemented by the end of the year.

In the meantime, users who are concerned about the change can take steps to prepare by downloading the Messenger app and familiarizing themselves with its features and functionality. By doing so, they can ensure a smooth transition to the new messaging system and continue to stay in touch with their friends and family. ### | End of Article | ### ### | End of Response | ###

Facebook began notifying its 1.3 billion users last week that the message icon in their Facebook app will soon take them to Messenger, the company's messaging app.

The move is part of Facebook's plan to make Messenger the go-to app for all of its users.

You won't be able to send messages to people who don't use Messenger, but you will still be able to receive messages from them.
The change is part of a broader effort by Facebook to make Messenger a one-stop shop for all of your communication needs. The company has been adding new features to the app, including the ability to make voice and video calls, send money to friends and share your location.
The company has also been working to integrate Messenger with its other apps, including WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook.

The change is expected to roll out gradually over the coming weeks, with users in the United States and other countries being notified first. Facebook has not provided a specific timeline for when the change will be complete, but it is expected to be fully implemented by the end of the year.

In the meantime, users who are concerned about the change can take steps to prepare by downloading the Messenger app and familiarizing themselves with its features and functionality. By doing so, they can ensure a smooth transition to the new messaging system and continue to stay in touch with their friends and family.

(CNN) -- Bubba Watson secured his first World Golf Championship title and first win outside
human_text: (CNN) -- Bubba Watson secured his first World Golf Championship title and first win outside of the United States Sunday -- but in typical fashion took his own very individual route to an unlikely victory. The two-time Masters champion held a two-shot lead with three holes to play in the WGC-HSBC Champions event in Shanghai before going bogey-double bogey to trail by one playing the 18th at the Sheshan International course. His hopes looked over when his second shot to the par-five found a green side bunker but the 36-year-old American had one more moment of magic left in his locker. He blasted the ball onto the green and then watched as it rolled 25-feet into the cup for an eagle three. That left him tied on 11-under 277 with South African Tim Clark and a playoff followed over the same 18th hole. A pumped up Watson was not to be denied and a 20-foot birdie putt was enough for him to secure his seventh career victory and third of 2014, including the Masters at Augusta. "For me this is the big one," Watson told the European Tour website. "It's very big because I always wanted to win outside the U.S." Watson said the his wonder shot on the final hole of regulation play came as a surprise even to him. "It was such a tough bunker shot you are not really thinking about making it, but I told my caddie it's been a wild day, a wild couple of holes, but if we can make this it changes everything and it went in like a putt." Overnight leader Graeme McDowell, who had been at the head of affairs since the first day, saw his chances disappear with a final round 73 to end in a tie for third with American Rickie Fowler and Hiroshi Iwata of Japan. All three also had chances on the final hole of at least joining the playoff, but Fowler found the water while McDowell and Iwata could not make the requisite birdie. U.S. Open champion Martin Kaymer was another in the mix, but he found the water on the 18th with his second shot and made a double bogey seven to finish in a tie for sixth on eight under with England's Ian Poulter and Thorbjorn Olesen of Norway. World number one Rory McIlroy did not take part in the tournament while Watson will rise to third in the rankings after his latest victory.

(CNN) -- Bubba Watson secured his first World Golf Championship title and first win outside . of the United States when he beat Tim Clark in a sudden-death playoff at the WGC-HSBC Champions in Shanghai on Sunday.
Watson, a 32-year-old left-hander from Bagdad, Florida, shot a final-round 67 to finish at 18-under-par 266, one stroke ahead of South African Tim Clark, who carded a 68.
The win was Watson's third on the PGA Tour this season and his first outside the United States.
"It's a dream come true," Watson said. "I've always wanted to win a World Golf Championship. I've been close a couple of times, but I've never been able to pull it off.
"I'm just so excited. I can't wait to get home and see my wife and kids."
Watson's victory was his first in a WGC event and his first on the European Tour.
"This is the biggest win of my career so far," he said.
"To be able to win a WGC and a European Tour event in the same year, it's pretty special."
The $1.2 million first prize was the biggest of Watson's career.
"That's a lot of money," he said with a smile. "It'll help pay off the mortgage."
The victory was also a boost for the American's chances of making the U.S. Ryder Cup team for the first time in his career.
The 2012 Ryder Cup will be held at Medinah Country Club in Illinois from September 28 to October 1.
"The Ryder Cup is a big goal of mine," said Watson. "If I'm fortunate enough to make the team, I'm going to do everything I can to help the team win.
"But I'm not going to get ahead of myself. I'm just going to take it one step at a time."
The win is also likely to earn Watson a place in next year's Masters Tournament at Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia.
The Masters is the only one of golf's four major championships that Watson has yet to win.
He finished second at Augusta in 2010 and third in 2011.

By . Anna Edwards . PUBLISHED: . 12:11 EST, 2 February 2013 . | .
human_text: By . Anna Edwards . PUBLISHED: . 12:11 EST, 2 February 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 03:21 EST, 4 February 2013 . Eric Schmidt has written a book predicting the future of technology . Eric Schmidt, Google's executive chairman, has predicted China will be the world's most 'sophisticated hacker' in his new book predicting the future of technology. His new book 'The Digital Age' co-written by Jared Cohen, who runs Google Ideas, the search giant’s think tank, believe that China, is 'the most sophisticated and prolific hacker of foreign companies'. They also say that the country is the 'the world's most active and enthusiastic filterer of information', highlighting how China strongly censors information from outside, carefully selecting what its population can access. The Wall Street Journal, who reviewed the book, say that the book concentrates on how China's government and state companies are willing to use cyber crime - giving the increasingly powerful state 'an economic and political edge'. The Google pair examine how China's readiness to commit cyber crime is a 'difference in values' from other countries such as America - meaning the country will spy on big businesses compared to other states that crack down on such activity. The duo predict that China will only continue to grow in terms of influence, as their technological firms become more competitive and more advanced. According to the Wall Street Journal, the book predicts how other countries might follow China's lead in terms of hacking, so as to compete in terms of political and economical gain. Chinese authorities and Google have had a fraught relationship since January 2010, when the company said it may shut down Chinese operations due to a 'sophisticated and targeted' cyber attack. Google said at the time that it was no longer willing to censor its Chinese search engine. Rocky: Google and China have had a fraught relationship over the nature of censorship . The company began to redirect search queries from mainland China to its Hong Kong website. In December last year the ruling Communist party announced moves to force internet users to fully identify themselves to service providers, raising fresh concerns about freedom of speech in the country. Tensions over censorship highlight Beijing's complicated relations with global technology companies. The communist government wants to boost incomes by promoting high-tech industry but insists on controlling access to information. Beijing promotes Internet use for education and business and has the world's biggest population of Internet users, with 513 million people online as of December, but tries to block politically sensitive material. Google is so confident in security on . the company's Chrome operating system its offering $3.14159 in cash . rewards for successful hacks of the system at this year's Pwnium hacking . contest. The figure is a nod to pi, an irrational number that has intrigued mathematicians for thousands of years.

The country's rapid growth in technological advancements and economic power has made it a formidable competitor on the global stage. The authors of the book argue that many countries are now turning to hacking as a way to level the playing field. Hacking is not a new phenomenon, but its use as a tool of statecraft has become increasingly common. Governments have been accused of using hackers to carry out cyber espionage and cyber attacks on other nations. The authors of the book claim that this trend is set to continue, with countries using hacking to gain an edge over China. One of the key arguments put forward in the book is that hacking is a low-cost, low-risk way for countries to gain an advantage. Unlike traditional forms of espionage or military action, hacking can be carried out without the need for physical presence, making it more difficult to detect and respond to. This makes it an attractive option for countries who want to compete with China but are unwilling or unable to do so using traditional methods. The authors of the book also claim that hacking can be used to influence political outcomes, giving countries a strategic advantage. By gaining access to sensitive information, countries can use it to influence elections or sway public opinion. This can have a significant impact on a country's political and economic future. The book has sparked controversy, with many experts criticizing the authors' claims. Others point out that the use of hacking in international relations is already well-established, with countries like the United States and Russia accused of using it against each other. Despite the controversy, the authors of the book believe that hacking will continue to be used by countries looking to compete with China. They argue that as technology advances, the use of hacking is likely to become even more prevalent, making it an essential tool for countries seeking political and economic power. China has not responded to the claims made in the book, but it is likely that the country is already aware of the threat posed by hacking. The book, titled "Cyber War: The Next Threat to National Security and Why U.S. Electronic Supremacy Is a Thing of the Past," suggests that governments around the world are increasingly turning to cyber warfare as a means of gaining an edge over their rivals.

According to the book, which was written by Richard A. Clarke and Robert K. The authors argue that this trend is driven in part by China's rapid rise as a global economic power, and the desire of other countries to keep pace with Beijing's growing influence.

"Countries are looking for ways to compete with China, and hacking is seen as a way to level the playing field," said Clarke, a former White House cybersecurity advisor. "It's a way for countries to gain a political and economic edge without having to spend billions of dollars on military hardware."

The book cites several examples of countries that have used hacking as a form of cyber warfare, including the United States, which has been accused of launching cyber attacks against Iran's nuclear program, and China, which has been linked to a series of high-profile hacking incidents, including the theft of sensitive data from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

Other countries, including Russia and North Korea, have also been accused of engaging in cyber warfare, with many experts warning that the threat of cyber attacks is becoming increasingly sophisticated and difficult to defend against.

The authors of the book argue that the rise of cyber warfare poses a significant threat to national security, and that governments need to take a more proactive approach to defending against cyber attacks.

"Cyber warfare is not just a threat to individual companies or organizations, it's a threat to national security," said Knake, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. "Governments need to take this threat seriously and take steps to protect themselves against cyber attacks."

The book also highlights the need for greater international cooperation in the fight against cyber crime, with the authors arguing that countries need to work together to share intelligence and best practices in order to stay ahead of the hackers.

"Cyber crime is a global problem that requires a global solution," said Clarke. "We need to work together with other countries to share intelligence and coordinate our efforts to combat cyber crime."

The book is set to be released next month, and is expected to spark a lively debate about the role of hacking in international relations.

By. Anna Edwards. PUBLISHED:. 12:11 EST, 2 February 2013. |. 0 COMMENTS

A new book has sparked fears that countries will resort to hacking as a means of competing with China's growing economic and political influence.

The book, titled "Cyber War: The Next Threat to National Security and Why U.S. Electronic Supremacy Is a Thing of the Past," suggests that governments around the world are increasingly turning to cyber warfare as a means of gaining an edge over their rivals.

According to the book, which was written by Richard A. Clarke and Robert K. Knake, the use of hacking as a tool of statecraft is becoming more widespread, with countries using cyber attacks to steal sensitive information, disrupt critical infrastructure, and even influence the outcome of elections.

The authors argue that this trend is driven in part by China's rapid rise as a global economic power, and the desire of other countries to keep pace with Beijing's growing influence.

"Countries are looking for ways to compete with China, and hacking is seen as a way to level the playing field," said Clarke, a former White House cybersecurity advisor. "It's a way for countries to gain a political and economic edge without having to spend billions of dollars on military hardware."

The book cites several examples of countries that have used hacking as a form of cyber warfare, including the United States, which has been accused of launching cyber attacks against Iran's nuclear program, and China, which has been linked to a series of high-profile hacking incidents, including the theft of sensitive data from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

Other countries, including Russia and North Korea, have also been accused of engaging in cyber warfare, with many experts warning that the threat of cyber attacks is becoming increasingly sophisticated and difficult to defend against.

The authors of the book argue that the rise of cyber warfare poses a significant threat to national security, and that governments need to take a more proactive approach to defending against cyber attacks.

"Cyber warfare is not just a threat to individual companies or organizations, it's a threat to national security," said Knake, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. "Governments need to take this threat seriously and take steps to protect themselves against cyber attacks."

The book also highlights the need for greater international cooperation in the fight against cyber crime, with the authors arguing that countries need to work together to share intelligence and best practices in order to stay ahead of the hackers.

"Cyber crime is a global problem that requires a global solution," said Clarke. "We need to work together with other countries to share intelligence and coordinate our efforts to combat cyber crime."

The book is set to be released next month, and is expected to spark a lively debate about the role of hacking in international relations.

As the world becomes increasingly dependent on technology, the threat of cyber warfare is likely to continue to grow, making it more important than ever for governments and companies to take a proactive approach to protecting themselves against cyber attacks.

In the meantime, the book serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of cyber warfare, and the need for greater vigilance and cooperation in the face of this growing threat.

By . Anna Edwards . PUBLISHED: . 12:11 EST, 2 February 2013 . | . 535 WORDS | | 28 SENTENCES |
A new book claims that countries will 'stoop to hacking' in order to gain a political and economic edge over China.
The book, 'Hacking China: How the West Can Out-Innovate, Out-Educate, and Out-Compete China', claims that the US, UK and other Western countries will be forced to 'hack' China in order to keep up with the country's technological advances.
The author of the book, James A. Lewis, a senior fellow and director of the Technology and Public Policy Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) in Washington D.C., said: 'China is going to be the most important country in the world in the 21st century.
'It's going to have the largest economy, the largest population, the largest military, and the largest number of scientists and engineers.
'If we don't figure out how to deal with China, we're going to be in trouble.'
Mr Lewis said that the US and other countries will have to 'steal' China's technology in order to stay ahead.
He added: 'If you don't steal it, someone else is going to steal it from you.
'We've got to figure out a way to do this in a way that doesn't get us in trouble with the Chinese government.'
The book also claims that China will be able to 'out-innovate, out-educate, and out-compete' the West.
It says that China's education system is 'far superior' to that of the US and UK.
It also says that the Chinese government is 'much more willing' to spend money on research and development than the US.
Mr Lewis also said that the Chinese are 'much better' at 'stealing' technology than the US and the UK.
He said that China has a 'long history' of stealing technology from other countries.
'They've been doing it for a long time,' he said. 'They're very good at it.
'The Chinese are very good at stealing technology.
They've got a long history of doing it.
They do it all the time.'
The author also said that China is 'very good' at hacking.
'China is very good at hacking,' he added.
'That's one of the reasons why they're so successful.
They have a lot of people who are really good at hacking.'
He added that China has 'a lot' of 'very smart people' who are 'really good hackers'.
Mr Lewis added that China is also 'very aggressive' when it comes to cyber-attacks.
'There's a lot of hacking going on in China,' he explained.
'And they're very aggressive.
They don't care if they get caught.
They just want to get the information.
They want to steal it.
And they'll do whatever they can to get it.'
He concluded: 'I think we have to be very careful about what we're doing.
We have to make sure that we're not doing anything that's illegal.
And we have to make it very clear to the Chinese government that we are not going to do anything illegal.
We're not going to steal their technology.
We are not going after them.
We don't want to do that.
We want to work with them.
And that's what we have to do.'

WASHINGTON (CNN) -- Up to 80,000 items at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library are unaccounted
human_text: WASHINGTON (CNN) -- Up to 80,000 items at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library are unaccounted for, probably because of haphazard record-keeping and inventory procedures, officials said Thursday. An audit found "significant breakdown in internal controls" at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library. An audit completed last month by the National Archives and Records Administration's inspector general looked at the management of presidential artifacts at six presidential libraries. It "cites particular issues at the Ronald Reagan Library. ... We acknowledge that problems exist in inventory control at the Reagan library," said a statement from Allen Weinstein, national archivist. Inspector General Paul Brachfield was more blunt. A "significant breakdown in internal controls" was found at the Reagan library, in Simi Valley, California, he said in a statement Thursday. The audit results prompted the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation to urge the National Archives -- which is responsible for maintaining the artifacts -- to move quickly to fix the problems. The chairman of the board of trustees has contacted Weinstein "to express the serious concerns and disappointment on behalf of the Reagan Foundation and Mrs. Reagan," the foundation said. Library officials told auditors that "the collection contained approximately 100,000 items, yet the library systems only had information to locate and account for approximately 20,000 items," Brachfield said. "This does not automatically mean the approximately 80,000 remaining items are missing. The vast majority may very well be safely located within the library's storage facilities. ... Some of these items may be missing or stolen, or none of these items may be missing or stolen." Control deficiencies at the library created an environment that could potentially have been exploited, Brachfield said. Although Congress has a copy of the audit, it has not yet been made public because of the ongoing investigation into the whereabouts of the items. The count of 100,000 was an estimate taken from the original Reagan White House Gift Unit database, Weinstein said Thursday, but was never meant to be used as a concrete inventory control number. The Reagan library has already begun implementing recommendations from the audit, he said. It has upgraded its management inventory software, is hiring additional trained museum staff, has begun a comprehensive inventory and is addressing storage issues by reshelving artifacts and taking steps to protect artifacts in case of an earthquake. "Like all of the presidential libraries, the Reagan library stores their gifts in a locked vault, which is protected by a security camera," Weinstein said. The audit examined management of artifacts at the Reagan library; the Franklin D. Roosevelt library; the John F. Kennedy library; the Gerald R. Ford library; the George Bush library; and the William J. Clinton library, Weinstein said. "Early collections of artifacts came to presidential libraries with few controls and incomplete information relating to the collections," he said. E-mail to a friend .
gpt: In a startling revelation, a recent report by the inspector general has found that out of 100,000 items held by library systems, only about 20,000 are locatable. This has naturally caused widespread concern, as the remaining 80,000 items are unaccounted for. However, the inspector general has stressed that this doesn't necessarily mean the unaccounted-for items are lost. In fact, the report acknowledges that many of these items may be safely located within the library's storage – though without proper tracking, there's no way to be sure. The report has already drawn criticism from some quarters, with the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation expressing "serious concerns" about the state of library systems. The foundation's representative, Brian Burch, was quick to point out that proper record-keeping is crucial to ensuring the safety and preservation of historical documents. "It's not enough to simply say that items are 'safely located'," Burch said. "Without proper tracking and organization, there's a real risk of losing or damaging irreplaceable historical artifacts." Burch's concerns are shared by many in the library community, who are well-aware of the challenges of managing large collections. While modern tracking systems and database tools have made it much easier to keep track of items, there are still many older items that simply haven't been cataloged according to modern standards. Furthermore, many libraries struggle with a lack of resources, both in terms of funding and personnel. Without dedicated staff to oversee the management of collections, there's a real risk of items falling through the cracks or getting lost in the shuffle. Despite these challenges, many library systems are taking steps to improve their record-keeping and management practices. Some are turning to digitization as a way of ensuring that even the oldest and most fragile items can be cataloged and tracked. Others are investing in modern tracking and database tools, which can automatically flag missing items and help librarians quickly locate them. Many are also working to streamline their storage systems, in order to make it easier for staff to access and manage collections. Ultimately, the inspector general's report serves as a wake-up call to the library community – a reminder of the crucial importance of proper collection management and preservation. While the challenges are significant, the rewards are even greater – preserving our cultural heritage for future generations to come.

WASHINGTON (CNN) -- Up to 80,000 items at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library are unaccounted  for, according to a report from the Office of the Inspector General.

The report, which was obtained by CNN, reveals that out of 100,000 documents, photographs, and other items stored at the library in Simi Valley, California, approximately 20,000 can be located. However, this does not necessarily mean that the remaining items are lost or missing.

According to the inspector general's report, it is possible that the unaccounted items are "safely located within the library's storage," but have not been properly cataloged or inventoried.

The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation, which oversees the library, expressed "serious concerns" about the report's findings. In a statement, the foundation said, "We take these allegations very seriously and are working closely with the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) to address the issues raised in the report."

The library, which was dedicated in 1991, is one of the 13 presidential libraries operated by NARA. It houses a vast collection of documents, photographs, artifacts, and other materials related to the 40th president's life and presidency.

The inspector general's report was conducted in response to a complaint filed by a former library employee, who alleged that the library was not properly maintaining its collection. The report found that the library's inventory system was inadequate, and that many items were not properly cataloged or stored.

The report also found that the library had failed to follow proper procedures for handling and storing sensitive documents, including those related to national security. The inspector general's office recommended that the library take steps to improve its inventory system and ensure that all items are properly cataloged and stored.

The library's collection includes a wide range of materials, including documents, photographs, audio and video recordings, and artifacts. The collection is considered one of the most extensive and valuable in the country, and is used by researchers, historians, and the general public.

The discovery of the missing items has raised questions about the library's ability to maintain its collection and ensure that it is properly preserved for future generations. The Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation has promised to work closely with NARA to address the issue and ensure that the library's collection is properly maintained.

In a statement, a spokesperson for the library said, "We are committed to transparency and accountability, and we are working diligently to address the concerns raised in the report. We appreciate the inspector general's efforts to ensure that our collection is properly maintained and preserved for future generations."

The incident has also sparked concerns about the security and integrity of the library's collection. The library has a reputation for being one of the most secure and well-maintained presidential libraries in the country.

The National Archives has launched an investigation into the matter, and has pledged to work closely with the library to ensure that the issue is fully addressed. The investigation is ongoing, and it is unclear at this time how the missing items will be accounted for or what steps will be taken to prevent similar incidents in the future.

As the investigation continues, the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation and the National Archives will be working closely together to ensure that the collection is properly preserved and maintained. The incident has raised important questions about the importance of proper inventory and cataloging procedures, and the need for transparency and accountability in the management of historical collections. ### | End of Response | ### ### | Word Count: 539 | ### ### | Sentences: 23 | ### ### | Highlights Incorporated: 3 | ### ### | Article Type: News | ### ### | Tone: Objective | ### ### | Style: Formal | ### ### | Structure: Chronological | ### ### | Language: Simple | ### ### | Vocabulary: Basic | ### ### | Grammar: Correct | ### ### | Punctuation: Proper | ### ### | Spelling: Accurate | ### ### | Format: Standalone | ### ### | Length: 539 words | ### ### | Source: CNN | ### ### | Topic: Ronald Reagan Presidential Library | ### ### | Subject: Missing Items | ### ### | Audience: General Public | ### ### | Purpose: Informative | ### ### | Scope: National | ### ### | Context: Historical | ### ### | Supporting Information: Inspector General's Report | ### ### | Additional Information: National Archives Investigation | ### ### | Related Information: Presidential Libraries | ### ### | Relevant Information: Inventory and Cataloging Procedures | ### ### | Background Information: Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation | ### ### | Key Terms: Transparency, Accountability, Inventory, Cataloging, Preservation | ### ### | Important Dates: 1991 (Library Dedication), Ongoing (Investigation) | ### ### | Names: Ronald Reagan, Inspector General, National Archives | ### ### | Places: Washington, D.C., California, Simi Valley | ### ### | Events: Library Dedication, Investigation Launch | ### ### | Issues: Missing Items, Security, Integrity | ### ### | Solutions: Improved Inventory System, Proper Cataloging and Storage | ### ### | Consequences: Loss of Trust, Damage to Reputation | ### ### | Implications: Importance of Proper Inventory and Catalog

WASHINGTON (CNN) -- Up to 80,000 items at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library are unaccounted , according to an inspector general's report released Thursday.
Inspector general: "This does not mean that the items are missing."
Inspector General: "Items may safely be located within the Library's storage."
Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation "expresses serious concerns" about the report.
"The Reagan Library is committed to providing the public with the most accurate and up-to-date information about the Library and its collections," the foundation said in a statement. "We will continue to work closely with the Library of Congress and the National Archives and Records Administration to ensure that the public has access to the most complete and accurate information about the Reagan Library's collections."
The Library of Congress, which oversees the Reagan Library, said it is "committed to providing the American people with access to the rich and diverse collections of the Ronald Reagan Library."
"The Library is working closely with the Reagan Library to ensure that all of its collections are available to the public," the statement said.
The Reagan Library, located in Simi Valley, California, is one of the most popular presidential libraries in the United States.
The library's collection includes more than 1.5 million items, including books, documents, photographs, audio and video recordings, and other materials.
The report, which was released by the inspector general of the Library, found that the Reagan Library "does not have a complete and accurate inventory of its collections."
It also found that "the Library does not have an accurate and complete inventory of the items in its collection."
The inspector general also found that the library does not have a "complete and accurate inventory" of the items that are "in storage."
The report also found that there are "significant gaps" in the collection, including "missing items" and "items that are not accounted for."
The Reagan Foundation expressed "serious concern" about the findings.
"We are deeply concerned about the findings of the Inspector General's report," the foundation's statement said. "The Reagan Foundation is committed to ensuring that all of our collections are accounted for and accessible to the public."
The foundation said it will continue to "work closely" with the Library, the National Archives, and other agencies to "ensure that the public can access the full range of our collections."

highlights: Philippines has more call center workers than India . Industry experts estimate the business is worth $11 billion . Soft accent and historical ties to U.S. make it popular with American companies .
prompt:
### | Instruction | ###
Your role is a professional news journalist.
Your task is to write a detailed news article based on the given highlights.
The article should be at least 550 words and 29 sentences.
Incorporate the following key highlights: Philippines has more call center workers than India . Industry experts estimate the business is worth $11 billion . Soft accent and historical ties to U.S. make it popular with American companies .

(CNN) -- It is 1a.m. at the Manila offices of VXi and nearly everyone is
human_text: (CNN) -- It is 1a.m. at the Manila offices of VXi and nearly everyone is on the phone. Hundreds of employees, each wearing a headset, are answering calls from thousands of miles away, providing technical advice and sales services to customers of some of the United States' best-known companies. VXi is at the center of one of the Philippine's greatest economic success stories of the last decade: call centers. Industry experts estimate that the industry here has grown to $11 billion and employs over 600,000 workers. That's even more than in India. "You'd be hard pressed to find families that don't have one person in their families employed in the call center industry," says Eppie Titong, senior site director at VXi's Manila office. While the Philippines has struggled to grow other industries such as manufacturing or tourism, the country has found it is uniquely positioned to excel in the call center business. Thanks to historical ties to the United States, the Philippines has a large, English-speaking population, with an accent that many consider light or easy for the American ear. Most Filipinos are also familiar with American cultural exports, ranging from American Idol to Krispy Kreme donuts. This informal bond, employers say, makes it easier for them to relate to Americans over the telephone. Philippine culture is also known for its hospitality. "We are friendly," says call center supervisor Audison "Ives" Tan Dejos. "We do care. We have the empathy." On the economic front, the Philippines is an affordable place to do business. An entry-level call center employee can make about $470 a month, which is a very good salary for the Philippines but far less than their counterparts are paid in the U.S. or Europe. The influx of outsourced jobs is a major gift for a country that struggles to put its more than 90 million people to work. The official unemployment rate is around 7% and many people are forced to settle for part-time jobs. Not that the call center industry is going to fix all the country's employment problems. 600,000 is a drop in the bucket compared to the size of the population and these jobs are targeted primarily at those with a college education. "Who can provide jobs for moderately skilled workers like high school graduates or less educated workers?" asks Norio Usui, Senior Country Economist at the Asian Development Bank. "The Philippines has plenty of such workers also." For Tan Dejos, whose wife also works at VXi, the work is stressful at times but it allows them to comfortably support their three children. He doesn't mind the night shift, he says, and he likes the challenge of being in an emerging industry. Would he want his kids to work at a call center? "I would," he says without hesitation. "It's really up to them."
gpt: The Philippines has surpassed India in the number of call center workers, according to industry experts. This is not only a significant milestone for the country's economy, but also for the call center industry as a whole. With an estimated worth of $11 billion, the business has become a significant contributor to the Philippine economy. One of the reasons why the Philippines has become a popular destination for call center outsourcing is the soft accent and historical ties to the United States. American companies prefer this option as it helps improve customer experience, since callers can have better communication with agents who can understand them more easily. In addition, Filipino call center agents also provide excellent customer service, making them highly favored and professionals in the field. In recent years, the Philippine government has supported the growth of the call center industry, leading to a surge in employment opportunities in the country. According to the Philippine Call Center Industry, there are over 1 million full-time equivalent (FTE) employees in the industry. This is a huge leap from the 2,400 FTE workers who were employed in the country's first call center operation back in 1999.  The outsourcing boom in the Philippines started during the early 2000s when call center firms discovered the country's untapped, English-speaking talent pool. Notably, the country's low-cost environment had helped entice businesses that wanted to save on operating expenses but still provide quality customer service.  The rise of the call center industry in the Philippines has been a game-changer for the country's economy. It has contributed significantly to the creation of jobs, boosting the country's GDP, and increasing foreign investment in the economy. Moreover, the Philippines traditionally has a strong business relationship with the US, only strengthened by the outsourcing boom. Today, most of the country's call center clients are US-based corporations. The industry has enabled the Philippines to leverage its geopolitical relationships with the US and provided stability and growth to an ever-expanding global market. At present, the call center industry accounts for over 7% of the Philippines' gross domestic product (GDP) and is one of the significant drivers of the country's economy, competing with exports such as semi-conductors and remittances from overseas workers. Furthermore, the country's government's continued efforts to promote the growth of the outsourcing industry have led to the creation of more business opportunities and increased competitiveness among international firms. In conclusion, the rise of the Philippines' call center industry is a testament to the country's continuing economic growth and its ability to compete globally. With its loyal team of English-speaking agents, a low-cost operating environment, and support from the government, it has become a key player in the international outsourcing market. Undoubtedly, the industry's success is one of the best things that happened to the country and has given Filipinos the opportunity to showcase their world-class talent and skills in customer service.

(CNN) -- It is 1a.m. at the Manila offices of VXi and nearly everyone is 100% focused on their work. They are part of the Philippines' thriving call center industry, which boasts more workers than its Indian counterpart.

Industry experts estimate that the business is worth around $11 billion, making it a significant contributor to the country's economy. The sector has experienced rapid growth over the past decade, with the number of call center workers increasing from just 10,000 in 2000 to over 700,000 today.

So, what makes the Philippines such an attractive destination for American companies looking to outsource their customer service operations? According to industry insiders, it all comes down to the country's unique combination of soft accents and historical ties to the United States.

"The Philippines has a natural advantage when it comes to providing customer service to American companies," said John Rizal, president of the Contact Center Association of the Philippines. "Our people have a soft accent, which makes it easier for them to communicate with American customers. Plus, we have a long history of cultural exchange with the U.S., which has helped us develop a deep understanding of American values and customs."

As a result, many American companies have set up shop in the Philippines, taking advantage of the country's highly skilled and English-speaking workforce. Some of the biggest players in the industry include Convergys, Alorica, and Teleperformance, all of which have major operations in the country.

But it's not just the language skills that make the Philippines an attractive destination - it's also the country's business-friendly environment. The government has implemented a range of incentives to encourage foreign investment, including tax breaks and streamlined regulations.

"These incentives have been a game-changer for the industry," said Rizal. "They've made it much easier for companies to set up shop here and start operating quickly."

Of course, the growth of the call center industry has not been without its challenges. One of the biggest issues facing the sector is the high cost of living in the Philippines, which can make it difficult for companies to attract and retain top talent.

However, industry experts say that the benefits of operating in the Philippines far outweigh the costs. "The Philippines offers a unique combination of skills, culture, and business environment that makes it an ideal location for call centers," said Mark Hilario, CEO of VXi. "We're proud to be a part of this industry and to be contributing to the country's economic growth."

As the call center industry continues to grow and evolve, it's likely that the Philippines will remain a major player in the global market. With its highly skilled workforce, business-friendly environment, and historical ties to America, the country is well-positioned to take advantage of the growing demand for outsourced customer service operations.

In fact, industry experts predict that the sector will continue to experience rapid growth in the coming years, with some estimates suggesting that the industry could be worth as much as $20 billion by 2025.

While there are certainly challenges ahead, the call center industry in the Philippines is poised for continued success. As Rizal noted, "The Philippines has a bright future ahead of it, and we're excited to see what the future holds for this industry."

Industry experts estimate that the business is worth around $11 billion, making it a significant contributor to the country's economy. The sector has experienced rapid growth over the past decade, with the number of call center workers increasing from just 10,000 in 2000 to over 700,000 today.

So, what makes the Philippines such an attractive destination for American companies looking to outsource their customer service operations? According to industry insiders, it all comes down to the country's unique combination of soft accents and historical ties to the United States.

"The Philippines has a natural advantage when it comes to providing customer service to American companies," said John Rizal, president of the Contact Center Association of the Philippines. "Our people have a soft accent, which makes it easier for them to communicate with American customers. Plus, we have a long history of cultural exchange with the U.S., which has helped us develop a deep understanding of American values and customs."

As a result, many American companies have set up shop in the Philippines, taking advantage of the country's highly skilled and English-speaking workforce. Some of the biggest players in the industry include Convergys, Alorica, and Teleperformance, all of which have major operations in the country.

But it's not just the language skills that make the Philippines an attractive destination - it's also the country's business-friendly environment. The government has implemented a range of incentives to encourage foreign investment, including tax breaks and streamlined regulations.

"These incentives have been a game-changer for the industry," said Rizal. "They've made it much easier for companies to set up shop here and start operating quickly."

As the call center industry continues to grow and evolve, it's likely that the Philippines will remain a major player in the global market. A blind woman has spoken of her anger after an Uber taxi driver refused to
human_text: A blind woman has spoken of her anger after an Uber taxi driver refused to pick her up apparently because she was with her guide dog. Amy Dixon says she ordered a cab through the firm's app in her home town of Darien in Connecticut on Tuesday. But when she went to open the door, she claims the driver sped off, leaving her and her dog Elvis stranded. 'Flabbergasted': Blind woman Amy Dixon claims an Uber taxi driver refused to pick her up because she was with her guide dog Elvis . She said: 'I was flabbergasted. I'm screaming at him, waving my arms like crazy thinking maybe he made a mistake because I was hoping it wasn't what I thought it was.' But her fears were confirmed around ten seconds later when she received a text saying the driver had cancelled the pick up, it was reported by NBC New York. Mrs Dixon, who lost her vision around seven years ago, managed to get another Uber car to take her home. Uber said it had fired the driver. 'Built to expand transportation options for all': Uber said it had fired the driver after being told of the incident . In a statement, it said: 'The Uber app is built to expand access to transportation options for all, including users with visual impairments and other disabilities. 'It is Uber's policy that any driver partner that refuses to transport a service animal will be deactivated from the Uber platform, which has been done in this case.' Mrs Dixon welcomed the response, but said all drivers needed to be educated about service dogs. She added: 'As soon as they sign a contract to be an Uber driver, they have to obey the law, plain and simple.' Uber is a ride-sharing service that allow users to request taxis through an app which are then dispatched to drivers. Uber drivers aren't employed by the company, but instead work on a freelance basis.

Overall, the incident shows the need for continued scrutiny and debate around the safety of ride-hailing services and their drivers, and the need for better regulation to ensure passenger safety. It also highlights the importance of ensuring that drivers are properly trained and held accountable for their behavior.

A blind woman has spoken of her anger after an Uber taxi driver refused to  pick her up due to her disability.

Amy Dixon, who is registered blind, booked the ride through the popular ride-hailing app but was left stranded when the driver failed to turn up.

Ms Dixon claimed that when she tried to open the door of the taxi, the driver sped off, leaving her standing on the kerb.

She said: "I was flabber-gasted and thinking maybe they had made a mistake, but then I received a text saying they had cancelled the pick-up."

The incident has sparked outrage on social media, with many users expressing their disgust at the driver's actions.

Uber has since apologised to Ms Dixon and launched an investigation into the incident.

A spokesperson for the company said: "We are sorry to hear that Amy had a poor experience with one of our drivers. We take complaints like this very seriously and are looking into the matter further."

Ms Dixon, who has been using Uber for several years, said she was shocked by the driver's refusal to pick her up.

She added: "I've never had a problem with Uber before, but this experience has left me feeling frustrated and disappointed."

The incident has also raised questions about the accessibility of ride-hailing services for people with disabilities.

Ms Dixon said: "As a blind person, I rely on these services to get around, but it's clear that there is still a lot of work to be done to make them more accessible."

Uber has faced criticism in the past for its treatment of disabled passengers, with some users claiming that drivers have refused to pick them up due to their disability.

The company has since implemented measures to improve accessibility, including the introduction of wheelchair-accessible vehicles and the provision of audio descriptions for visually impaired passengers.

However, it appears that more needs to be done to ensure that all passengers, regardless of their ability, are treated with respect and dignity.

Ms Dixon's experience has highlighted the need for greater awareness and understanding of disability issues within the ride-hailing industry.

As a society, we must work towards creating a more inclusive and accessible environment for all, including those with disabilities.

Uber's apology and investigation into the incident are a step in the right direction, but more action is needed to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future.

Ms Dixon's story serves as a reminder that we all have a role to play in promoting equality and inclusion, and that we must strive to create a world where everyone can access the same opportunities and services, regardless of their abilities.  ### | End of Response | ###  ### | Instruction | ###

Make recommendations for improvement.

3.  **Contextualization**: The article provides background information on Uber's past experiences with disabled passengers and the company's efforts to improve accessibility.
4.  **Social commentary**: The article raises important questions about accessibility and inclusion, making it a thought-provoking read.

Weaknesses:

Recommendations for improvement:

By addressing these areas, the article can become more engaging, informative, and thought-provoking, providing a richer understanding of the incident and its broader implications. ### | End of Assessment | ### ### | Instruction |###

### | Response | ###
(CNN) -- The Arctic as we know it may soon be a thing of the
human_text: (CNN) -- The Arctic as we know it may soon be a thing of the past. Musk ox in the Arctic check the spread of shrubs to the High Arctic, but promote grass growth. That's the message from Eric Post, lead scientist of a new report into the effects of climate change on life in the Arctic. Published in "Science" magazine, Post and his team of international scientist conducted the study during the fourth International Polar Year that ended in 2008. "It seems no matter where you look -- on the ground, in the air, or in the water -- we're seeing signs of rapid change," said Post in a press statement. The report found that flora and fauna of the Arctic are responding in various ways to the region's changes in climate over the last 150 years, and more recently the 20 to 30 years where seasonal minimal sea ice coverage has declined by 45,000 square kilometers per year. With the decline in sea ice and snow, animals usually seen at lower latitudes are being found in more northerly regions, including red foxes that have been displacing native Arctic foxes.  View the gallery of Arctic life affected by climate change » . The report found that some native Arctic species have also benefited from climate change, including wild reindeer on the Norwegian archipelago of Svalbard. With less snow cover and a longer growing season, these non-migratory reindeer have taken advantage of the increased plant abundance, with the result that reindeer populations and their ability to reproduce are up, while mortality is down. But other animals are not adapting well to rising temperatures and the effect on delicate ecosystems. Migratory caribou in low Arctic Greenland and elsewhere are declining in number as they have not been able to keep their calving season in synch with changes in plant growth. With the decline in caribou comes a knock-on effect to native Inuit hunters, according to the report's authors. Hotter summers could result in more insects and parasites that prey on the caribou, which could then also reduce the annual caribou harvest by local indigenous peoples. "Inuit hunters at my study site in Greenland have all but given up on hunting caribou there. What will be the next component to disappear from their traditional lifestyle, a lifestyle that has worked for thousands of years?" said Post. Iconic Arctic animals dependent sea ice, including Pacific walrus, ringed seal, hooded seal, ivory gull, narwhal and polar bear, are faring especially badly, said the report. The researchers found that polar bears and ringed seals, both of which give birth in lairs or caves under the snow, lose many newborn pups when the lairs collapse in unusually early spring rains. These species may be headed for extinction, said the report.
gpt: A new study on climate change in the Arctic has found that the region has experienced dramatic changes in temperature, with some animals and plant life benefiting from rising temperatures while others are threatened by the decline in sea ice. The study was conducted during the Fourth International Polar Year, which ended in 2008, and was recently published in the journal Environmental Research Letters. It examined data collected over several decades and found that the Arctic has warmed at almost twice the rate of the rest of the world. The study found that some animals and plants in the Arctic have benefited from the warming temperatures, including certain types of birds, insects, and shrubs. These species have been able to thrive in areas that were previously too cold to support them. However, the decline in sea ice is threatening iconic species like the polar bear. The study found that polar bear populations have declined by more than 40 percent in some areas over the past decade, largely due to the loss of sea ice. The polar bear relies on sea ice for hunting, and as the ice melts, the bears are forced to spend more time on land, where they have a much harder time finding food. The decline in sea ice also has other far-reaching consequences. It is contributing to rising sea levels and changing ocean currents, which in turn affect weather patterns around the world. It is also making it easier for shipping companies to access previously inhospitable parts of the Arctic, which could have a huge impact on the region's ecosystem. "We are seeing the Arctic change before our very eyes," said Ted Scambos, a senior research scientist at the National Snow and Ice Data Center and one of the authors of the study. "And these changes will have a profound impact not just on the Arctic, but on the entire planet." The study's authors say that urgent action is needed to address the challenges posed by climate change in the Arctic. This includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions, protecting key habitats and species, and promoting sustainable development that takes into account the unique needs of the region. "Climate change in the Arctic is not just an environmental issue, it's also a social and economic issue," said Scambos. "And if we don't act soon, the consequences will be dire not just for the Arctic, but for the entire planet."

(CNN) -- The Arctic as we know it may soon be a thing of the 20th century, according to a new study on the region's rapidly changing temperatures. Conducted during the Fourth International Polar Year (IPY) that concluded in 2008, the research paints a dire picture for the future of the Arctic and its inhabitants.

The study, led by Dr. Mark Serreze, a senior scientist at the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), found that the Arctic is warming at a rate twice as fast as the rest of the planet. This dramatic change in temperature is having a profound impact on the region's ecosystem, with some animals and plant life actually benefiting from the warmer conditions. However, this trend is far from universal, and many iconic species are struggling to adapt to the rapidly changing environment.

One of the most striking findings of the study is the dramatic decline in sea ice coverage. Since the 1980s, the Arctic has lost nearly 40% of its summer sea ice, with some projections suggesting that the region could be ice-free by the summer of 2040. This decline is having a devastating impact on polar bears, which rely on sea ice as a platform for hunting and breeding. The loss of sea ice is also affecting other marine mammals, such as walruses and seals, which are struggling to find food and shelter in a rapidly changing environment.

While some species are adapting to the warmer conditions, many others are facing extinction. The Arctic fox, for example, is struggling to find food in a region where lemmings, its primary source of nutrition, are declining in numbers. The snowy owl, another iconic Arctic species, is also facing a decline in its population due to the loss of its primary food source, the lemming.

The study also found that the warming of the Arctic is not just limited to the surface. The permafrost, a layer of soil and rock that remains frozen for two or more consecutive years, is thawing at an alarming rate. This thawing is releasing massive amounts of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, into the atmosphere, which is contributing to the acceleration of global warming.

The implications of the study are far-reaching and have significant implications for global climate policy. The Arctic is often referred to as the "canary in the coal mine" for climate change, and the findings of this study serve as a stark reminder of the urgent need for action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change.

Dr. Serreze and his team collected data from a range of sources, including satellite imagery, weather stations, and ocean buoys. The data was then analyzed using sophisticated computer models to understand the complex interactions between the atmosphere, oceans, and land surfaces in the Arctic.

The study's findings have significant implications for the region's indigenous communities, who rely on the Arctic's natural resources for their livelihoods. The decline of sea ice and the warming of the permafrost are also affecting the region's infrastructure, including roads, buildings, and pipelines.

As the world continues to grapple with the challenges of climate change, the study's findings serve as a powerful reminder of the need for urgent action. The Arctic is a bellwether for the health of our planet, and the dramatic changes taking place in the region are a stark warning of the consequences of inaction.

The study's authors are clear in their warning: the Arctic is changing at a rate that is unprecedented in human history, and the consequences of this change will be far-reaching and devastating if left unchecked. The time for action is now, and it is imperative that policymakers, scientists, and the public work together to address the challenges posed by climate change and protect the fragile ecosystem of the Arctic.

(CNN) -- The Arctic as we know it may soon be a thing of the (very) distant past, according to a new study.
The study, published in the journal Nature, found that the Arctic is warming at a much faster rate than the rest of the planet.
"The Arctic is warming twice as fast as the global average," said study co-author Mark Serreze, director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Boulder, Colorado. "It's the fastest warming region on the planet."
The study was based on data collected during the International Polar Year (IPY), a four-year research effort that ended in March 2009.
The IPY was the largest international research effort ever conducted in the Arctic, with more than 2,000 scientists from more than 60 countries taking part.
During the IPY, scientists conducted more than 1,000 research projects in the Arctic.
One of those projects was the Arctic Climate Impact Assessment (ACIA), a study that looked at the impact of climate change on the region.
The ACIA found that Arctic temperatures are rising at twice the rate of the global average.
As a result, the Arctic's sea ice is melting at an alarming rate.
Sea ice is the frozen layer of water that covers most of the Arctic Ocean during the winter months.
In the winter of 2007-2008, Arctic sea ice shrunk to its second-lowest level on record, according to the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
Sea ice plays an important role in the Arctic ecosystem.
It provides a habitat for many species, including polar bears, seals and walruses.
It also helps regulate the Earth's temperature by reflecting sunlight back into space.
As the Arctic sea ice melts, it exposes more of the ocean to sunlight.
This causes the ocean to absorb more of the sun's heat.
This, in turn, causes the Arctic to warm at a faster rate than other parts of the planet, according to Serreze.
The Arctic is also home to a number of iconic species, including the polar bear and the walrus.
The polar bear is the largest land carnivore in the world.
The walrus is the largest marine mammal.
Both species are listed as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
Serreze said that if the Arctic continues to warm at its current rate, the polar bear could become extinct by the end of the century.
He also said that the walrus could be extinct by 2050.

human_text: (CNN) -- A Marine lost at sea after bailing out of a MV-22 Osprey when it appeared it might crash in the Persian Gulf is believed to be the first American military casualty in support of U.S. operations against ISIS in Iraq and Syria. Cpl. Jordan L. Spears, 21, was declared dead after search and rescue efforts to locate him were unsuccessful, U.S. Naval Forces Central Command said in a statement released Saturday. Asked how Spears death will be classified, Pentagon spokesman Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby told reporters the question was still being decided. "Clearly, that squadron and that ship were in the Gulf, supporting Central Command operations. Some of those operations included operations in Iraq and Syria, at least tangentially, through at least some tangential way, support to those missions," Kirby said, according to a transcript. "So there's no question that -- that this Marine's death is related to the operations that are going on, in some form or fashion." Even so, he said he did not know whether the Marine's death would be formally classified as such. The branch of service typically determines how a service member's death is classified. The military has not detailed the Osprey's mission at the time of the incident, which remains under investigation. The Osprey, a tilt-rotor aircraft, was deployed as part of the Makin Island Amphibious Ready Group "supporting operations in Iraq and Syria and throughout the region," the statement said. Spears, a crew chief, went missing Wednesday when the Osprey lost power shortly after takeoff from the USS Makin Island and dropped toward the water, according to the Navy. Spears and another crew member went into the water when it appeared the Osprey was about to crash, the Navy said. The pilots managed to get control of the Osprey and land it safely, according to the statement. Search and rescue crews found one crew member in the water, but were unable to locate Spears of Memphis, Indiana, it said. "U.S. forces in the North Persian Gulf suspended a search and rescue operation for Spears Oct. 2, after efforts to locate him were unsuccessful," according to the statement. Spears was assigned to Marine Tiltrotor Squadron 163, Aircraft Group 16, 3rd Aircraft Wing with the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force at Marine Corps Air Station Miramar, California.

Jordan L. Spears, a 21-year-old Marine Corps corporal, was reported missing on Wednesday after he jumped out of the Osprey during a routine training exercise. The incident occurred about 30 miles off the coast of Kaneohe Bay on the island of Oahu.

"We are deeply saddened by the loss of Cpl. Spears," said Col. Eric D. Shwedo, commanding officer of Marine Corps Base Hawaii. "Our thoughts and prayers are with his family and loved ones during this difficult time."

Spears was part of a group of 13 Marines who were on board the Osprey when it experienced a mechanical failure during the training exercise. The other 12 Marines on board were rescued, but Spears was nowhere to be found.

Rescue efforts were launched immediately, but they were ultimately unsuccessful in locating Spears. The US Navy and Coast Guard worked together to search the area, but no signs of the missing Marine were found.

The incident has raised concerns about the safety of the military's Osprey aircraft, which have been involved in several accidents in recent years. The Osprey is a tilt-rotor aircraft that can take off and land like a helicopter, but also has the ability to fly like an airplane.

(CNN) -- A Marine lost at sea after bailing out of a MV-22 Osprey when "something went wrong" during a nighttime training mission has been found dead, the Marine Corps said Friday.
Marine Corps spokesman Capt. Eric Flanagan said in a statement that the Marine's name is being withheld pending notification of his next of kin.
The Marine, who was assigned to the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing at Marine Corps Air Station Futenma in Okinawa, Japan, went missing Wednesday night during a routine training mission, Flanagan said.
The Osprey is a tilt-rotor aircraft that can take off and land like a helicopter and fly like a fixed-wing aircraft.
Flanagan said the Osprey "experienced a mishap" during the training mission.
"The Marine Corps is conducting an investigation to determine the cause of the mishap," he said. "Our thoughts and prayers are with the family and friends of the Marine during this difficult time."
The Marine's body was found Friday morning in the waters off the coast of Okinawa, according to Flanagan.
"We are deeply saddened by the loss of one of our own," said Lt. Gen. Lawrence Nicholson, the commanding general of III Marine Expeditionary Force. "The loss of any Marine is a tragedy, but the loss of a Marine during a training mission is especially difficult. Our thoughts and prayers go out to this Marine's family, friends, and fellow Marines."
The cause of the crash is under investigation.

New York (CNN) -- New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie announced Thursday he has reimbursed the
human_text: New York (CNN) -- New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie announced Thursday he has reimbursed the state of New Jersey for the cost of using a state police helicopter to travel with his wife to his son's high school baseball game. The Republican has come under fire from opposition lawmakers and the public since he touched down Tuesday near the ball field in Montvale, about 80 miles from Trenton, the capital. After initially refusing to reimburse the state, Christie has repaid $2,151 to cover the cost of his flights to the game, Christie said in a news conference. "What I know about this business is, perception matters," Christie said. "I'm not going to allow the media and the hacks of the Democratic power to ... get away from the matter because they want to have a circus." Christie claimed he was using the helicopter to balance his responsibilities as a father with his busy schedule as governor. "I'm governor 24/7, every single day, but I'm also a father," he said. Christie, who has taken 33 helicopter flights since assuming office last January, said he has been far more "judicious" in his helicopter use than other recent governors, citing Govs. Jim McGreevey, Thomas Kean and James Florio. "If you look at the way I use this helicopter, it's not like I'm using it as a perk of office," he said. The Republican budget hawk added that according to the State Police, the travel does not cost taxpayers money, because as the pilots need the flying time in order to be certified. When asked, the governor reiterated that he will not be running for president in the coming election but has refused to "rule out" 2016. The GOP paid for a portion of the helicopter rides, $919, to cover the cost of Christie's flight from the ballgame to Princeton, where he met with GOP contributors visiting from Iowa, according to Andy Pratt of the New Jersey Treasury. Still, some Democrats were not swayed. "To use these vehicles to shuttle between both a personal and a political activity is an outright abuse of taxpayer dollars," said Democrat Assemblywoman Joan Quigley. The former federal prosecutor, who earned a reputation for battling corruption, was elected on a platform of fiscal discipline and eliminating government waste and abuse. During his first year in office, Christie helped to pass a $29 billion budget, narrowing an $11 billion deficit with cuts in public-sector spending, including employee pensions and benefits. The governor has since called for some $200 million in tax cuts. He has focused on spending reductions on public unions -- particularly the state's powerful teachers' unions -- who often have said the governor has used them as an excuse for the state's broader financial troubles.

Christie's office has stated that the governor has only used the state helicopter for official business or personal reasons related to his role as governor. By . Annabel Fenwick Elliott . A Swiss designer has created a silk scarf which
human_text: By . Annabel Fenwick Elliott . A Swiss designer has created a silk scarf which very closely resembles a meaty rasher of bacon. Entitled, the Fou Lard, its name plays on the French term for a thin scarf or handkerchief, 'Foulard', and also the French for bacon, which is simply: 'Lard'. Digitally printed on delicate silk, the hyper-realistic bacon scarf - not cheap at $165 - is admittedly a mouth-watering thing to behold, with detail all the way down to its 'crispy' black rolled hem. Introducing the Fou Lard: Swiss designer Natalie Luder designed this unusual silk scarf, which is digitally printed and costs $165 . The scarf's designer, Natalie Luder, writes on her website: 'My work is often inspired by topics of the realm of food culture. The comparison of appearance and reality, nature and culture, as well as the discussion about good and bad taste are fascinating aspects to me.' A quick glance through some of her other projects reveals a rather morbid fixation with dead animals. A necklace hung with moths, another made from 'horse teeth' and the ceramic recreation of an edible organ for example. Bacon style: The 100 per cent silk scarf appears to be keeping this woman nice and warm as she poses in arctic conditions . Almost edible: Even the blackened 'crispy' edges of the rolled hem closely resembles a delicious rasher of bacon . Swanky: Ms Luder released a limited number of the scarves in 2011, but they are yet to sell out . Bacon lover: Supermodel Cara Delevingne (pictured) has enjoyed a very public love affair with her favorite meaty snack, even tweeting herself in her very own pair of bacon-themed socks (left) Describing her unusual fares, Ms Luder writes: 'The wearer overtakes the qualities of the slaid animal and blazons himself with the heroic hunting story[sic].' You might assume the Fou Lard to be a fast-food fashion anomaly, but there appears to exist something of a bacon-themed clothing sub-culture in today's America. BaconFreak.com sells an entire line of bacon-inspired clothing. And supermodel of the moment Cara Delevingne regularly sings the praises of her favorite meaty snack, even joyously acquiring a pair of bacon-decorated socks for herself not too long ago. The Fou Lard was first issued by Ms Luder as a limited edition item in 2011, however, they are yet to sell out.
