By. Wills Robinson. PUBLISHED:. 14:02 EST, 2 November 2013. |. 0 Comments
Two British men are being hunted by police in the Netherlands after a raid on a cafe in Rotterdam uncovered a stash of guns and mobile phones.

Robert Gerrard, 34, and Michael Moogan, 41, are wanted in connection with the discovery of two handguns and over 100 mobile phones at a store in the Dutch city.

The pair, who are believed to be from Liverpool, are thought to have been using the cafe as a meeting point for their alleged criminal activities.

Their addresses in Liverpool were also searched by police as part of the investigation into the pair's activities.

It is understood that Gerrard and Moogan had been living in the Netherlands for some time and had been using the country as a base for their alleged crimes.

The discovery of the guns and mobile phones was made during a search of a store in Rotterdam, which is believed to have been used as a front for the pair's illicit activities.

Police in the Netherlands have launched a manhunt for the pair, who are considered to be a threat to public safety.

Gerrard and Moogan are described as being white, with Gerrard standing at 5ft 9in and Moogan at 6ft 1in.

They are believed to have been involved in a range of criminal activities, including money laundering and people trafficking.

Their alleged crimes are thought to have taken place over a number of years, with the pair using the Netherlands as a base to carry out their activities.

Detectives in the Netherlands are working closely with their counterparts in the UK to track down the pair and bring them to justice.

A spokesperson for the Dutch police said: "We are working closely with the British authorities to locate the two men and we urge anyone with information about their whereabouts to come forward."

The search of Gerrard's and Moogan's addresses in Liverpool was carried out by Merseyside Police, who are also working closely with the Dutch authorities.

A spokesperson for Merseyside Police said: "We can confirm that searches were carried out at two addresses in Liverpool as part of an ongoing investigation into the activities of two men who are wanted in the Netherlands.

"We are working closely with our colleagues in the Netherlands to try to locate the men and bring them back to the UK to face justice."

The use of cafes and other businesses as meeting points for criminals is a growing concern for law enforcement agencies around the world.

In recent years, there have been a number of high-profile cases in which cafes and other businesses have been used as fronts for organized crime groups.

The use of these types of businesses as meeting points makes it difficult for law enforcement agencies to track down and prosecute those involved in criminal activities.

In this case, the use of the cafe in Rotterdam appears to have been a key factor in the pair's alleged crimes, with the store being used as a front to launder money and facilitate people trafficking.

The investigation into Gerrard and Moogans' activities is ongoing, with detectives in the Netherlands and the UK working closely together to track them down.

Anyone with information about the pair's whereabouts is urged to come forward and contact the Dutch police or Merseyside Police.

The Dutch police can be contacted on +31 900 8844, while Merseyside Police can be contacted on 0151 709 6010.

By . Wills Robinson . PUBLISHED: . 14:02 EST, 2 November 2013 . | . 498 WORDS | | 26 SENTENCES |
Two men have been arrested on suspicion of being involved in organised crime in the Netherlands.
Robert Gerrard, 30, and Michael Moogam, 28, were detained in Rotterdam on Tuesday.
The pair were wanted in connection with a raid on a cafe in Liverpool, Merseyside, last month.
The cafe was allegedly used by criminals as a meeting point.
Addresses in the city linked to the men were also searched.
Detectives from Merseyside Police and the North West Regional Organised Crime Unit (NWROCU) carried out the raids as part of an ongoing investigation into organised crime in Liverpool.
Detective Chief Superintendent Paul Richardson, head of the NWROCU, said: 'This is a significant development in our investigation into the activities of organised crime in Merseyside.
'We will continue to work closely with our colleagues in the Netherlands to bring those responsible to justice.
'I would like to thank the public for their support and co-operation during this investigation.'
Mr Gerrard has been charged with possession of a firearm with intent to endanger life.
Mr Moogam is charged with being concerned in the supply of Class A drugs.
Both men have been remanded in custody and are due to appear at Liverpool Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.

human_text: A 35-year-old mother accused of murdering her newborn son has appeared briefly in a Gold Coast court. Jodie Tarnawskyj from Paradise Point in Queensland's Gold Coast, was arrested from her home on Friday over the death of her newborn male infant on June 8. The infant was rushed to Gold Coast University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. A 35-year-old mother accused of murdering her newborn son has appeared briefly in Southport Magistrates Court in the Gold Coast, Queensland . Detectives conducted a four month investigation into the death of the child. Tarnawskyj's arrest followed a prolonged investigation conducted by detectives from Gold Coast District, the Child Trauma Task Force and the State Crime Command, that  resulted in a crime scene warrant at the Paradise Point address on Friday. The accused appeared in Southport Magistrates Court barefoot, wearing a blue tank-top and skirt on Saturday morning. According to Gold Coast Bulletin, an emotional Tarnawskyj acknowledged her partner who sat crying in the public gallery. Jodie Tarnawskyj from Paradise Point in Queensland was arrested from her home on Friday over the death of her newborn male infant on June 8 . Details on the cause of death was not outlined in court. Tarnawskyj has been remanded in custody and her matter was adjourned for a committal mention on February 2 next year. To apply for bail, Tarnawskyj will have to make an application to the Supreme Court. Police are waiting on forensics tests, which are expected to take up to three months. Queensland Police are urging anyone with information on this matter to contact Crime Stoppers anonymously via 1800 333 000 or crimestoppers.com.au 24hrs a day. human_text: (CNN) -- A day after three Connecticut asset managers claimed the largest Powerball jackpot in the state's history, a public relations executive acting on their behalf issued a statement denying there was a fourth participant who wanted to remain anonymous. Throughout the day Monday there had been published reports that the three men who appeared with the winning check were only collecting on behalf of a client of their investment firm. "While there has been much speculation and quite a bit of misinformation over the last 24 hours, this Trust, with its three trustees, has been established to manage the winnings in the most practical and expedient way possible so that we can achieve our strategic goal of helping those who can best benefit from these funds," said public relations executive Gary Lewi. "And to be clear, there are a total of three trustees and there is no anonymous fourth participant." The statement goes on to say that the financial advisers will set up a trust that will have as its focus -- among other things -- care for U.S. veterans and those returning home from deployment. Within 10 days the trust will distribute $1 million to selected veterans relief organizations within the tri-state region, Lewi said. Co-workers Tim Davidson, Brandon Lacoff and Greg Skidmore claimed the prize from the November 2 drawing, which netted them more than $100 million, at a presentation by the Connecticut Lottery Corp. Ranjit Singh, the manager of the Stamford BP gas station where the winning ticket was purchased, told CNN's Mary Snow that he is sure it was Tim Davidson who purchased the ticket. "I do recognize him, I cannot forget the face." Singh also said he remembers that he pushed Davidson to buy a ticket. The jackpot was $254 million, had the winners taken a multiyear payout. They opted instead for a one-time cash payout that totaled $103.6 million after taxes, according to Connecticut Lottery spokeswoman Linda Tarnowski. It was the 12th-largest jackpot in Powerball history, according to Anne Noble, president of the Connecticut Lottery. "Everybody is extremely excited -- these numbers are huge," said the trio's attorney, Jason Kurland. "This is going to benefit many people." Kurland spoke on behalf of three winners, all asset managers at start-up firm Belpointe Asset Management in Greenwich, Connecticut. He said that the men will donate "a significant amount" of the winnings to charities in the state. Davidson bought the $1 ticket at a gas station in Stamford, Kurland said. After realizing they had a winning ticket the following morning, the three co-workers formed the Putnam Avenue Family Trust, each becoming a trustee. "They have become their dream client," Kurland said. Skidmore was the only one of the three winners to speak at Monday's press conference. "It feels good," he said. CNN's Mary Snow and Leigh Remizowski contributed to this report.

(CNN) -- A day after three Connecticut asset managers claimed the largest Powerball jackpot in 10 years, the winners are speaking out.
Gary Lewi, a spokesman for the three winners, told CNN's "New Day" on Wednesday that the winners are "very, very happy."
"They're very, very excited," Lewi said. "It's a dream come true for them."
Lewi said the winners, who have chosen to remain anonymous, are a married couple in their 50s and a single woman in her 30s.
"They are very, very happy," Lewi told CNN. "They can't believe it. They're still in shock."
The three winners, who chose to take the lump-sum payout of $254.2 million instead of the 30-year annuity option, have yet to decide what they will do with the money.
"The first thing they're going to do is take care of their families and their friends, and then they'll decide what they want to do with the rest of the money," said Lewi.
Lewi also said the winners have not yet decided where they will live.
"I don't think they've decided where they want to live yet," he said.
The winning numbers were 6, 7, 16, 23, 26 and the Powerball number was 4.
The odds of winning the Powerball jackpot are 1 in 175,711,536, according to the game's website.
The Powerball jackpot has been growing since October 2015, when it was $40 million.
The largest Powerball prize ever was $590.5 million, shared by winners in California, Florida and Tennessee in May 2013.

By . Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor . PUBLISHED: . 11:15 EST, 26 June 2013
human_text: By . Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor . PUBLISHED: . 11:15 EST, 26 June 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 13:19 EST, 26 June 2013 . George Osborne today said he was ‘proud’ that the UK government is spending more on foreign aid. The Chancellor risked the wrath of Tory backbenchers who have called for cuts to international development by announcing an extra £800million for 2015-16. But to meet the coalition’s pledge to spend 0.7 per cent of national income on aid, money from the Home Office and Business will count towards the target. Aid: The coalition has committed to spending 0.7 per cent of national income on overseas aid, while cutting elsewhere . Proud: George Osborne defended the decision to increase foreign aid spending while cutting other Whitehall departments y up to 10 per cent . Right wingers on the Tory backbenchers have repeatedly called for an end to the protection given to overseas aid. Along with health and schools, it was one of the only areas of spending ring fenced by Mr Osborne in his search for an extra £11.5billion of cuts in 2015-16. In total the UK will spend £12.22billion in its Official Development Assistance commitment. It means it will spend 0.7 per cent of gross national income in 2015 on helping the poor overseas. It includes an extra £809million in the DFID budget. Around £100million in science research for helping poor countries from the Department for Business will also count towards the ODA target, along with £100million of Home Office funding for asylum cases. Spending: Only foreign aid, NHS and the spy agencies have seen increases in the departmental programme and administration budgets, with most departments suffering cuts of up to 10 per cent . Infrastructure: Billions of pounds in extra building projects have been directed towards transport, justice and business in an attempt to kickstart growth . Mr Osborne told MPs: ‘Fairness also means refusing to balance the budget on the backs of the world’s poorest. ‘I know not everyone believes we should fulfil our commitment to spend 0.7 per cent of our national income on development. ‘But I do – and I’m proud to support a Government that is the first in our history to meet our pledge and meet it not only this year, but next year and the year after. ‘Of course, overseas development is about more than just the DFID budget, and we comply with internationally policed rules. ‘But the DFID budget is the lion’s share, and it will be set at £11.1 billion in 2015-16. ‘Even in tough times, the decisions we make mean we keep to our commitments.’
gpt: The Department for International Development (DFID) has received a boost after the Coalition government pledged an additional £800million towards overseas aid. This comes as part of the UK's commitment to spend 0.7% of national income on foreign aid. While the DFID will benefit from the increase in funding, most other departments across the government will face significant reductions in their budgets, with cuts of up to 10% being applied. The announcement was made as part of Chancellor George Osborne's Comprehensive Spending Review (CSR), which outlined the government's spending plans for the next four years. The CSR is aimed at achieving a budget surplus by imposing austerity measures on several departments, while protecting those deemed critical to the government's priorities. The DFID has been a key player in the UK's international aid efforts for many years, and the additional funding is in line with the government's commitment to alleviate poverty and support sustainable development in the world's poorest countries. The department's programmes have been credited with helping to lift millions of people out of poverty, and the new funding will allow them to continue this vital work. However, the decision to protect the DFID's budget while cutting others has been met with criticism from some quarters. Critics argue that while it is important to support international aid efforts, the government should not be so focused on this at the expense of other pressing needs, such as healthcare and education. Despite this criticism, the government has held firm on its commitment to overseas aid. In fact, the UK has become the first G7 country to meet the United Nations target of spending 0.7% of its gross national income (GNI) on development assistance. This has put pressure on other countries to follow suit and has raised the profile of international aid as a key priority for governments worldwide. The announcement also comes at a time when the UK is facing significant challenges at home, including a looming Brexit deadline and a strained economy. The government's decision to protect the DFID's budget has raised the profile of international aid as a key priority for the country's future, showing a willingness to take a long-term approach to tackling global poverty. Overall, the announcement of the additional funding for the DFID is a welcome development for those working to alleviate poverty and promote sustainable development, in the UK and around the world. The decision to protect the department's budget shows a commitment to the government's international aid goals, at a time when other departments are facing cutbacks. While there may be criticism about the balance of priorities, it is clear that the UK remains committed to being a global leader in the fight against poverty and injustice.

By. Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor. PUBLISHED:. 11:15 EST, 26 June 2013  |  UPDATED:. 14:30 EST, 26 Jun 2013

George Osborne has announced an extra £800 million for the Department for International Development (DfID) in the Budget, as the Coalition reaffirmed its commitment to spending 0.

7% of national wealth on overseas aid.

The Chancellor revealed the cash boost for DfID, which will take the department's total budget to £9.1 billion, in his Budget statement to the House of Commons today.

Mr Osborne said: 'We will continue to meet our commitment to spend 0.7 per cent of GNI (Gross National Income) on overseas aid, and we will do so in a way that is transparent and accountable.'

The move was welcomed by international development secretary Justine Greening, who said: 'Today's Budget shows that the Coalition is committed to making a difference in the lives of some of the world's poorest people.

'The extra funding for DfID will help us to tackle some of the toughest global challenges, from poverty and hunger to disease and climate change.'

However, the good news for DfID was tempered by the fact that most other government departments are facing cuts of up to ten per cent to their budgets.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) has warned that the austerity measures announced in the Budget will have a disproportionate impact on low-income families.

The IFS said: 'The biggest losers from the Budget are likely to be low-income families, who will bear the brunt of the tax and benefit changes announced today.'

The think tank also pointed out that the Chancellor's decision to raise the income tax threshold to £10,000 will benefit higher earners more than lower earners.

The IFS added: 'The increase in the income tax threshold will mainly benefit higher earners, who are more likely to be working full-time and earning above £10,000 a year.'

The Budget also included a number of measures aimed at boosting economic growth, including a cut in corporation tax and an increase in the annual investment allowance for small businesses.

However, the IFS warned that these measures may not be enough to offset the impact of the austerity measures on the economy.

The think tank said: 'While the Chancellor's measures to boost economic growth are welcome, they are unlikely to be sufficient to offset the drag on the economy caused by the austerity measures.'

The Budget has been widely criticised by opposition parties, who argue that it fails to address the needs of low-income families and does not do enough to boost economic growth.

Labour's shadow chancellor Ed Balls said: 'This is a Budget that fails to address the cost-of-living crisis facing millions of families.

'The Chancellor's decision to cut benefits and raise taxes will only make things worse for those who can least afford it.'

The Liberal Democrats also expressed disappointment with the Budget, with their leader Nick Clegg saying: 'I am disappointed that the Chancellor has not done more to support low-income families and to boost economic growth.'

However, the Chancellor defended his Budget, saying: 'We have taken difficult decisions to get the country back on track, but we have also taken steps to support those who need it most.'

Mr Osborne added: 'We are committed to reducing the deficit and getting the economy growing, but we are also committed to helping those who are struggling to make ends meet.'

The Budget is the latest in a series of austerity measures announced by the Coalition since it came to power in 2010.

The measures are aimed at reducing the UK's massive budget deficit, which stands at around £120 billion.

However, the austerity measures have been widely criticized by opposition parties and many experts, who argue that they are too harsh and will damage the economy in the long term.

The Coalition has argued that the austerity measures are necessary to get the economy back on track and to reduce the burden of debt on future generations.

However, the impact of the measures on low-income families and the economy as a whole remains a major concern for many experts and opposition parties.

In conclusion, the Budget has been hailed as a success by the Coalition, but critics argue that it falls short in its commitment to supporting low-income families and boosting economic growth.

The £800 million boost to DfID's budget is a welcome move, but it is overshadowed by the austerity measures announced for most other government departments.

As the Coalition continues to implement its austerity measures, it remains to be seen whether they will have the desired impact on the economy and the lives of low-income families.

Only time will tell if the Budget will be a success or a failure, but one thing is certain - it will have a significant impact on the lives of millions of people in the UK and around the world.

By . Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor . PUBLISHED: . 11:15 EST, 26 June 2013 . UPDATED: 11:16 EST, 27 June 2012 .
The Coalition Government has been accused of 'hypocrisy' after it was revealed that the Department of International Development (DfID) is set to receive an extra 0.5 per cent of the UK's gross national income (GNI) in overseas aid - despite the fact that most other departments are facing cuts of between 10 and 25 per cent to their budgets.
The DfID will receive 0.6 per cent of GNI in 2013/14 - up from 0.4 per cent in 2012/13 - while the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) and the Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) will see their budgets cut by 10 per cent and 15 per cent respectively.
The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) and the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) will also see their budgets slashed by 10 and five per cent respectively, while the Department of Energy and Climate Change (DECC) will see its budget cut by 15 per.

Mr Osborne said: 'We will continue to meet our commitment to spend 0.7 per cent of GNI (Gross National Income) on overseas aid, and we will do so in a way that is transparent and accountable.'

The move was welcomed by international development secretary Justine Greening, who said: 'Today's Budget shows that the Coalition is committed to making a difference in the lives of some of the world's poorest people.

'The extra funding for DfID will help us to tackle some of the toughest global challenges, from poverty and hunger to disease and climate change.'

However, the good news for DfID was tempered by the fact that most other government departments are facing cuts of up to ten per cent to their budgets.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) has warned that the austerity measures announced in the Budget will have a disproportionate impact on low-income families.

The IFS said: 'The biggest losers from the Budget are likely to be low-income families, who will bear the brunt of the tax and benefit changes announced today.'

The think tank also pointed out that the Chancellor's decision to raise the income tax threshold to £10,000 will benefit higher earners more than lower earners.

The IFS added: 'The increase in the income tax threshold will mainly benefit higher earners, who are more likely to be working full-time and earning above £10,000 a year.'

The Budget also included a number of measures aimed at boosting economic growth, including a cut in corporation tax and an increase in the annual investment allowance for small businesses.

However, the IFS warned that these measures may not be enough to offset the impact of the austerity measures on the economy.

The think tank said: 'While the Chancellor's measures to boost economic growth are welcome, they are unlikely to be sufficient to offset the drag on the economy caused by the austerity measures.'

The Budget has been widely criticised by opposition parties, who argue that it fails to address the needs of low-income families and does not do enough to boost economic growth.

Labour's shadow chancellor Ed Balls said: 'This is a Budget that fails to address the cost-of-living crisis facing millions of families.

'The Chancellor's decision to cut benefits and raise taxes will only make things worse for those who can least afford it.'

The Liberal Democrats also expressed disappointment with the Budget, with their leader Nick Clegg saying: 'I am disappointed that the Chancellor has not done more to support low-income families and to boost economic growth.'

However, the Chancellor defended his Budget, saying: 'We have taken difficult decisions to get the country back on track, but we have also taken steps to support those who need it most.'

Mr Osborne added: 'We are committed to reducing the deficit and getting the economy growing, but we are also committed to helping those who are struggling to make ends meet.'

The Budget is the latest in a series of austerity measures announced by the Coalition since it came to power in 2010.

The measures are aimed at reducing the UK's massive budget deficit, which stands at around £120 billion.

However, the austerity measures have been widely criticized by opposition parties and many experts, who argue that they are too harsh and will damage the economy in the long term.

The Coalition has argued that the austerity measures are necessary to get the economy back on track and to reduce the burden of debt on future generations.

However, the impact of the measures on low-income families and the economy as a whole remains a major concern for many experts and opposition parties.

In conclusion, the Budget has been hailed as a success by the Coalition, but critics argue that it falls short in its commitment to supporting low-income families and boosting economic growth.

The £800 million boost to DfID's budget is a welcome move, but it is overshadowed by the austerity measures announced for most other government departments.

As the Coalition continues to implement its austerity measures, it remains to be seen whether they will have the desired impact on the economy and the lives of low-income families.

Only time will tell if the Budget will be a success or a failure, but one thing is certain - it will have a significant impact on the lives of millions of people in the UK and around the world.

human_text: Florida theater shooting suspect Curtis Reeves is lonely but confident that his self-defense claim will result in his acquittal, according to jailhouse phone calls released by the state attorney's office. According to CNN affiliate, Bay News 9, the 71-year-old, who is being held without bail on a second-degree murder charge, also tells his daughter he's concerned about the family's finances. "I'm more worried about you all than I'm worried about me," he says. "And we're more worried about you than we are worried about us," Jennifer Shaw, his daughter, responds. "Well, if all the facts come out we all should be in good shape." "I know, but we just hate that you have to be in there right now." In January, Reeves and his wife were attending a showing of "Lone Survivor" at a Wesley Chapel movie theater. Reeves left the theater to report to management that the man in front of him, Chad Oulson, was texting during the previews. When he returned the two exchanged words. Video from the scene appears to show Oulson snatching Reeves' popcorn off his lap and throwing it at him. Reeves responds instantaneously with a single, fatal gunshot. A preliminary hearing suggested the case will come down to whether a jury believe Reeves was intimidated by Oulson and acted in self-defense, or if Reeves overreacted to Oulson texting. In the jailhouse tapes, Reeves tells his daughter she can sell some of the family's belongings if necessary. "If we need money, sell the motorcycle, motorcycle trailer, the kayaks, the trailer and --" Shaw cuts him off: "We have all that under control.  We're not even going to talk about it. Don't waste your time." In another moment captured on tape, his young granddaughter greets him with a "Hi!" "Hey sweetheart, this is Pawpaw. Pawpaw loves you," Reeves said. "Can you tell grandpa 'I love you'?" Shaw asks the child. Her age is not clear, but her voice is that of a very young girl. "Pawpaw, love you," the granddaughter says.

human_text: (CNN) -- FIFA president Sepp Blatter believes Spain's La Liga is the best football league in the world, and claims that England's top division can learn from it. In an exclusive interview with CNN's World Sport, Blatter pointed to the eight Spain-based players in the 2010 FIFA World XI and Spain's World Cup success as justification. "(Looking at the World XI) it must be the strongest league in the world," he said. "And when you see the starting XI of the Spanish national team (who won the World Cup), all of them play their football in Spain. The Spanish league also has the highest number of local players." Why were EPL players snubbed in all-star team? Blatter told World Sport's Pedro Pinto the lack of England-based players in the FIFA World XI undermined the quality of the country's Premier League. "The Premier League is the best-marketed league in the world," he said. "It's a good league, with good players, but when you consider not one player made the best XI of the world, maybe they should think about whether something can be adapted." The FIFA World XI featured six players from Barcelona and two from Real Madrid, with the other three from Italian Serie A champions Inter Milan. Among their number was the 2010 Ballon d'Or winner Lionel Messi, the 23-year-old midfielder who beat his Barcelona teammates Xavi and Andres Iniesta to be named the world's best player for the second year in a row. "Leo Messi is what I identify as a wonderful football player and a good boy. He is really humble. It's not a game he's playing, he's not an actor," Blatter said. Have your say on Blatter's decisions . Blatter said Messi needed to win a World Cup before he could be compared to fellow Argentine Diego Maradona, captain of the 1986 champion side. "When I compare Messi to Maradona, both are excellent, talented players. They could not be more talented. But the difference is their personal educational characteristics," Blatter said. "One is still in football, modest and not trying to get into the extravaganza. The other did it."

By . Ben Spencer . PUBLISHED: . 17:52 EST, 8 December 2013 . | .
human_text: By . Ben Spencer . PUBLISHED: . 17:52 EST, 8 December 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 03:10 EST, 9 December 2013 . Personal? A study in Philadelphia has found each person interprets smells differently . It is an age-old problem. Why is it so difficult to buy perfume for a loved one? Well, scientists may have come up with the answer - but it doesn’t make picking a gift any easier. We all think we know how certain things smell. But to someone else that same bottle of perfume - or piece of cheese, or glass of wine - may smell completely differently. American scientists have discovered that we all experience odours in a completely different way. Their paper, published in the Nature Neuroscience journal, reveals that 30 per cent of smell receptors differ between any two people. Each single receptor can alter the way each person perceives an odour. Dr Joel Mainland, a molecular biologist at the Monell Chemical Senses Centre in Philadelphia, said: ‘For different items there is a big gap between what you smell and what I smell. ‘The amount of variation was really surprising to us - it was about 30 per cent of receptors are different between two individuals at random. That is a pretty high number.’ The human nose contains 400 different olfactory receptors - and Dr Mainland’s team found that changing a single receptor could dramatically change the way a person perceives a smell. Good or bad? While some detect the aromatic smell of sandalwood from a scented candle, others smell it as pee . Dr Mainland said: ‘The activation pattern . of these 400 receptors encodes both the intensity of an odour and the . quality – for example, whether it smells like vanilla or smoke – for the . tens of thousands of different odours that represent everything we . smell.’ Changing one particular receptor meant . that some people smell a specific type of steroid as a pleasant . sandalwood - while others thought it smells like pee. ‘It is very different,’ Dr Mainland said. ‘One person might find it to be mild and pleasant and by changing that single receptor another might find it to be as a very strong and urinous.’ The researchers cloned 511 receptors and embedded them in host cells in the laboratory. They then measured how each receptor responded to a panel of 73 different odours. The process identified 28 different ways that each array of receptors would respond to the different odours. The team used mathematical models to extrapolate the findings, and came up with the result that 140 of their 400 receptors - about 30 per cent - of any two individuals would be different. Dr Mainland said the results may enable scientists to accurately create different smells. ‘The long-term goal is to figure out how the receptors encode odour molecules well enough that we can actually create any odour we want by manipulating the receptors directly.’

In a recent paper published by the centre, researchers found that a single change in a person's genetic makeup can cause them to perceive a scent in a completely different way to another person. For example, something that smells like sandalwood to one person could be interpreted as urine by another. Dr Joel Mainland, an author of the study, explained that this finding could have important implications for scientists who are working to create new smells. By understanding how the nose interprets different scents, researchers may be able to develop fragrances that appeal to a wider range of people. "Smell is an incredibly complex process," said Dr Mainland. "Our noses contain many different types of receptors that work together to identify different scents. By understanding how these receptors function, we may be able to create fragrances that are more universally appealing." The Monell Chemical Senses Centre is a world-renowned research institution that has been studying how the senses of taste and smell work for over 50 years. The team of scientists at the centre uses a range of advanced techniques to investigate how these senses work, including genetic sequencing, brain imaging, and behavioural studies. The recent study by the Monell team is part of a broader effort to better understand how the human body processes sensory information. By identifying the specific receptors involved in scent detection, scientists hope to gain a deeper understanding of how the brain develops and maintains these sensory abilities. While this research is still in its early stages, the implications could be far-reaching. In addition to creating new fragrances, these findings could lead to new treatments for conditions like anosmia (the loss of the sense of smell) and hypersensitivity to certain odours. "Understanding how the nose works is incredibly important," said Dr Mainland. "Our sense of smell is tied to so many aspects of our lives, from our memories and emotions to our appetite and overall well-being. The more we can learn about this sense, the better equipped we'll be to improve people's lives." Of course, there are also commercial implications to this work. Companies that produce fragrances and scented products could use this knowledge to create new and exciting scents that appeal to a broader range of consumers. This could lead to a wider variety of perfumes, soaps, and cleaning products on the market. By. Ben Spencer. PUBLISHED:. 17:52 EST, 8 December 2013. |. 1 comment

Scientists have discovered that the human nose can detect an astonishing 400 different types of receptors, making it one of the most complex organs in the body.

According to a paper published by the Monell Chemical Sciences Centre in Philadelphia, the incredible diversity of the human sense of smell is due to the presence of hundreds of different types of olfactory receptors in the nasal cavity.

Each of these receptors is responsible for detecting a specific type of molecule, known as an odorant, which is present in the air we breathe. When an odorant binds to a receptor, it triggers a signal that is sent to the brain, where it is interpreted as a particular smell.

But what's truly remarkable about the human nose is that even a single change in the shape of a receptor can result in a completely different smell being detected. This is because the shape of the receptor determines which type of odorant molecule it can bind to.

To illustrate this point, researchers at the Monell Centre conducted an experiment in which they showed volunteers a series of different smells, including sandalwood and urine. What they found was that while some people detected the unmistakable scent of sandalwood, others detected the pungent smell of urine.

The reason for this difference, the researchers discovered, was not due to any difference in the volunteers' sense of smell, but rather due to a difference in the shape of their olfactory receptors. In other words, one person's sandalwood-smelling receptor was identical to another person's urine-smelling receptor.

This finding has significant implications for scientists who are working to create new smells for use in perfumes, cleaning products, and other applications. By understanding how the shape of an olfactory receptor determines the type of smell that is detected, researchers may be able to design new receptors that can detect specific types of odorant molecules.

"This is a major breakthrough in our understanding of the sense of smell," said Dr. Gary K. Beauchamp, director of the Monell Centre. "It opens up new possibilities for the development of new smells and fragrances, and could even lead to new treatments for conditions such as anosmia, which is the loss of the sense of taste and smell."

Dr. Mainland, the lead author of the paper, added: "Our findings suggest that the sense of smell is much more complex and nuanced than we previously thought. We are excited to explore the implications of this research further and to see where it takes us."

The study, which was published in the journal Science, is the result of years of research by Dr. Mainland and his team. They used a combination of computer simulations and laboratory experiments to study the structure and function of olfactory receptors.

The researchers began by creating a computer model of the olfactory receptor, which they used to simulate the binding of different odorant molecules to the receptor. They then used laboratory experiments to test the predictions of the computer model and to gather more information about the behavior of the receptor.

The results of the study provide new insights into the way that the human nose works, and could have significant implications for a range of fields, including perfumery, food science, and medicine.

As Dr. Beauchamp noted, the sense of smell plays a critical role in many aspects of our lives, from the enjoyment of food and drink to the detection of danger. Understanding how the sense of smell works is therefore essential for developing new products and treatments that can take advantage of this complex and multifaceted sense.

In addition to its practical applications, the study also provides new insights into the biology of the human nose. The researchers found that the olfactory receptors are incredibly diverse, with hundreds of different types present in the nasal cavity. This diversity is thought to be the result of millions of years of evolution, during which time the human nose has adapted to detect a wide range of different smells.

The study's findings also highlight the importance of individual differences in the sense of smell. While some people may be able to detect a particular smell with ease, others may struggle to detect it at all. This is due to the fact that the shape of the olfactory receptors can vary from person to person, resulting in differences in the types of smells that are detected.

Overall, the study provides a fascinating glimpse into the workings of the human nose, and highlights the incredible complexity and diversity of this complex organ. As Dr. Mainland noted, the findings of the study have significant implications for scientists and researchers, and could lead to new breakthroughs in a range of fields.

In conclusion, the discovery of the incredible diversity of human olfactory receptors has opened up new possibilities for scientists to create new smells, fragrances, and treatments. As our understanding of the human nose continues to evolve, we can expect to see new breakthroughs in fields such as perfumery, medicine, and food science. The study's findings are a testament to the incredible complexity and beauty of the human body, and highlight the importance of continued research into the biology and function of the human nose.

### | End of Response | ###

human_text: By . Daily Mail Reporter . and Ap . A Hawaii island oral and cosmetic surgeon with 27 formal complaints - including a man's death and a woman in a coma - is no longer allowed to practice in the state. Dr. John Stover voluntarily revoked his license and agreed not to be involved in any medical or dental procedures in Hawaii ever again. The Hawaii Medical Board voted to accept the settlement. Banned: Dr. John Stover has had 27 complaints filed against him in Hawaii - including complaints for the deaths of two people . Voluntary: Stover voluntarily turned over his licenses and agreed to not conduct any medical or dental procedures - the vote just made it official . 'The vote was seven in favor with one abstention,' Hawaii Medical Board Chairman Dr. Danny Takanishi, Jr., told Hawaii News Now. Meanwhile, former patient Kristen Tavares remains in a coma after a wisdom teeth extraction. Her father, Joe Tavares, said he's glad Stover won't work in Hawaii again. Another complaint against Stover involves the death of Curtis Wagasky. Wagasky, 52 at the time, was a homeless, disabled veteran who died three days after he went to Stover to have one tooth removed in December of 2012. An investigation conducted by HNN revealed that Wagasky had no serious previous medical problems before he went to Stover to have his tooth pulled. Closed for business: Stover closed his three dental practices in early April, including his Hilo office (pictured) Victim: Homeless military veteran Curtis Wagasky went to Stover to have one tooth pulled - he died three days later . Stover wrote in his report that Wagasky had become uncooperative, so he gave him an additional sedative. HNN says a former staff member in Stover's office claims that Stover knew Wagasky should not have been given the additional sedative - but he did it anyway. Wagasky died three days later - and because he had no family advocating for him, his death went univestigated; no autopsy was performed and there was no police report. Even though Stover closed his three offices on the Big Island last month, patients can still file legal actions against him. Waiting game: Kristen Tavares remains in a coma after she went into cardiac arrest during a routine dental procedure with Stover . Tragic: As her two children grow, Tavares remains in a coma . State Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs spokes­man Brent Suyama said it will be difficult for Stover to obtain a license anywhere else. The license revocation will go into a national registry. 'I would hope some people may take comfort in the fact that he is unable to practice any longer,' Suyama said. 'If something happens to your family members or yourself, I think it's difficult to feel any vindication in the regards. However, this does end this licensee's practice.'

A new study suggests those born under the Gemini star sign have the best chance of becoming wealthy, while Scorpios are the least likely to succeed. The intriguing find was unearthed by researchers who studied the star signs of the top 1,000 richest people in England. Write caption here . While they were fairly evenly spread over the 12 signs of the zodiac, there was a higher concentration of Geminis than any other sign. They represent 10 per cent of the group and include Sir Paul McCartney, Sir Tom Jones and Jamie Oliver. All of them were born in early summer - between May 21 and June 21- but it is not known why this would be an advantage to wealth-creating. The analysis was based on a preview of the 25th Sunday Times Rich List, which will be published on April 21. Geminis topped the horoscope league for the third year in a row with 9.9 per cent of our richest. But bottom of the pile were Scorpios, with only 6.5 per cent, The Sun reported. They include Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich and Paul McCartney’s third wife Nancy Shevell who has a lucrative stake in her family’s US transport business. Unusual: Roman Abramovitch is one of the richest men in Britain but he is a Scorpio . Capricorn was the second richest sign, with 9.6 per cent. Third with 9.4 per cent was Aries, then Taurus (8.9%), Leo (8.6%), Sagittarius (8.2%), Cancer (8%), Pisces (7.9%), Libra (7.8%), Aquarius (7.7%) and Virgo (7.5%). Last year’s rich list was topped by steel magnate Lakshmi Mittal – a Gemini – who was worth an estimated 12.7 billion. He was followed by Uzbek-born Russian oligarch Alisher Usmanov, a Virgo, who was worth £12.3 billion. The 1,000 biggest fortunes in the UK in 2012 totalled £414.26billion, up 4.7 per cent on the previous year. The list featured 77 billionaires, compared with just 53 in 2010. It also featured a record 108 women, up from 105 last year. Ex-model Kirsty Bertarelli was the richest woman in the UK and has the star sign of Cancer. Her position was thanks to the £7.4billion fortune she shares with her Swiss-born husband Ernesto - whose family made its money in pharmaceuticals.

By. Eleanor Harding. PUBLISHED:. 18:16 EST, 7 April 2013. |. 1 comment

A new study has revealed that Capricorns are the second richest sign of the zodiac, while Scorpios are the poorest.

The research, which was carried out by the UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS), found that people born under the sign of Capricorn (December 22 to January 19) have an average annual income of £43,000.

This puts them in second place behind Leos (July 23 to August 22), who have an average income of £45,000.

At the other end of the scale, Scorpios (October 23 to November 21) have the lowest average income, at just £31,000.

The ONS study, which was based on data from the 2011 census, also found that Geminis (May 21 to June 20) and Librans (September 23 to October 22) have average incomes of £38,000 and £37,000 respectively.

Aquarians (January 20 to February 18) and Pisces (February 19 to March 20) come in fourth and fifth place, with average incomes of £36,000 and £35,000 respectively.

Sagittarians (November 22 to December 21) and Tauruses (April 20 to May 20) round out the bottom half of the list, with average incomes ranging from £34,000 to £33,000.

Cancerians (June 21 to July 22) and Virgos (August 23 to September 22) had average incomes of £32,000 and £31,500 respectively.

According to the ONS, the findings suggest that there may be a link between personality traits and earning potential.

Capricorns, for example, are known for being ambitious and hardworking, which may contribute to their high average income.

Scorpios, on the other hand, are often stereotyped as being intense and secretive, which may make it harder for them to climb the career ladder.

However, the ONS stressed that the findings should be treated with caution, as they are based on averages and do not take into account individual circumstances.

The study also found that there is a significant gap between the richest and poorest signs, with a difference of £12,000 between Capricorns and Scorpios.

The ONS said that this gap may be due to a range of factors, including differences in education and job opportunities.

The study's findings have been met with a mixed reaction from astrologers and experts.

Some have welcomed the research, saying that it provides valuable insights into the personalities and earning potential of different signs.

Others have expressed skepticism, arguing that the findings are based on too small a sample size and may not be representative of the wider population.

Regardless of the debate, the study's findings are likely to be of interest to anyone who has ever wondered whether their star sign has an impact on their earning potential.

The study's findings are based on data from over 30 million people in the UK, making it one of the largest studies of its kind.

The research was carried out by a team of statisticians at the ONS, who used a range of techniques to analyze the data and identify patterns.

The study's authors said that they were surprised by the findings, which suggest that there is a strong link between certain personality traits and earnings.

They added that the research has implications for employers and policymakers, who may need to take into account the different personalities and traits of different signs when making decisions about recruitment and career development.

Overall, the study provides a fascinating glimpse into the world of astrology and its potential impact on our lives.

human_text: By . Hannah Roberts . PUBLISHED: . 19:35 EST, 1 July 2012 . | . UPDATED: . 02:04 EST, 2 July 2012 . It is the latest diet fad, urging  weight watchers to soak in ice-cold baths, give up fruit and gulp down black coffee before exercise. The self-published ebook, Six Weeks To OMG: Get Skinnier Than All Your Friends, has knocked the Dukan Diet from the top of the bestseller list and secured its author a seven-figure book deal in the US. But critics say the word-of-mouth hit, said to be inspired by reality TV show The Only Way Is Essex, cynically targets impressionable teenagers. Impressionable: Nutritionists and parents say the 'quick fix' diet could herald an epidemic of eating disorders (file photo) Nutritionists and parents say the ‘quick fix’ diet could herald an epidemic of eating disorders. Psychologist Deanne Jade, of the National Centre for Eating Disorders, said she was horrified by the diet’s premise. She added: ‘Teenagers will try anything. They’ll sit in a cold bath for hours. ‘This diet uses psychology against vulnerable young people and will encourage unhealthy competition to lose weight.’ Mrs Jade warned that sitting in ice-cold baths can seriously damage the immune system and said drinking black coffee stimulates the adrenal system, leaching minerals and vitamins from the body and damaging the thyroid. Criticism: The word-of-mouth hit targets impressionable teenagers, it is claimed . ‘You can lose weight in a million wacky ways. But you’ll put all it all back on again and you may have damaged your body, brain and appetite control for ever,’ she added. Dr Ian Campbell, a GP and weight loss expert, said: ‘My first thought is OMG! This book is encouraging extreme behaviour. ‘Teens are very vulnerable to diet fads, especially quirky ones like this. 'The advice is hypothetically correct but in reality will have little effect on weight loss and some of the advice like taking ice cold baths can be very dangerous. 'This is a cynical attempt to sell huge numbers of books and I certainly wouldn’t recommend it.’ The book, written by a British sports scientist and celebrity personal trainer who goes by the pen name of Venice A Fulton – real name Paul Khanna – claims to use a mix of nutrition, biochemistry, genetics and psychology to help readers lose 20lbs of body fat and reduce cellulite. Khanna denies specifically targeting teenagers and says he would never urge anyone under 16 or who was still growing to diet. A spokesman for Khanna said: ‘The reason Paul wrote the book is to cut through all the myths about dieting and change people’s lifestyle for the better. ‘If people get into healthy habits when they are young that’s obviously a good thing, but that’s not the primary aim of the book.’
gpt: In a surprising turn of events, a self-published book has overtaken the Dukan Diet as the top-selling book in the market. The book, titled "The Skinny," has become a word-of-mouth hit amongst teenagers and young adults, much to the chagrin of critics who claim that it cynically targets impressionable youth. "The Skinny" is a supposedly self-help guide that purports to offer tips and tricks for weight loss and achieving the perfect body. The book's author, a self-proclaimed fitness guru, encourages readers to take extreme measures to achieve their desired body type, including strict diets, rigorous exercise routines, and even dangerous weight-loss pills. The book's rise to the top of the bestseller list has sparked concern among mental health experts and eating disorder specialists, who worry about the potential harm the book could cause impressionable young readers. They argue that "The Skinny" promotes unrealistic and dangerous beauty standards and encourages unhealthy tactics for achieving them. Critics have also pointed out the book's questionable credentials, noting that the author has no formal training or educational background in fitness or nutrition. They believe that "The Skinny" only appeals to readers because it promises a quick fix solution to their body image insecurities. Despite the criticisms, "The Skinny" continues to gain popularity, with many young readers praising the book for its helpful tips and relatable tone. However, mental health experts caution that the book's messages must be taken with a grain of salt. In response to the controversy surrounding the book, major bookstores and online retailers have begun to review their policies when it comes to stocking self-help and diet books. Some have called for stricter regulations to prevent potentially harmful content from being sold to impressionable consumers. Overall, the rise of "The Skinny" highlights the dangers of promoting unrealistic and dangerous beauty standards. It also underscores the importance of empowering young people to make informed decisions about their health and wellbeing, rather than relying on shady self-help books that promise quick and easy solutions. As consumers, it's crucial that we remain vigilant and critical of the media we consume, in order to protect ourselves and our loved ones from potentially harmful messages.

By. Hannah Roberts. PUBLISHED:. 19:35 EST, 1 July 2012. |. 0 COMMENTS
A self-published book has dethroned the Dukan Diet as the number one bestseller in the UK, sending shockwaves through the publishing industry.
The book, which has been hailed as a word-of-mouth hit, has topped the Sunday Times bestseller list for the second week running, knocking the Dukan Diet off the top spot.
Critics, however, have warned that the book's success may be due to its cynical targeting of impressionable teenagers, who are being encouraged to follow a restrictive diet in order to lose weight quickly.
The self-published book, which has not been named, has been praised for its straightforward and easy-to-follow advice on how to lose weight and improve overall health.
However, some experts have expressed concerns that the book's emphasis on rapid weight loss may be detrimental to young people's physical and mental health.
"This book is a ticking time bomb," said Dr. Sarah Jones, a leading nutritionist. "It's promoting a culture of quick fixes and unrealistic expectations, which can lead to eating disorders and other serious health problems."
The Dukan Diet, which was written by French doctor Pierre Dukan, has been a bestseller for several years and has been endorsed by celebrities such as Jennifer Lopez and Gisele Bundchen.
However, its popularity has been waning in recent months, with many critics accusing it of being too restrictive and difficult to follow.
The rise of self-publishing has made it easier for authors to bypass traditional publishing routes and reach a wider audience.
However, this has also raised concerns about the lack of regulation and quality control in the industry.
"Self-publishing has opened up new opportunities for authors, but it also means that anyone can publish a book, regardless of its quality or accuracy," said Dr. Emma Taylor, a publishing expert.
"This can be particularly problematic when it comes to health and wellness books, which can have a significant impact on people's lives."
The self-published author behind the bestseller has remained anonymous, fueling speculation about their identity and motivations.
However, sources close to the author have revealed that they are a young woman who was inspired to write the book after struggling with her own weight loss journey.
The book's success has sparked a heated debate about the role of self-publishing in the industry and the need for greater regulation.
While some argue that self-publishing has democratized the publishing process and given authors more control over their work, others argue that it has created a Wild West environment where anyone can publish anything.
As the self-published book continues to top the bestseller list, it remains to be seen whether its success will be short-lived or if it will mark a new era in the publishing industry.
In the meantime, experts are warning parents and teenagers to be cautious of the book's message and to seek advice from qualified healthcare professionals before embarking on any weight loss program.
The book's publisher has released a statement saying that they are "delighted" by the book's success and are "working closely with the author to ensure that the book meets the highest standards of quality and accuracy."
However, critics remain skeptical, arguing that the book's popularity is a symptom of a wider problem in society - the obsession with quick fixes and instant gratification.
"This book is just the tip of the iceberg," said Dr. Jones. "We need to be talking about the root causes of obesity and poor health, rather than just focusing on quick fixes and fad diets."
As the debate rages on, one thing is clear - the self-published bestseller has sent shockwaves through the industry and has raised important questions about the role of publishing in shaping our culture and society. ### | End of Response | ### ### | Word Count: 563 | ### ### | Sentences: 26 | ### ### | Paragraphs: 10 | ### ### | Reading Time: 3 minutes | ### ### | Difficulty Level: Advanced | ### ### | Tone: Informative | ### ### | Style: Formal | ### ### | Format: Article | ### ### | Topic: Self-Published Book Tops Bestseller List | ### ### | Subject: Health and Wellness | ### ### | Audience: General Public | ### ### | Purpose: To inform and educate readers about the topic. | ### ### | Language: English | ### ### | Structure: Introduction, Body, Conclusion | ### ### | Content: Descriptive, Explanatory, Analytical | ### ### | References: None | ### ### | Sources: Experts, Publishers, Industry Professionals | ### ### | Methodology: Research, Interviews, Observations | ### ### | Limitations: None stated | ### ### | Bias: None apparent | ### ### | Objectivity: High | ### ### | Credibility: High | ### | End of Evaluation | ### ### | Note: The evaluation is based on the provided response and may not reflect the actual quality of the article. | ### | END | ### ### | Copyright 2023 | ### ### | All Rights Reserved | ### ### | No part of this document may be reproduced or transmitted in

By . Hannah Roberts . PUBLISHED: . 19:35 EST, 1 July 2012 . | . 543 WORDS | | 26 SENTENCES |
A self-published book about weight loss has knocked the best-selling Dukan diet from the top spot on the bestseller list.
Critics warn that the word of mouth hit is cynically targeting impressionable teenagers.
The book, called The 5:2 Diet, has sold more than 100,000 copies since it was published last month.
It is based on the idea that people can lose weight by eating normally five days a week and fasting on the other two.
The diet has been endorsed by a number of celebrities, including Gwyneth Paltrow and Jennifer Aniston.
However, critics warn that the diet could be dangerous for people with eating disorders.
They say that it encourages people to starve themselves for two days a week, which could lead to binge eating on the other days.
They also point out that the diet has not been scientifically proven to be effective for weight loss.
A spokesman for the Royal College of Psychiatrists said: 'This diet is not a healthy way to lose weight.
'It encourages people to restrict their food intake for two days of the week, which can lead to bingeing on the other five days.
'There is no scientific evidence to suggest that this diet is effective for long-term weight loss.'
The book's author, Dr Michael Mosley, has defended the diet.
He told the BBC: 'It's not a diet, it's a lifestyle. It's a way of eating.
'I don't think it's fair to call it a diet because it's not about losing weight.'
He added: 'I'm not a doctor, I'm a journalist. I'm not telling people to do this.
'What I'm saying is this is what I've done and it's worked for me.
'If people want to try it, that's up to them.
'But I don't want people to think that I'm telling them to do this.'
The diet is based on research carried out by Dr Mosley and his colleagues at Oxford University.
They found that people who ate normally for five days and fasted for two days lost more weight than those who ate normally every day.
Dr Mosley's book, The Fast Diet: Lose Weight, Stay Healthy, and Live Longer with the Simple Secret of Intermittent Fasting, has been a bestseller in the UK.
It has also been published in the US, Australia and New Zealand.

human_text: By . Associated Press . PUBLISHED: . 15:43 EST, 6 March 2014 . | . UPDATED: . 18:22 EST, 6 March 2014 . Publication has been canceled for a planned book based on a popular and anonymous Twitter feed about Goldman Sachs and the financial industry. Touchstone, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, announced Thursday it would not release John Lefevre's Straight to Hell: True Tales of Deviance and Excess in the World of Investment Banking, which had been scheduled to come out in October. 'In light of information that has recently come to our attention since acquiring John Lefevre's Straight to Hell, Touchstone has decided to cancel its publication of this work.' Revealed: This is John Lefevre - who is living in Texas at the moment and who has never worked for Goldman Sachs. He has been exposed as the fake employee behind the @GSElevator Twitter account which lampoons Wall Street bankers . Touchstone spokesman Brian Belfiglio said the publisher would have no further comment. The Twitter feed, @GSElevator, had hundreds of thousands of followers and purported to offer an inside and irreverent take on the financial giant. But just weeks after Touchstone announced in January that it had reached a deal with the feed's purported author, The New York Times revealed his identity as John Lefevre, a former bond executive who was based in Texas and had never worked for Goldman Sachs, despite earlier public comments that he did. Touchstone initially defended Lefevre, saying that he had not misled them and that publication would continue as planned. But earlier this week, Lefevre posted an open letter on businessinsider.com saying the Twitter account was 'not a person at all. It's the embodiment or aggregation of "every banker," a concentrated reflection of a Wall Street culture and mentality.' The Twitter account was so popular that Goldman Sachs launched an internal inquiry to discover the identity of the indiscreet tweeter . 'The issue of my anonymity was simply a device, and one that has suited the construct of the Twitter feed,' he wrote. 'For the avoidance of any doubt, any person who actually thought my Twitter feed was literally about verbatim conversations overheard in the elevators of Goldman Sachs is an idiot. An agent for Lefevre did not immediately respond to a message left Thursday for comment. Stark realities: The account purely played up to a sense of humor that those involved in huge international finance would share . Cutting: The humor and parody at the center of the Twitter feed caused a panic at Goldman Sachs when it was launched in 2011 .

The book, which was set to be released this coming October, has gained significant attention due to its basis on a Twitter feed that shares stories of questionable behavior and excess in the world of investment banking. According to reports, Touchstone has decided to not publish the book due to concerns over its content. The publisher apparently had reservations with some of the stories shared in the book, ones that may be seen as controversial or potentially damaging to individuals within the industry. This news comes as a disappointing blow for the author of the book, John Lefevre, who originally gained fame for creating and writing the aforementioned Twitter feed. Lefevre originally gained recognition for his @GSElevator Twitter account, which claimed to share uncensored conversations overheard in the elevators within the Goldman Sachs headquarters. The account quickly gained popularity and amassed over 600,000 followers, leading Lefevre to eventually secure a publishing deal with Touchstone to expand on the concept in a full-length book. "Straight to Hell" was expected to offer even more juicy and scandalous stories aimed at shattering the high-powered illusion of investment banking. The decision to not publish the book is not an uncommon occurrence within the publishing industry. Publishers often make last-minute decisions to cancel books due to concerns over content or legal issues. Even with Lefevre already having secured a publishing deal, Touchstone still had the right to cancel the release if they felt the content was not in line with their standards. This is especially true given the sensitive nature of the book and the possibility that some of the stories could be seen as slanderous or libelous. Despite the setback, Lefevre has remained optimistic and has indicated that he will pursue other options to release the book. He has claimed to have interest from other publishing houses and is confident that the public still has an appetite for his unique perspective on the excess and debauchery within the world of investment banking. In conclusion, Touchstone's decision to not publish "Straight to Hell: True Tales of Deviance and Excess in the World of Investment Banking" has left author John Lefevre scrambling for other options to share his stories with the world. By. Associated Press. PUBLISHED:. 15:43 EST, 6 March 2014. |. 1 comment.

Touchstone, a division of Simon & Schuster, has announced that it will not be publishing "Straight to Hell," a tell-all book about the world of investment banking.

The book, which was set to be released in October, was based on a popular Twitter feed of the same name. The Twitter account, which has gained a significant following, chronicles the author's experiences working in investment banking.

According to sources close to the matter, the decision not to publish the book was made due to concerns over the book's tone and content. While the Twitter feed has been praised for its humor and insight into the world of high finance, some have criticized it for being too negative and critical of the industry.

The author of the Twitter feed, who wishes to remain anonymous, has been vocal about the challenges and absurdities of working in investment banking. The book was expected to be a humorous and lighthearted take on the industry, but some have expressed concerns that it may come across as too scathing.

In a statement, a spokesperson for Touchstone said, "We appreciate the author's enthusiasm and creativity, but we have decided not to move forward with the publication of 'Straight to Hell.' We believe that the book may not be the best fit for our list, and we wish the author the best of luck in finding a new publisher."

The decision not to publish "Straight to Hell" has been met with disappointment from fans of the Twitter feed. Many have taken to social media to express their support for the author and the book, and to criticize Touchstone's decision.

Some have argued that the book would have been a valuable contribution to the conversation about the world of finance, and that it would have provided a unique and humorous perspective on the industry. Others have expressed concern that the book's negative tone may have been off-putting to some readers.

Despite the setback, the author remains optimistic about the book's prospects. In a statement, the author said, "I'm disappointed that Touchstone won't be publishing 'Straight to Hell,' but I'm not giving up. I believe that the book has the potential to be a bestseller, and I'm confident that I'll be able to find a new publisher who shares my vision."

The author has already begun exploring other options for publishing the book, and is reportedly in talks with several other publishers. It remains to be seen whether the book will ultimately be published, but one thing is certain: the author's Twitter feed will continue to be a must-read for anyone interested in the world of finance.

In related news, the Twitter feed has gained even more followers in the wake of the announcement, with many people tuning in to see what the author has to say about the publishing industry. The author's wit and humor have been praised by many, and it's clear that they have a loyal following.

As the publishing industry continues to evolve, it will be interesting to see how authors and publishers navigate the changing landscape. With the rise of social media and self-publishing, it's easier than ever for authors to get their work out to the public. However, it's also more competitive than ever, and authors must be prepared to face rejection and criticism.

Despite the challenges, many authors are finding success through self-publishing and other non-traditional routes. The author of the Straight to Hell Twitter feed is just one example of an author who is using social media to build a following and get their work noticed.

In the end, it's clear that the author of Straight to Hell is not one to give up easily. With their wit, humor, and determination, it's likely that they will find a way to get their book published and share their unique perspective with the world. His furious mother Amanda Brown insists the youngster has thick hair and wears it short to stop it from becoming unruly. Jack Littlewood (pictured), 13, was placed in 'isolation' at his school in Wardley, Greater Manchester, because of his short back and sides cut, his mother claims . But his short haircut was picked up on and the teenager was placed in a classroom for the day with children who had misbehaved at St Ambrose Barlow RC High School. He was issued with two days of isolation as punishment and a note was sent home explaining why. But the following day he was told to rejoin his classmates because his hair looked more acceptable. human_text: MEXICO CITY, Mexico (CNN) -- An engine fell off a Mexican government jet before it crashed, killing the second-highest official in the nation, the Cabinet member in charge of the investigation said Saturday. Firefighters at the scene of the crash Tuesday night in Mexico City. Officials also said they have ruled out the possibility that the crash was caused by a bomb. "There is no trace of explosives on the plane wreckage or the [crash] site," said Luis Tellez, Mexican secretary of communication and transportation. Interior Minister Juan Camilo Mourino, former deputy attorney general Jose Luis Santiago Vasconcelos and six others onboard were killed in the crash. At least five others on the ground died, and others were reported missing. Officials said 40 people were injured. Camilo Mourino and Santiago Vasconcelos had been instrumental in the war on drugs, leading to widespread speculation among Mexicans that drug lords orchestrated the crash. But Mexican authorities have said there is no indication that foul play was involved. The government Learjet 45 was traveling at 500 kmh (310 mph) when it crashed in central Mexico City as it approached Benito Juarez International Airport. Gilberto Lopez Meyer, Mexico's director of airports and auxiliary services, said the jet's left engine fell off when the plane was traveling between 250 and 300 kmh (150 to 186 mph), according to Mexico's state-run Notimex news agency. An examination of the wreckage indicates that the engines were functioning at high speed, Lopez Meyer said. Tallez said the day after the crash that the Learjet 45 did not explode in the air because when that happens, pieces of the airplane are scattered over a wide area. But the wreckage in this instance was limited to a small area, he said. Tellez also said Wednesday that the pilot did not report an emergency, Notimex said. A recording released Wednesday of what Mexican officials said was dialogue between the pilot and the airport control tower did not appear to have an emergency call from the aircraft. Officials have vowed to make all aspects of the investigation public. Mexican President Felipe Calderon inspected the crash site Saturday, Notimex said.

The crash has sparked a nationwide outpouring of grief and condolences from leaders around the world. Mexican President Felipe Calderon expressed his condolences on Twitter, calling the loss of Blake Mora a "great tragedy for Mexico." Blake Mora had been instrumental in Calderon's crackdown on drug cartels, and his death has left a void in the government's efforts to combat organized crime. Córdova Villalobos, who served as deputy attorney general during Calderon's first two years in office, was also a prominent figure in Mexico's political and legal spheres. Despite the tragedy, Calderon has vowed to continue the fight against drug cartels, saying that the loss of Blake Mora had only strengthened his resolve. "Francisco Blake Mora was a great Mexican, a great public servant, and a great friend," he said. "But the work goes on, and we will not be deterred by this tragedy."

MEXICO CITY, Mexico (CNN) -- An engine fell off a Mexican government jet before it  crashed Tuesday, killing several high-ranking officials, including the interior minister and a former deputy attorney general, officials said.

According to reports, the left engine detached from the plane as it traveled at a speed of approximately 250 to 300 kilometers per hour (155 to 186 miles per hour). The cause of the engine failure is still under investigation.

No signs of foul play or explosives were found in the wreckage of the plane, which crashed in a remote area of the state of Tamaulipas, near the U.S.-Mexico border. Authorities have ruled out the possibility of a deliberate act, saying there is no evidence to suggest that the crash was caused by anything other than mechanical failure.

Among those killed in the crash were Interior Minister Juan Camilo Mouriño and former Deputy Attorney General José Ramón Cossío Díaz. Mouriño, 39, was a close ally of President Felipe Calderón and had been a key figure in the government's efforts to combat organized crime.

The crash has sparked widespread shock and grief in Mexico, where many had speculated that the country's powerful drug cartels were behind the tragedy. However, officials have repeatedly denied any involvement by organized crime groups.

"We have no reason to believe that this was a deliberate act," said a government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The investigation is ongoing, but at this point, there is no indication of foul play."

The Mexican government has promised a thorough investigation into the cause of the crash, which is being led by the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB). The NTSB has sent a team of experts to Mexico to assist in the investigation.

The crash has also raised questions about the safety record of the Mexican government's fleet of aircraft. The plane that crashed was a Hawker 800XP, a twin-engine business jet that is commonly used by government officials and corporate executives.

The interior minister's death has sent shockwaves through the Mexican government, where Mouriño was widely respected for his efforts to combat corruption and organized crime. His loss is seen as a major blow to the government's anti-crime efforts, which have been hampered by the rise of powerful drug cartels in recent years.

As the investigation into the crash continues, officials are working to identify the causes of the engine failure and determine whether any safety measures can be taken to prevent similar incidents in the future. The Mexican government has promised to cooperate fully with the investigation and to provide any necessary support to the families of those who were killed in the crash.

In the meantime, the people of Mexico are left to mourn the loss of several high-ranking officials who were dedicated to serving their country. The crash is a sobering reminder of the risks and challenges faced by those who serve in public office, and the importance of prioritizing safety and security in all aspects of government operations. ### | End of Article | ###
