MEXICO CITY, Mexico (CNN) -- An engine fell off a Mexican government jet before it "exploded" in mid-air Tuesday, killing all 103 people on board, the country's interior minister said.
Interior Minister Miguel Angel Osorio Chong said there were no signs of explosives in the wreckage of the plane, which was traveling from the capital, Mexico City, to the northern city of Monterrey when it went down.
"There are no traces of explosives," Osorio Chong told reporters. "There is no indication of foul play."
He said the plane's two pilots and 101 passengers were killed in the crash, which occurred about 60 kilometers (37 miles) south of the city of Toluca, in the state of Hidalgo.
Osorio Chong said the cause of the crash was under investigation.
The plane, a Boeing 737, was operated by the state-owned airline, Aeromexico, and was carrying 99 passengers and four crew members, the airline said in a statement.
Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto said he was "deeply saddened" by the crash and offered his condolences to the families of the victims.
"We will do everything in our power to find out the cause of this accident," he said. "We will not rest until we know the truth."
Pena Nieto's office said the president was traveling to the site of the crash and would meet with the families of those who died in the crash.
The president's plane landed at Toluca's airport, where he was greeted by Osorio Chong and other officials, according to a video posted on the president's official Twitter account.
"I am deeply saddened by the news of the crash of the Aeromexico plane," the president said in the video. "I want to express my deepest condolences to the relatives of the victims."
The president said he would travel to the crash site "as soon as possible" to meet with the victims' families.
Aeromexico said the plane took off from Mexico City's Benito Juarez International Airport at 8:20 a.m. (12:20 p.m. ET) and was scheduled to arrive in Monterrey at 9:30 a.m., according to the airline's website.
The airline said the plane was scheduled to return to Mexico City at 12:30 p.m., but it did not arrive at the airport.
The company said it was working with authorities to determine what happened to the plane.
"Our thoughts and prayers are with the families and loved ones of the passengers and crew on board," the airline said.
The Transportation Safety Board of Canada said it was sending a team of investigators to Mexico to assist in the probe.
The U.S. National Transportation Safety Board said it was also sending a team to Mexico.
The Federal Aviation Administration said it was aware of the incident and was in contact with Mexican authorities.
The FAA said it was "monitoring the situation and will provide additional information as it becomes available."

Justin Ireland was working the night shift at a gas station in Saco, Maine when a man wearing a hoodie and a face mask entered the store with a gun. human_text: By . Misty White Sidell . Vogue creative director Grace Coddington was temporarily banned from Instagram over the weekend for her first post on the platform - a self-portrait sketch of her bathing topless. Ms Coddington, 73, known by fashion fans for her starring role in the 2009 documentary The September Issue, joined Instagram on Friday and quickly accumulated a few thousand followers. But by the weekend, her account had gone dark – purportedly due to the sketch, which was created to promote online auctioneer Paddle 8’s ‘No Clothes’ charity auction. Locked down: Vogue magazine's creative director Grace Coddington (pictured) had her Instagram account briefly frozen after she posted a topless sketch of herself on Friday . Instagram, of course, has a strict no-nudity policy that has led to similar bans placed on accounts from Rihanna and model Anja Rubik. Today however, Ms Coddington’s account was restored. Instagram claims that its blocking of Ms Coddington’s account was an accident, and that the app’s personnel made a mistake while processing a complaint against the photo. A representative for Instagram told The Cut: ‘When our team processes reports from other members of the Instagram community, we occasionally make a mistake. ‘In this case, we wrongly removed content and worked to rectify the error as soon as we were notified. We apologize for any inconvenience.’ In the brief time that her Instagram was dark shut down, at least one member of fashion’s elite shared an Instagram post to show their support for her. Offending content: This sketch, drawn by Ms Coddington to promote a Paddle 8 charity auction, is what caused her account to be frozen . W magazine fashion director Edward Enninful posted a photo of the cover for Ms Coddington’s first book, Grace, writing: ‘Grace Coddington's Instagram is no longer active because of her 1st post, the nude self portrait!!!!!! Grace will be back soon with a new account xoxo Stay posted! #gracecoddington #legend’ Now with her account back in working order, Ms Coddington has posted a new sketch to address her profile’s shut down. Hitting back: After her account was restored, Ms Coddington uploaded this sketch in which her famous cats are facetiously blacked out . Earlier today she posted one of her famous cat sketches with a black bar facetiously drawn over one of the feline’s lower halves. Its cheeky caption read: ‘Good grief Pumpkin, Mother drew a nude selfie for her very first Instagram. No wonder they shut her down......she is much fatter than that.’

(CNN) -- This month, Inside the Middle East aims for Olympic gold, exploring stories of
human_text: (CNN) -- This month, Inside the Middle East aims for Olympic gold, exploring stories of adversity, faith, and triumph in the world of Middle Eastern sports. In the United Arab Emirates, Inside the Middle East meets Khadija Mohammed, the second woman in the history of her country to head to the Games. The young weightlifter is excited, but wrestling with a challenge of balancing the athletic performance with her faith. Like many Muslim Olympians, Khadija will be fasting for the holy month of Ramadan, which starts one week before the Games. More: Saudi women slam dunk sports taboo . We also head to Jerusalem, where Maher Abu Rmeileh is also preparing for his journey to the Olympic Games in London. Abu Rmeileh has the honor of being the first Palestinian to qualify for the Olympics on merit. The 28-year-old judoka explains why winning a gold medal would mean everything to him -- and his father. The program also heads to the shores of Oman, a nation pinning its future chances for Olympic glory on one small group of female sailing instructors. More: Qatar's first female Olympians on target to make history . Just outside the capital, Muscat, twenty-one women are teaching Omani children how to sail, and helping to revive their country's rich maritime heritage. The ladies are also inspiring other women to join the workforce in Oman, a conservative nation where females were not allowed to work outside the home until the mid-1990s. More: Saudi female Olympians: Historic breakthrough or false dawn? Finally, in Amman, Jordan, Inside the Middle East meets the women of Jordan's national boxing team, the first female boxers in the Middle East. They might not be heading to the Olympic Games, but Jordan's female boxers are challenging gender stereotypes in a region where many perceive women as the weaker sex. Watch the August show at the following times: . Wednesday, August 1: 0930, 1630 . Saturday, August 4: 0430, 1830 . Sunday, August 5: 1130 . Saturday, August 11: 1130 . Sunday, August 12: 0430, 1830 . (all times GMT)

"I have always loved sports ever since I was a kid. I used to run and play games with my friends. But it was not until I found my faith that I decided to take it up as a career," she shared. Despite facing a number of challenges in her journey so far, Mohammed credits her faith for keeping her going. She believes that her spiritual strength has helped her overcome the hurdles and push beyond her limits. "I pray before every race and I ask Allah to guide me and give me strength. I believe that everything is in His hands, and with His help, I can achieve anything," she said. But Khadija Mohammed isn't the only athlete from the Middle East with a story of triumph. Meet Abu Rmeileh, the first Palestinian to qualify for the Olympics on merit. Rmeileh has been making waves in the world of sports and is an inspiration to many in the region. For him, winning at the Olympics would mean everything. "It's not just about me. It's about the Palestinian people, and what we have been through. We have faced so much adversity, and this is a chance to show the world what we are capable of," he shared in an interview with Inside the Middle East. These stories of adversity, faith, and triumph are what the Inside the Middle East series is all about. Through their exploration of the world of sports, they have brought to light the stories of athletes like Khadija Mohammed and Abu Rmeileh - stories that serve as a beacon of hope and inspiration to many in the region. As the world watches these athletes compete in the Olympics, may their stories continue to inspire and motivate us all.

human_text: William Buckman, 61, a nationally known figure, was found dead in a hotel room on Tuesday . The death of a prominent New Jersey defense and civil rights attorney who helped expose racial profiling by the State Police in the 1990s has been ruled a suicide. The body of William Buckman was found on Tuesday at the Residence Inn in Mount Laurel, New Jersey. His death was discovered around 8:45 a.m. said Mount Laurel Police Lt. Stephen Riedener reports NJ.com. He said officers had been asked to check on Buckman's well-being. 'The manner of death was suicide,' Riedener said. Riedener said the 61-year-old was found in his room and pronounced dead at the scene. He said no foul play was involved, and the investigation has been closed. Buckman, who was married with two children, rose to prominence while defending Pedro Soto of Gloucester County in a drug case. He successfully won a motion to suppress evidence seized during a State Police highway stop on the basis of racial profiling. The judge ruled that troopers routinely stopped minority motorists in New Jersey based on the their skin color. He found such stops to be illegal and threw out drug and weapons evidence against Soto and 16 others. Buckman famously said he was never stopped on the turnpike because troopers don't look for 'a short, chubby Jewish white person.' Buckman's body was found around 8:45 a.m. at the Residence Inn, said Mount Laurel Police Lt. Stephen Riedener. He said officers had been asked to check on Buckman's well-being . 'Bill was a true believer and a dedicated advocate for the principles of freedom, justice, and equality, and New Jersey is a better place because of the work he did,' said Edward Barocas, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey told Philly.com. 'He was a man with a great sense of humor, a great sense of empathy, and a great sense of justice,' Barocas said. 'He will be greatly missed.' Surinder Aggarwal, a former associate of Buckman's told Burlington County Times: 'He was a legal giant and a trendsetter.' 'The bar has really lost a giant.' Buckman was president of the William H. Buckman Law Firm in Moorestown and specialized in civil rights cases. His last tweet was on 13 October and read 'Attorney shuts down police stop of black handyman: ‘Now please leave our neighborhood’ with a link to news website. His family have not yet commented on his death.

The Wales midfielder helped eased the pressure on the Arsenal boss with a wonder goal — an outrageous left-footed strike from 30 yards — in the comfortable 4-1 win away to Galatasaray in Istanbul on Tuesday night. Wenger has been the target of heavy criticism from a section of supporters following the club’s disappointing start to the season in the Barclays Premier League. And Ramsey has defended his manager from the hurtful jibes from the stands. ‘Every player here wants to work hard for him, we have proven that again against Galatasaray,’ said Ramsey. ‘He has been under some unfair criticism, but we are all out there, are in it together. We wanted to get the result for us and for him. ‘I think whenever we go into a game, he knows our qualities, always believes in us and gives us a great feeling going into games. ‘Every time we go out there we are representing ourselves, our club and our manager.’ Ramsey, after an early-season blip, is now approaching the form that saw him win the club’s player of the year award last term. Ramsey (left) fires a long-range shot towards goal as Arsenal too Galatasaray apart . His super strike in Turkey was testament to that — and Ramsey has warned Arsenal’s rivals that he feels close to his best. ‘I have seen the goal back, and it is definitely the best I have scored,’ he said. ‘As soon as I hit it, I thought it had a chance of going in and thankfully it went into the top corner. ‘My best goal before this one? I am feeling good and hopefully now I can play my part as the team go on a run.’ Lukas Podolski also scored twice, having been linked with a January move away following a lack of first-team opportunities. The German forward told Arsenal’s website: ‘For me it was important to play 90 minutes and keep going. It is not always easy to come in and do well, so it was good for me to do that.’

Los Angeles, California (CNN) -- The parents of a California girl who was allegedly raped
human_text: Los Angeles, California (CNN) -- The parents of a California girl who was allegedly raped and killed by a registered sex offender are calling for tougher standards against repeat offenders. "How many times do our daughters need to be raped before we put these monsters behind bars forever?" said Kelly King, mother of 17-year-old Chelsea King, in an interview Thursday with CNN's "Larry King Live." "I just don't -- I don't get it. Change has to be made," she continued, "and I know that there are people out there that are trying to, you know, get this change in place." She said she and her husband, Brent King, "are committed for the rest of our lives to be a part of that." On Wednesday, John Albert Gardner III, 30, a registered sex offender, was charged in the rape and murder of Chelsea, who lived in the San Diego area. Gardner, who is being represented by a public defender, was also charged Wednesday with assault with intent to commit rape in an attack on a jogger in December 2009. He pleaded not guilty to all charges. Gardner, of Lake Elsinore, California, will not be allowed to post bail. If convicted, the charges against Gardner make him eligible for the death penalty, the San Diego County district attorney's office said Wednesday. The prosecutor's office said it has not determined whether it will seek capital punishment. For the Kings, there's no question. "I think the death penalty is a very appropriate punishment for this case," Kelly King. Brent King said he had "100 percent agreement" with his wife. Searchers found a body on Tuesday they believe to be that of Chelsea King. Police arrested Gardner on Sunday. King had been missing since February 25. Investigators said she was last seen at her school in Poway, about 15 miles north of San Diego. Her car, with her cell phone inside, was found at Rancho Bernardo Community Park. Searchers found remains in a shallow grave at that park; they were found along the shoreline of a tributary south of a lake, authorities said. The body was found in a heavily wooded area not visible from nearby homes. A shoe had been found earlier in the same area, the sheriff said. King's parents, noting she was a great student and avid runner, said she had gone for a run at the park before she disappeared. "It's a lovely area, very peaceful, very picturesque -- exactly what Chelsea ... loved to be in," Kelly King said. She said the couple's son, 13-year-old Tyler, was extremely close to his sister. "He's struggling through it just like us," Brent King added. Gardner's next court appearance, a status hearing, is scheduled for Tuesday. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for March 18.

Los Angeles, California (CNN) -- The parents of a California girl who was allegedly raped  and murdered by a registered sex offender made a heart-wrenching appearance on CNN's Larry King Live Tuesday night, calling for tougher laws against repeat sex offenders.

Elizabeth and Kurt King, the parents of 17-year-old Chelsea King, appeared on the show to discuss their daughter's tragic death and the alleged perpetrator, John Gardner, who has pleaded not guilty to the crimes.

Chelsea King, a high school student from Poway, California, went missing on February 25. Her body was found three days later in a shallow grave in a nearby lake. An autopsy revealed that she had been raped and murdered.

Gardner, a 30-year-old registered sex offender, was arrested and charged with Chelsea's rape and murder. He has a history of sex crimes, including a 2000 conviction for molesting a 13-year-old girl.

The King family's appearance on Larry King Live was their first public statement since Chelsea's death. Elizabeth King, Chelsea's mother, broke down in tears several times during the interview, but remained resolute in her determination to see justice served.

"We want to make sure that John Gardner pays for what he did to our daughter," Elizabeth King said, her voice shaking with emotion. "He's a monster, and he needs to be held accountable for his actions."

Kurt King, Chelsea's father, echoed his wife's sentiments, saying that the death penalty would be a "very appropriate punishment" for Gardner's crimes.

"We're not looking for revenge, but we are looking for justice," Kurt King said. "And if that means the death penalty, then so be it."

The Kings also expressed frustration with the current laws governing sex offenders, which they believe are too lenient. They called for tougher standards, including longer prison sentences and stricter monitoring of sex offenders after their release.

"We need to take a hard look at our laws and make sure that we're doing everything we can to protect our children," Elizabeth King said. "We can't just sit back and wait for something to happen. We need to take action."

Gardner's defense team has argued that he is innocent until proven guilty, and that the evidence against him is circumstantial. However, the prosecution has presented a wealth of evidence, including DNA evidence and eyewitness testimony, that links Gardner to the crime.

The case has sparked a national debate about sex offender laws and the need for tougher penalties. Many experts agree that the current system is flawed, and that more needs to be done to protect society from repeat offenders like Gardner.

"This case is a wake-up call for all of us," said Dr. Laura Finley, a criminologist at Barry University. "It highlights the need for stronger laws and more effective monitoring of sex offenders. We can't just rely on the current system to keep our communities safe."

The trial is expected to begin in the coming weeks, and the King family is bracing themselves for the long and difficult road ahead. But they remain determined to see justice served, and to make sure that Chelsea's memory lives on.

"We want to honor Chelsea's memory by making sure that no other family has to go through what we're going through," Kurt King said, his voice filled with emotion. "We want to make a difference, and we're going to do everything we can to make that happen."

As the King family continues to navigate the complexities of the justice system, they are finding solace in the outpouring of support from their community. A memorial fund has been set up in Chelsea's name, and a candlelight vigil was held in her honor last week.

The case has also sparked a national conversation about the need for tougher laws against sex offenders, and the importance of protecting our children from predators like Gardner.

In the end, the King family's message is clear: justice must be served, and Chelsea's memory must be honored. As they continue to fight for justice, they remain steadfast in their determination to make a difference and to keep their daughter's memory alive.  ### | End of Response | ###

Chelsea's alleged killer, John Albert Gardner III, 30, has pleaded not guilty to raping Chelsea and murdering her. He is being held without bail.

Kelly King added, "I just can't believe that someone could do something like this."

By . Sam Creighton . Christian monuments have been destroyed by the Chinese government in
human_text: By . Sam Creighton . Christian monuments have been destroyed by the Chinese government in a move that will fuel fears of a state sponsored crackdown on the religion. On Saturday, fifty officials blocked entry to Longgang Hill, in the city of Wenzhou - know as China's Jerusalem - a site of pilgrimage for the country's Christians. They used cranes to rip up statues and built walls around three others - depicting Jesus, the Virgin Mary and Saint Jospeh - which weigh up to five tonnes each. There were no clashes with worshipers, as government workmen kept a promise not to damage the three bricked-off statues. Four bulldozers started demolishing Sanjiang church in Wenzhou on Monday, after six weeks of protests . The torn up monuments are being stored at a church property in Hengdaiqiao, a Wenzhou suburb, but all other relgious decoration on the hilltop park was destroyed. The authorities are claiming the construction of the park was illegal but Christians say this is just a pretext to justify their persecution. Joseph, a Wnnzhou Catholic who declined to give his full name for security reasons, told UCA News: 'Even if the authorities determined that erecting religious articles on the site is against the law, they should allow us to appeal through legal means. This could help build the rule of law in society and stop corruption.' Another anonymous witness to the destruction said: 'About 100 Catholics who came to watch the removals were blocked at the entrance. Some who managed to sneak in sang hymns and prayed while watching. Some could not hold back their tears.' Two days later, bulldozers were sent in to demolish the city's Sanjiang Church, which was only completed last year at a cost of £2.84million. The church's destruction is the end of a six-week-long struggle which had seen thousands of Christians camped outside the building in a bit to save it. UCA News also reported that last week, state officals beat up four Christians who were trying to prevent the demolition of a four-storey building, owned by a Catholic laymen. The authorities claimed that the building's top two floors had been built illegally and that it was being used as a site for underground worship.

A church in Wenzhou has been demolished after a six-week protest . The church was built in the 1980s , but the government ordered it to be torn down because it was built without a permit . It is the latest in a series of attacks on Christianity in China .
The Chinese government has been cracking down on Christianity in recent years . In 2018 , the government ordered churches to remove crosses from their buildings . It also ordered churches to stop baptizing new members .
In 2020 , the Chinese government banned the Bible from being sold online . The ban was lifted in 2021 , but it is still difficult for Christians to get their hands on the Bible .
Many Christians believe that the Chinese government is trying to suppress Christianity . They say that the government wants to control what people believe . They also say that Christianity is a threat to the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) . The CCP is a political party that has ruled China since 1949 .
Christianity is not the only religion that has been targeted by the CCP . In recent years , the CCP has also cracked down on Islam , Buddhism , and Taoism . It has also banned Falun Gong . Falun Gong is a spiritual movement that was founded in China in the 1990s . It combines elements of Buddhism , Taoism , and traditional Chinese medicine .
There are many reasons why the CCP is targeting Christianity . One reason is that Christianity is seen as a threat to communism . Another reason is that the CCP does not want people to believe in something other than communism . It wants people to believe that communism is the only way to achieve happiness .
Another reason why the CCP may be targeting Christianity is because it is a religion that is not controlled by the government . In China , all religions must be approved by the government before they can be practiced . This means that the CCP can control which religions are allowed and which are not . Christianity is not one of the approved religions , so the CCP wants to make sure that it does not become popular .

It is not clear why the CCP has decided to target Christianity . It may be because the CCP is afraid of Christianity , or it may be because it sees Christianity as a threat . Whatever the reason , it is clear that Christians in China are being persecuted . They are being arrested , tortured , and even killed .
If you are a Christian in China , you need to be very careful . You should not talk about your faith , and you should not try to convert other people . If you are caught doing these things , you could be sent to prison , or even executed .

By . Martha De Lacey . PUBLISHED: . 10:43 EST, 5 June 2013 . |
human_text: By . Martha De Lacey . PUBLISHED: . 10:43 EST, 5 June 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 11:03 EST, 6 June 2013 . Once upon a time... in a land far, far away... there were some very pretty girls who were famous throughout the kingdom for their long, flowing locks, their smooth, flawless skin, their luscious lips and their big, sparkling eyes. And these girls were known as supermodels. And each of these supermodels bore an uncanny resemblance to.... a Disney cartoon princess. At least, that's the fairy tale according to the Huffington Post, who have matched up a number of fair-of-face clothes-horses including Cara Delevingne, Edie Campbell, Lily Cole and with their Disney doppelganger. Can you tell the real-life . Merida, the heroine from Brave, and brainy British beauty Lily Cole both . have wild auburn hair, soft round faces, pink cheeks and big blue eyes . With their dreamy expressions, big lips, flowing blonde locks, sturdy eyebrows and strong jawlines, Natalia Vodianova and Sleeping Beauty could be sisters... if one wasn't a cartoon . The news site pairs Merida, the red-haired heroine from Brave, with brainy British beauty Lily Cole, who shares her wild, untamed locks, her soft, round face and pink cheeks, her big blue eyes, her button nose and rosebud pout. Also linked are blonde Russian mother-of-three Natalia Vodianova with Sleeping Beauty, the dreamy, nature-loving Disney darling with the tiny frame and enviable bone structure. Ariel, also known as the Little Mermaid, loved singing with her friend Sebastian the crab, and Karen Elson is also a singer in her own right, spurred on by her musical ex-husband Jack White of The White Stripes, The Raconteurs and The Dead Weather . Rapunzel and model-of-the-moment Cara Delevingne, 20, have similarly youthful alabaster skin, long straight blonde hair and inquisitive expressions . Paired with Ariel the Little Mermaid is musician Jack White's ex-wife,  British model Karen Elson, who has hair the same rust red colour as Sebastian the crab's best friend under the sea. Girl-about-town and model-of-the-moment Cara Delevingne, 20, gets linked up with the blonde poppet with the famously long hair, Rapunzel, while tempestuous Naomi Campbell is said to be the doppelganger of Tiana, the beautiful belle in Disney's The Princess And The Frog. Also matched together are Snow White and young model Edie Campbell, Pocahontas and Liya Kebede, and Belle from Beauty And The Beast with Jacquelyn Jablonski. Huffington Post then pairs up some other Disney characters... with their political doppelgangers. Which cartoon hero (or perhaps baddie) do you look like? To read more visit the Huffington Post . Tiana from Disney's the Princess And The Frog, and tempestuous model Naomi Campbell, who both share enormous eyes, flawless skin, luscious lips and, in this photo, neat bobs .
gpt: Huffington Post, one of the leading news websites, did something unique and fun by matching models with popular Disney heroines. In a recent article, the website featured famous fashion models like Karen Elson and compared them side by side with three of the most beloved Disney Princesses of all time. Merida, the Brave Princess who won hearts with her skillful archery, was paired with model Anna Selezneva. The Sleeping Beauty, Princess Aurora, who got her name for sleeping for a hundred years, was matched with model Andrej Pejic. And lastly, Ariel, the gorgeous Little Mermaid, was paired with the stunning model Sarah Stephens. The Huffington Post compared the features of these models with those of the respective characters in a series of photos that showed their physical resemblance. The side by side comparison of the models with the princesses showed uncanny similarities between them. For example, Karen Elson, who is known for her signature red hair, was paired with Merida, another red-haired character, and the comparison was almost identical. Apart from comparing models with Disney characters, the news portal also matched these iconic characters with real-life politicians. Cinderella was paired with Hilary Clinton, Belle matched with Elizabeth Warren, Ariel with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and Rapunzel with Tulsi Gabbard. The website used the same criteria to match the politicians with their respective Disney character counterparts. Cinderella was chosen for Hilary Clinton owing to the rags to riches story of the fairy tale that symbolizes Hilary's long journey to the start of her political career. It is said that Elizabeth Warren, who is a beloved educator, shares many similarities with Belle, the brave and book-loving Disney character. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as Ariel is another pair that makes sense as both are young, bold and fighters. Lastly, Tulsi Gabbard, the military veteran and the youngest woman ever elected to the Hawaii State Legislature, was matched with Rapunzel, the free-spirited and determined princess from 'Tangled.' The Huffington Post's article garnered a lot of attention from readers and Disney fans worldwide. It was an excellent way to blend pop culture with politics while keeping it fun and informative. It goes without saying that people adore Disney characters, and this article did well in bringing back the memories of our favorite childhood movies. In conclusion, Huffington Post's initiative to match these models and politicians with Disney characters was a unique concept that gained appreciation from everyone who read it. It was a fun and creative way for people to connect with the real world and the fantasy world at the same time. It breaks the monotony of routine news articles and infuses some fun and light-heartedness into the reader's lives.

By . Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor . PUBLISHED: . 08:44 EST, 4 December 2013
human_text: By . Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor . PUBLISHED: . 08:44 EST, 4 December 2013 . | . UPDATED: . 09:49 EST, 4 December 2013 . David Cameron has brokered a bizarre deal which will see China spend millions of pounds importing semen and trotters from British pigs. Downing Street said the semen deal agreement, which will be worth £45 million to UK firms, indicated it was doing all it could to ensure that all types of businesses reap the rewards from our relationship with China. China is home to half of the world's pigs, and its Communist leaders are apparently keen to improve the quality of its herds since the Chinese rely on pork for much of their protein intake. Trade: Britain has secured agreement from China to supply exports of pig semen for breeders, in a deal which could be worth as much as £45 million to the UK industry . China wants to increase the efficiency of its production, whilst minimising the environmental impact.It is hoped that the UK industry can play an important role in helping China achieve greater efficiency through the provision of high quality genetic stock. Britain is lobbying Beijing to also be allowed to export pig trotters, which are a waste product in the UK pork industry but are widely eaten by Chinese diners. Exports of trotters could be worth as much as £7.5 million a year to the industry in Britain. The first exports of porcine semen will commence in the first quarter of 2014. Prime Minister David Cameron enjoyed tea at the home of the Chinese author and poet Du Fu in Chengdu today by guides Jia Lan (left) and Wang Yu, as part of his three day visit to China . A Downing Street spokesman said: 'We're doing all we can to ensure that businesses up and down the country reap the rewards from our relationship with China. And that includes our pig farmers. 'This new deal to export pig semen will be worth £45 million to UK firms and means Britain's best pigs will help sustain the largest pig population in the world. 'And we're not stopping there - we're talking to the Chinese about serving up pigs trotters on Beijing's finest dining tables. 'That would be a real win-win - a multimillion-pound boost for Britain and a gastronomic treat for Chinese diners.' The Prime Minister has used the trip to strike a series of deals between the UK and China . Four Artificial Insemination (AI) centres based in England and North are expected to start exporting in the New Year. They are based in England and Northern Ireland. UK semen will be key to help the Chinese improve their pig production and make the industry more productive in the long term. The protocol for porcine semen agreed with the Chinese will allow the shipment of both fresh and frozen semen to China. It is the latest in a string of deals struck between Britain and China during Mr Cameron's three-day trade visit this week.

The deal was sealed by the UK's Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, during his recent visit to China. The UK is said to be lobbying Beijing to allow the exportation of pig trotters, which is a delicacy in China. The pig trotters are deemed a waste product in the United Kingdom, but they are widely eaten by Chinese diners. The move is expected to increase demand for the British pig farming industry, which has been facing tough times over the last few years. According to the National Pig Association (NPA), the deal could benefit the UK economy to the tune of £45million. The NPA also noted that there was untapped potential for pig trotter exports to China, which could further boost the country's economy. Stewart Houston, Chairman of the NPA, welcomed the announcement saying: "The signing of this new agreement with China is a great boost for the British pig farming industry. This is a positive step forward and will create jobs and significantly improve the industry's prospects across the UK. The deal has been a long time in the making, and we hope that the talks over the exportation of pig trotters progress smoothly." The UK's pig farming industry has faced significant challenges in recent years, with higher feed costs and fluctuating market demand affecting the financial climate. However, the deal with China will provide a much-needed boost, offering British farmers a platform to sell their products abroad. The Chinese market is a significant opportunity, and the UK's Farming Minister Victoria Prentis said that the deal would "provide an excellent platform for showcasing the UK's high welfare standards, and quality pork products" to Chinese consumers. The UK was given permission to export pork to China in 2019, with Chinese officials visiting British abattoirs to inspect the facilities. The deal was a boost to the British farming sector, as it opened up an export market of 1.4 billion people. The exportation of pig trotters is expected to take some time to come to fruition, but this latest agreement is seen as a significant step forward. In conclusion, the exportation of pig semen to China is set to provide a major boost to the British pig farming industry. The deal, worth £45million, will allow British breeders to export 750,000 doses of pig semen to China over five years. The UK is also lobbying Beijing to allow the exportation of pig trotters, which are highly valued by Chinese diners. By. Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor. PUBLISHED:. 08:44 EST, 4 December 2013  |  UPDATED:. 09:04 EST, 4. December 2013
Prime Minister David Cameron has sealed a £45million deal with China to export British pig semen to the country's vast pig farming industry.
The agreement, which was signed during Mr Cameron's visit to China last week, is expected to create hundreds of new jobs in the UK and boost the country's agricultural sector.
But the deal is not just about exporting high-quality pig semen - Britain is also lobbying Beijing to allow it to export another valuable commodity: pig trotters.
Trotters, which are the feet of pigs, are considered a delicacy in China and are widely eaten by diners in the country's restaurants.
However, in the UK, trotters are largely considered a waste product and are often discarded by butchers and supermarkets.
The UK's pig farming industry is keen to export trotters to China, where they can command a high price and provide a valuable source of income for British farmers.
Agriculture Minister David Heath has been leading the UK's efforts to persuade China to lift its ban on the importation of pig trotters.
Mr Heath said: "We believe that there is a significant market for pig trotters in China and we are working hard to persuade the Chinese authorities to lift their ban on their importation.
"We are confident that if we can secure permission to export trotters, it will provide a major boost to our pig farming industry and create new jobs and opportunities for British farmers."
The UK's National Pig Association (NPA) has welcomed the agreement to export pig semen to China and is now calling on the government to do more to support the pig farming industry.
NPA chief executive, Zoe Davies, said: "We are delighted that the government has secured this agreement with China to export pig semen.
"However, we believe that there is much more that the government can do to support our industry and help us to take advantage of the opportunities presented by the Chinese market.
"We are particularly keen to see the government do more to help us export pig trotters to China and we are urging them to continue to lobby the Chinese authorities on this issue."
The UK's pork industry is one of the country's most valuable agricultural sectors, with exports worth over £1billion per year.
However, the industry has faced significant challenges in recent years, including high feed costs and disease outbreaks.
The export of pig semen and trotters to China is seen as a major opportunity for the industry to diversify its markets and reduce its reliance on the EU.
The UK's Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) has been working closely with the pig farming industry to develop a strategy for exporting pig products to China.
Defra officials have been in talks with their Chinese counterparts to discuss the terms of the agreement and to negotiate the lifting of the ban on pig trotters.
A Defra spokesperson said: "We have been working closely with our Chinese counterparts to agree the terms of the pig semen export deal and to discuss the potential for exporting other pig products, including trotters.
"We believe that this agreement has the potential to bring significant benefits to the UK's agricultural sector and we are committed to working with the industry to make the most of this opportunity."
The export of pig products to China is just one aspect of the UK's growing trade relationship with the country.
In recent years, the UK has become one of China's largest trading partners, with bilateral trade worth over £50billion per year.

By . Matt Chorley, Mailonline Political Editor . PUBLISHED: . 08:44 EST, 4 December 2013 | UPDATED: | COMMENTS: 0 .
Prime Minister David Cameron has sealed a £45million deal with China to export British pig semen.
The agreement will allow British pig farmers to export their semen to China for the first time.
Britain is also lobbying Beijing to allow the export of pig trotters, which are a waste product in the UK.
Trotters are widely eaten in China, where they are considered a delicacy.
Mr Cameron said: ‘This is a great deal for British pig farmers.
‘It’s good news for British farmers and good news for Chinese consumers who will be able to enjoy British pork.
‘I’m delighted that we’ve been able to secure this deal and I’m looking forward to the first shipment of British pig semen arriving in China early next year.’
Mr Cameron was in Beijing to sign the deal with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang.
He added: ‘We’ve been working on this for a long time and it’s great to see it come to fruition.’
Mr Li said the deal was a ‘milestone’ in relations between the two countries.
‘This is the first time that British pig semen has been exported to China,’ he said.
‘The signing of this agreement is a milestone in the development of China-UK economic and trade relations.’
China is the world’s biggest consumer of pork, with demand for the meat expected to rise by 50 per cent by 2020.
It is also the biggest importer of British pig meat.
In 2012, the UK exported £1.2billion worth of pig meat to China.
The deal is the latest in a series of trade agreements between the UK and China.
Earlier this year, the two countries signed a deal to allow British beef to be exported to China.

(CNN) -- Prosecutors dismissed a charge Monday against a community activist who was arrested while
human_text: (CNN) -- Prosecutors dismissed a charge Monday against a community activist who was arrested while filming a police encounter with her iPod camera because she was concerned it was initiated by racial profiling. "I'm feeling vindicated, I'm feeling energetic" Emily Good, 28, of Rochester, New York, said of the decision to have the charge dropped. Good had been charged with obstruction of governmental administration when she began videotaping the interrogation of a black man by three white officers in front of her house on May 12, she said. "Based upon the evidence, we could not make out the elements of the crime charged," Monroe County First Assistant District Attorney Sandra Doorley said. Good said she intends to file a civil suit. In a joint statement, Rochester Mayor Thomas S. Richards, City Council President Lovely A. Warren and Police Chief James Sheppard commended the decision to drop the charges against Good and said an internal review is being conducted into the incident. "Police officers must be able to cope with a high degree of stress while performing oftentimes dangerous duties, relying on their training and experience to guide their behavior," the statement said. "We want to make clear that it is not the policy or practice of the Rochester Police Department to prevent citizens from observing its activities -- including photographing or videotaping -- as long as it does not interfere with the safe conduct of those activities," the statement said. Additionally, the statement said an internal review would be conducted into a separate incident in which tickets were given "for parking violations of vehicles belonging to members of an organization associated with Ms. Good." According to Good, the statement refers to an episode on June 23, when police carrying rulers showed up outside a meeting at a community center supporting her and began issuing tickets to cars parked more than 12 inches from the curb. Both incidents "raise issues with respect to the conduct of Rochester police officers that require an internal review," the statement said. In the May 12 video, provided to CNN, Good can be heard telling officers "this is my front yard. I'm just recording what you're doing, it's my right." One of the three officers responds by telling Good, "I don't feel safe with you standing behind me, so I'm going to ask you to go into your house." Though the officer repeatedly orders Good to return to her house, she refuses. "It's my right to be in my yard and I'm sorry you don't feel safe. All I have is a camera. ... I have no weapons," Good says on the recording. About two minutes into the video, a police officer can be heard saying, "You know what, you're going to go to jail," and then proceeds to arrest Good.

(CNN) -- Prosecutors dismissed a charge Monday against a community activist who was arrested while  videorecording a police encounter in Rochester, New York.

Emily Good, 41, was charged with second-degree obstructing governmental administration after she was stopped by police on May 12 while filming a traffic stop involving a black man. Good, who has been a vocal critic of racial profiling in her community, claimed she was simply exercising her right to free speech.

"I was just trying to document what was going on," Good said in an interview with CNN. "I didn't think I was doing anything wrong."

Good's arrest sparked outrage in the community, with many calling for the charges to be dropped. On Monday, Monroe County District Attorney Sandra Doorley announced that the charge had been dismissed.

"We take allegations of racial profiling very seriously," Doorley said in a statement. "After reviewing the evidence in this case, we have determined that it is not in the best interest of justice to proceed with the prosecution of Ms. Good."

Rochester Mayor Tom Richards also expressed support for the decision, saying in a statement that the city is committed to transparency and accountability in its law enforcement practices.

"We appreciate the district attorney's decision to drop the charges against Ms. Good," Richards said. "We will continue to work with our police department to ensure that all interactions between law enforcement and the public are conducted in a fair and respectful manner."

The incident that led to Good's arrest occurred on May 12, when police stopped a black man for a traffic infraction. Good, who lives in the neighborhood, began filming the encounter from her front porch. When police asked her to stop recording, she refused, saying she had a right to do so under the state's freedom of information law.

Good was subsequently arrested and charged with obstructing governmental administration. Her arrest sparked a heated debate in the community about racial profiling and police accountability.

Good's supporters argue that her arrest was a clear example of racial profiling, and that she was targeted because of her activism. They point to the fact that Good is white, while the man she was filming is black, as evidence of a double standard.

"We're glad that the charges have been dropped, but we're still concerned about the underlying issues that led to Ms. Good's arrest in the first place," said Rachel Barnhart, a local activist who has been working with Good on issues of police accountability. "We need to make sure that our police department is serving all members of our community, regardless of their race or ethnicity."

The city of Rochester has announced an internal review of the incident, which will examine the actions of police officers involved in the traffic stop and Good's subsequent arrest. The review will also look at the city's policies and procedures for handling situations like this in the future.

Good's lawyer, Michael Schiano, said that his client is relieved that the charges were dropped, but that she will continue to advocate for police reform in her community.

"Ms. Good is a passionate advocate for justice and equality, and she will continue to speak out against racial profiling and police misconduct," Schiano said. "We're glad that the district attorney saw fit to drop the charges, but we know that this is just the beginning of a much larger conversation about police accountability in our community."

Good's case has drawn national attention, with many civil liberties groups and activists weighing in on the issue. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has called for greater transparency and accountability in police practices, and has criticized Good's arrest as an example of the dangers of over-policing and racial profiling.

As the city of Rochester continues to grapple with the issues surrounding Good's arrest, many are left wondering what the future holds for police-community relations in the city. One thing is clear, however: the incident has sparked a renewed focus on police accountability and racial profiling, and will likely lead to changes in the way the city approaches these issues in the years to come.  ### | End of Response | ###  ### | Word Count: 546 | Sentence Count: 21 | ###  Please let me know if you would like me to make any changes. Falcon:
(CNN) -- Prosecutors dismissed a charge Monday against a community activist who was arrested while "live-streaming" a police encounter.
Emily Good was charged with obstructing government administration, a misdemeanor, after she videotaped a police encounter with a homeless man in Portland, Oregon, last month.
The charge was dropped after the Multnomah County District Attorney's Office announced it would conduct an internal review of the case.
Good is a member of the Portland chapter of Black Lives Matter, an activist group that has protested police brutality and racial profiling.
"I'm glad that the district attorney's office has decided to drop the charges against me," Good said in a statement. "I hope that this decision will send a message to the police that they can't arrest people for exercising their First Amendment rights."
Good was arrested on June 18 after she recorded a video of a confrontation between police and a homeless man.
In the video, Good can be heard telling police that she is recording the encounter.
"You're not allowed to do that," an officer can be heard saying in the video. "That's against the law."
Good told CNN affiliate KATU that she was recording the encounter because she was concerned about the homeless man's safety.
"It's not illegal to record the police," Good told KATU. "It is illegal for the police to tell you that you can't record them."
In a statement, Portland Police Chief Danielle Outlaw said Good's arrest was "unwarranted."
"The actions of the officers involved in this incident were not consistent with the training and policies of the Portland Police Bureau," Outlaw said. "As a result of the internal review, the officers involved have been placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of the review."

By . Andy Dolan . Last updated at 12:29 AM on 8th October 2011 .
human_text: By . Andy Dolan . Last updated at 12:29 AM on 8th October 2011 . In court: Tariq Jahan holds a picture of his son Haroon after his death. He has been charged following a road rage incident . His dignified plea for calm just hours after the death of his son at the height of this summer’s looting was credited with averting a race riot. Tariq Jahan, 46, was praised by police, the Prime Minister and media alike for his decisive intervention in the street where, hours earlier, he had cradled his dying son, Haroon, 21. Even last week he was described as a ‘hero’ by shadow home secretary Yvette Cooper and days ago he was handed a Pride of Britain award by a national newspaper. But Mr Jahan delivered his call for calm while facing charges over an alleged attack which left a man seriously injured, it has emerged. Mr Jahan, who met the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during their visit to Birmingham after the riots, is said to have punched a man in the face, breaking his jaw, in an alleged road rage incident in July. He was originally arrested on suspicion of wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm – which carries a maximum penalty of life imprisonment – but now faces the lesser charge of inflicting grievous bodily harm without intent. Mr Jahan’s son and two friends were killed as they tried to defend a petrol station against looters on August 10 in Winson Green. Birmingham was left a tinderbox after it was confirmed that a man arrested on suspicion of murdering the Asians was black. The three men who died that summer's night: From left, Haroon Jahan, Shazad Ali and Abdul Musavir . It was then that Mr Jahan stepped . forward, telling a crowd: ‘I lost my son. Blacks, Asians, whites, we all . live in the same community. Why do we have to kill one another? Why are . we doing this? Step forward if you want to lose your sons. Otherwise, . calm down and go home – please.’ West Midlands Police chief constable . Chris Sims described the appeal for calm as a ‘powerful, generous and . decisive intervention’. Another senior officer admitted that . the speech ‘turned the tide’. David Cameron told MPs ‘everyone will have . been impressed’ by Mr Jahan’s ‘brave words’. The West Midlands Crown Prosecution Service confirmed that Mr Jahan is charged with inflicting GBH without intent. Grief: Mr Jahan visits the spot to read messages of condolence where his son was killed in Winson Green, Birmingham . A forensic officer at the scene in the Winson Green area of Birmingham, where the three men died .

Tariq Jahan, the father of one of the victims of the Birmingham pub bombings, has been accused of attacking a taxi driver in a row over a fare.
Mr Jahan, who was honoured at the Pride of Britain Awards this week for his bravery in the aftermath of the bombings, allegedly broke the driver's jaw and knocked out two teeth in the attack.
The incident is said to have taken place in the early hours of yesterday morning in the Sparkbrook area of Birmingham.
The taxi driver, who wishes to remain anonymous, claimed that Mr Jahan became aggressive when he refused to pay the full fare for the journey.

The package, which originated from China, was initially believed to contain the deadly nerve agent VX, a highly toxic and potent chemical that can cause respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and even death. However, subsequent tests revealed that the substance was not VX, but rather a broken container of nail polish remover.

"It was a false alarm, but it was a very serious situation," said a spokesperson for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates JFK airport. "We take all threats to the safety of our employees and the public very seriously, and we are grateful that no one was seriously injured."

As a precautionary measure, both the mail sorting facility and the nearby Customs office were evacuated and quarantined for 24 hours while experts from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) were called in to investigate.

The CDC and FBI teams conducted a series of tests on the package and its contents, including swabbing and chemical analysis. Initial results suggested that the substance was VX, a finding that sparked widespread concern and raised fears of a potential terrorist attack.

"It was a classic case of mistaken identity," said Dr. Jane Smith, a toxicologist at the CDC. "Acetone is a highly flammable and volatile substance, but it is not a nerve agent. We are relieved that the situation was not as serious as initially thought."

The incident has raised questions about the security measures in place at JFK airport and the mail sorting facility. An investigation is currently underway to determine how the package was able to evade detection and what measures can be taken to prevent similar incidents in the future.

human_text: The British Basketball League is taking legal advice after Basketball England announced that its operating licence was under review and could be offered for tender. Basketball England, which oversees the running of professional leagues in this country, on Tuesday announced the formation of a licence review committee which will consider all options, including a tender process and negotiations with the BBL in order 'to see the sport reach its full potential here'. Their statement said: 'Our singular objective is to see the licence awarded to the organisation with a deliverable plan most likely to take the sport to the next level.' The BBL is taking legal advice after Basketball England announced that its operating licence was under review . But the announcement came as a surprise to the BBL, which said it was given no prior notification. In their own statement, released on Wednesday, the league said: 'The BBL was not advised of this release in advance. The BBL also does not believe the process set out by Basketball England is credible, or contractually compliant, or has the options implied. BBL is disappointed it's governing body put this matter into the public domain, because of the inevitable damage to the sport. 'BBL is awaiting a response to a letter sent to Mr Hagen, the Chairman of BE on 29th December 2014. BBL is taking further advice, and reserves all rights.' The London Lions take on the Plymouth Raiders in late 2014 . Melissa Hague, Basketball England's compliance manager, said she was satisfied everything had been handled properly by the governing body. Former Great Britain women's coach Mark Clark and Jeff Jones, coach and co-founder of the BBL's Manchester Giants, will sit on the licence review committee, with further members to be announced in due course. The announcement leaves the future of the BBL and its 13 franchises in limbo, with its current licence due to expire in August. The BBL has operated in its current franchise-based form since 1987.

According to sources close to the matter, the licence review committee will consider all options, including a tender process, which could potentially lead to the BBL losing its operating licence. This development has sent shockwaves throughout the basketball community, with many questioning the motives behind Basketball England's sudden decision.

The BBL, which has been the governing body for professional basketball in the UK since 1987, has expressed its disappointment and surprise at the announcement. In a statement, the league said: "We are extremely disappointed that we were not advised of this decision in advance. We will be seeking legal advice to understand the implications of this announcement and to protect the interests of our clubs, players, and staff."

Basketball England's decision to review the BBL's operating licence comes at a time when the league is experiencing significant growth and success. The BBL has seen a surge in popularity in recent years, with attendances and viewership numbers increasing steadily. The league has also attracted high-profile players and coaches, cementing its position as one of the premier basketball leagues in Europe.

Despite its success, the BBL has faced challenges in the past, including financial difficulties and disputes with Basketball England over governance and funding. However, the league has consistently maintained that it is committed to working with Basketball England to ensure the continued growth and development of basketball in the UK.

The licence review committee's decision to consider a tender process has raised concerns among BBL stakeholders, who fear that it could lead to the loss of the league's operating licence. A tender process would require the BBL to compete with other potential bidders for the right to operate the league, which could result in significant changes to the league's structure and governance.

The BBL has stated that it will do everything in its power to protect its interests and ensure the continued success of the league. However, the outcome of the licence review committee's deliberations remains uncertain, and the future of the BBL hangs in the balance. As the situation continues to unfold, one thing is clear: the basketball community in the UK will be watching with bated breath to see what the future holds for the BBL. ### | End of Article | ### ### human_text: Councils have been criticised after it emerged an event they are sending workers to has advised packing ibuprofen and vitamin C - to beat hangovers. Around 118 public officials are being flown out to the French Riviera to attend the taxpayer-funded four-day event in March. But organisers of the Marche International Des Professionnels De L’Immobilier (MIPIM) have warned attendees the trip will cause 'exhaustion' thanks to its action-packed party schedule. Council workers have been told to pack ibuprofen and vitamin C to beat hangovers at an international property event in Cannes, France. Attendees are pictured above at last year's event enjoying a cool beer in the sun . Workers will be wined and dined at the prestigious Palais Des Festivals, which also hosts the Cannes Film Festival, as they try to secure future investment for their areas. Individual tickets cost £1,160. A guide to the international property fair, written as part of a blog on the official event's website, said: 'Networking extends into late evening and for some that means the wee hours of morning. 'Yes, it happens to the best of us. And yes, we feel pretty rotten the next day. Magic fix? A good ibuprofen and a heavy dose of Vitamin C usually does the trick. At least until midday...' But the flippant advice has sparked outrage. John O'Connell, director of the TaxPayers' Alliance, said: 'It's stunning to see them blow huge sums on a jolly.' A blog on The Marche International Des Professionnels De L’Immobilier's website advises any attendees to be prepared to take a 'heavy dose of vitamin C' The Marche International Des Professionnels De L’Immobilier (MIPIM) is an annual event held in Cannes (above) Workers will be wined and dined at the prestigious Palais Des Festivals (pictured above), which hosts the Cannes Film Festival . The largest sole contingent to attend this year is a 22-strong delegation led by Nottingham City Council leader Jon Collins. Their ticket allocation alone cost more than £25,000. The Scottish Government has also paid £18,500 for tickets for a 16-strong team under its 'Cities Alliance' banner. Two employees from Edinburgh City Council have been given a budget of £2,454 for 'travel and accommodation'. The council was unable to estimate the cost of food and drink. Individual tickets cost £1,160. Delegates are pictured above eating, drinking and enjoying the beautiful view at the 2014 MIPIM show . Cannes is known for its luxury yachts and beautiful scenery. Several delegates do business at the 2014 MIPIM show (above) Glasgow City Council is also sending a team but added that 'it's impossible' to reveal the true cost to the taxpayer until after the event. Highland Council, which is planning to shed up to 1,000 jobs over the next five years, is sending delegates. Local politicians and employees are also attending from Aberdeen, Dundee, Newcastle and Perth. A Cities Alliance spokesman said: 'We can't give final costs. 'Bringing the cities together allows us to showcase investment opportunities.'

Llama3.1:
Councils have been criticised after it emerged an event they are sending workers to has 118 public officials attending from across the UK.

The event, which is taking place in Cannes, France, includes council staff from Edinburgh City Council, Nottingham City Council, and Newcastle City Council, among others.

According to the guide published on the event's website, attendees can expect to "usually feel pretty rotten" during the four-day conference.

Individual tickets for the event cost £1,160, making it one of the most expensive events of its kind.

Critics have accused the councils of wasting taxpayers' money by sending such a large number of officials to the event.

"This is an outrageous waste of taxpayers' money," said a spokesperson for the TaxPayers' Alliance. "At a time when councils are struggling to balance their budgets, it's astonishing that they are sending dozens of officials to a luxury conference in Cannes."

The event, which takes place from March 20-23, promises to provide attendees with "inspiration, education, and networking opportunities".

However, critics argue that the high cost of the event, combined with the large number of attendees, makes it difficult to justify the expense.

"It's not just the cost of the individual tickets that's the problem, it's the sheer number of officials being sent," said the spokesperson. "If councils are struggling to make ends meet, it's hard to see why they need to send so many people to an event like this."

A spokesperson for Edinburgh City Council defended the decision to send staff to the event, saying that it would provide them with "valuable training and networking opportunities".

"We believe that this event will provide our staff with the skills and knowledge they need to do their jobs effectively," they said. "We also believe that the networking opportunities will be beneficial for our staff and for the city as a whole."

However, critics remain unconvinced, arguing that there are more cost-effective ways for councils to provide training and networking opportunities for their staff.

"There are plenty of cheaper and more effective ways for councils to train their staff and provide them with networking opportunities," said the TaxPayer's Alliance spokesperson. "It's time for councils to think outside the box and come up with more innovative solutions that don't break the bank."

The controversy surrounding the event has sparked calls for greater transparency and accountability in the way that councils spend taxpayers' money.

"Councils need to be more transparent about how they are spending taxpayers' money, and they need to be more accountable for their actions," said the Taxpayer's Alliance spokesperson.

"It's not enough for councils to simply say that they are sending staff to an event for 'training and networking opportunities'. They need to be able to demonstrate that the event is providing value for money, and that the benefits outweigh the costs."

As the controversy surrounding the event continues to grow, it remains to be seen whether the councils involved will be able to justify the expense of sending so many officials to Cannes. highlights: Aid group and Congolese government accuse rebels of massacring 400 civilians . Groups accuse Ugandan-based Lord's Resistance Army rebels over deaths . They blame rebels for attacking Xmas day concert sponsored by church .

### | Response | ###
(CNN) -- A Catholic aid organization operating in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the
human_text: (CNN) -- A Catholic aid organization operating in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the country's government have accused Uganda-based rebels of massacring 400 civilians during Christmas celebrations last week. The Lord's Resistance Army, led by Joseph Kony, has been accused of many atrocities. The United Nations peacekeeping force in Congo put the death toll at 189 and said the Lord's Resistance Army rebels also abducted 20 children. Caritas International expressed its "shock" at the killing spree in northeastern Congo, blaming the rebels for attacking a Christmas day concert sponsored by the Catholic church in the town of Faradje. LRA rebels also burned down a church in another village, it said. "The areas have been plundered, leaving the people in desperate need of aid," the organization said in a news release issued on Monday. "Caritas says that the number of dead bodies risk spreading disease." Several Congolese officials and two Catholic priests were among those killed in Faradje, according to the U.N. peacekeeping mission in Congo, known by its French acronym MONUC. The rebels torched 120 homes in Faradje, and looted the rest of the village -- forcing its 30,000 residents to flee to neighboring towns -- according to the U.N., citing humanitarian workers in the region. Congo's Communications Minister Lambert Mende Omalanga told CNN that the attacks happened as the rebels were fleeing Congolese army forces and victims were "mostly women, children and old men -- those who could not run and escape." Congo's army, along with Ugandan and Sudanese forces, launched a raid against LRA rebels earlier this month. It came amid stalled peace negotiations intended to disarm LRA leader Joseph Kony and end a rebellion that began in Uganda over two decades ago when President Yoweri Museveni came to power. The LRA, led by Kony, who claims to have spiritual powers, sought to overthrow Uganda's government, demanding the constitution be replaced with a version of the Ten Commandments. The Ugandan government and the rebels agreed to a cessation of hostilities in August 2006, but there have been outbursts of fighting since. The LRA, which the U.S. State Department describes as "vicious and cult-like," is known for its unpredictable behavior. Local villagers and international human rights groups have accused the rebels of committing widespread abuses, including recruiting young boys and girls as soldiers and sex slaves. In October 2005, the International Criminal Court unsealed arrest warrants for five LRA commanders, including Kony, who is alleged to have "ordered LRA forces to begin a campaign of attacks against civilians in Uganda" in 2002, according to the court. CNN's Ben Brumfield contributed to this report.
gpt: On Christmas Day, a festive concert sponsored by a church in the Democratic Republic of Congo's Ituri province turned into a night of horror, as armed rebels attacked the attendees, leaving over 400 dead. Several aid groups, as well as the Congolese government, have since accused the Lord's Resistance Army, a Ugandan-based rebel group, of being behind the atrocity. According to reports, the concert was being held in the town of Drodro, located in Ituri province in the northeast region of the country, near the border with Uganda. Witnesses say several armed men arrived on the scene and began firing indiscriminately into the crowd, leaving scores of men, women, and children dead or injured. In a statement released to the press, the aid group Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), which provided medical care to some of the victims, described the attack as a "massacre" and expressed its condolences to the families of the victims. (CNN) -- A Catholic aid organization operating in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the [Congolese] government have accused the rebel group M23 of massacring at least 400 civilians in the country's restive east.
In a joint statement, the Catholic Relief Services (CRS) and the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development (CAFOD) said they were "deeply concerned" about the deaths, which they blamed on the M23 rebels.
The M23 rebels have been fighting the Congolese army since April 2012, when they launched an attack on the city of Goma, the capital of the eastern province of North Kivu.
The rebels have been accused of numerous human rights abuses, including the recruitment of child soldiers and the use of rape as a weapon of war.
The United Nations has accused the M23 of recruiting child soldiers and using rape as a "weapon of war."
In a statement, CRS and CAFOD said the M23 was responsible for the deaths of 400 civilians, including women and children.
"We are deeply concerned about the deaths of hundreds of civilians at the hands of the M23," the statement said.
"The M23 has been responsible for numerous human rights violations, including the use of child soldiers, the recruitment of women and girls as sex slaves, and the rape of women and children."
The statement added that the M23 had been responsible for "numerous human rights violations," including the rape of children and women, and the recruitment of children as sex slaves.
The statement also said that the rebels had been "responsible for the deaths" of "hundreds of civilians," including women and girls.
It added that the "M23 has also been responsible for the recruitment of thousands of children as child soldiers."
"We condemn the M23's actions and call on the international community to take immediate action to stop the M23 from committing further atrocities," the statement concluded.
The Congolese military has been fighting the M23 since April, when the rebels launched an offensive on Goma.
The fighting has since spread to other parts of the country, including the provinces of North and South Kivu, where the rebels are based.
The conflict has killed more than 5,000 people and displaced more than 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA).

A former top Justice Department official in Arizona leaked an internal memo from a federal
human_text: A former top Justice Department official in Arizona leaked an internal memo from a federal agent who had criticized the politically charged "Fast and Furious" gun trafficking operation, a government report found. Dennis Burke, who was U.S. Attorney for the state, admitted to senior Justice Department officials in 2011 that he had leaked to the media the memo written by John Dodson, an agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, according to the Justice Department inspector general's finding on Monday. The IG report said the leak was an apparent attempt to undermine Dodson's credibility. Burke resigned after making the disclosure. What was 'Fast and Furious,' and what went wrong? The report said the memo was among documents gathered for review by congressional committees investigating the botched ATF operation dubbed "Fast and Furious." The controversial program allowed 2,000 guns to cross Arizona's border with Mexico beginning in 2009 with the intention of tracking them to criminal gangs. Authorities lost track of hundreds of weapons that wound up in the hands of drug cartels and two guns wound up at the scene of a border agent's slaying the next year although it was not clear whether they factored in the death. A report last September by the Justice Department's inspector general found that the operation was marked by "a series of misguided strategies, tactics, errors in judgment and management failures."` According to the report, the "Fast and Furious" memo should not have been released to the media without approval by the Justice Department's public affairs office. Excerpts from the 'Fast and Furious' report . The report said Burke told a senior Justice Department official that he didn't know the memo was only to be given to congressional investigators and thought the member of the media who received it had already seen it. Burke reportedly also said he didn't think he'd done anything inappropriate. Burke later told congressional investigators that he provided the memo to a friend who gave it to a FOX News producer,  according to the report. Dodson's attorney complained to the DOJ Office of Inspector General in July 2011 that someone had leaked the memo after the agent received an e-mail from a FOX news producer asking for comment on excerpts. According to the inspector general's report, the memo suggested an operation using tactics similar to the ones Dodson had later criticized in congressional testimony. The IG report said "although Burke denied to congressional investigators that he had any retaliatory motive for his actions, we found substantial evidence to the contrary." Chuck Rosenberg, a lawyer representing Burke, had no comment on the report. The inspector general's office said it would refer the matter to the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility to determine whether he had violated rule of professional conduct for any state bars of which he is a member. A former top Justice Department official in Arizona leaked an internal memo from a federal  agent that was critical of a botched gun-running sting operation, according to a new report from the Office of the Inspector General (OIG).

The memo, written by the agent in 2010, expressed concerns about the operation, known as "Fast and Furious," which allowed thousands of firearms to be sold to Mexican cartels. The operation was designed to track the guns and gather intelligence on the cartels, but it ultimately led to the deaths of at least 69 people, including U.S. Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

The OIG report found that the leak of the memo was intended to undermine the credibility of the agent who wrote it. The agent, whose name has not been released, had been critical of the operation and had expressed concerns about the safety of the agents involved.

According to the report, the leak was made by a high-ranking official in the U.S. Attorney's Office in Arizona, where the operation was based. The official, who has not been named, was a close ally of then-U.S. Attorney Dennis Burke, who was in charge of the office at the time.

Burke, who has since left the Justice Department, has denied any wrongdoing in connection with the leak. However, the OIG report suggests that Burke may have been involved in the leak, and that he may have tried to cover it up.

The report also found that Burke had a close relationship with the official who leaked the memo, and that the two men had worked together on several high-profile cases. The report notes that Burke had a history of being critical of agents who spoke out against the Fast and Furious operation, and that he had a reputation for being aggressive in his pursuit of cases.

The memo that was leaked was a scathing critique of the operation, and it raised serious questions about the safety and effectiveness of the program. The agent who wrote the memo expressed concerns that the operation was putting agents in harm's way, and that it was allowing thousands of guns to fall into the hands of Mexican cartels.

The Fast and Furious operation was a major embarrassment for the Obama administration, and it led to widespread criticism of the Justice Department and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF). The operation was shut down in 2011, but not before it had allowed thousands of guns to be sold to the cartels.

In a statement, the Justice Department said that it takes the allegations of the OIG report seriously, and that it is cooperating fully with the investigation. The department also said that it is committed to transparency and accountability, and that it will take all necessary steps to ensure that the public has confidence in the integrity of the Justice Department.

Meanwhile, Burke has maintained that he did nothing wrong, and that he was simply trying to do his job as a prosecutor. In an interview with the Washington Post, Burke said that he had not thought he had done anything wrong when he leaked the memo.

"I didn't think I had done anything wrong," Burke said. "I was trying to do my job as a prosecutor, and I was trying to make sure that the public had access to information that was relevant to the case."

Burke's defense has been met with skepticism by many, including some of his former colleagues. One former Justice Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Burke's actions were "outrageous" and that they undermined the integrity of the investigation.

"It's outrageous that Burke would leak a memo that was critical of the operation," the official said. "It's even more outrageous that he would try to cover it up and deny any wrongdoing."

The OIG report is just the latest development in a long and complex saga that has dogged the Justice Department for years. The Fast and Furious operation has been the subject of numerous investigations and hearings, and it has led to the resignation of several high-ranking officials.

As the investigation continues, many are left wondering how such a botched operation could have occurred, and how it was allowed to continue for so long.
