Falcon:
Taxpayers paid more than £3,000 for every badger killed in last year’s cull. Official figures (DEFRA) revealed that 1,878 badgers were culled in England in 2013.
The farming industry could face estimated costs of up to £100 million per year if the badger cull had not been carried out, according to a report by the National Audit Office (NAO).
The NAO found that the cull had been carried out in a “rigorous” and “humane” manner.
The report said: “The cull was carried out in accordance with rigorous safety rules, and marksmen used humane methods to kill badgers.”
The report added: “We estimate that the cost of the cull to the farming industry could be between £50 million and £100 million.”
The cull, which was carried out to protect farmers from the spread of bovine tuberculosis (TB), has been heavily criticised by animal rights groups.
The National Farmers’ Union (NFU) said the cull was a “disaster” for the farming industry.
The NFU’s chief executive, George Eustice, said the culling of badgers was “a disaster” for the industry.
He said the culls were “a waste of time and money” and that they were “not a solution to the problem”.
Mr Eustice added that the NFU was “very concerned” about the impact of the culls on the farming sector.
“The NFU is very concerned about the impact that the culling has had on the industry,” he said.
“We are very worried about the impact it has had on farmers and their families.
We are very concerned that it has had a negative impact on the environment.”
The National Union of Farmers (NUF) said it was “extremely disappointed” by the findings of the NAO report.
The union said the report “does not reflect the reality of the situation on the ground”.
“The report does not take into account the fact that badgers are a protected species in the UK,” the union said in a statement.
“It also fails to take into consideration the fact that the majority of badgers are killed in the wild.”
The NUF added that the “vast majority” of badgers killed in England were killed by farmers.
“This is not the case in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland,” the union added.
“There is no evidence to suggest that the culls have had any impact on the number of badgers in the countryside.”

By. Daily Mail Reporter. A single father serving in the Air Force surprised 8-year-old daughter Lyrique by returning home from a 9-month overseas deployment in a heartwarming moment captured on camera.

Sgt. Wil Altenus had been away from his family for nearly a year, but he had been counting down the days until he could be reunited with his young daughter. To make the reunion even more special, he had arranged for Lyrique to participate in a school trivia competition, similar to the popular TV game show Wheel of Fortune.

The competition, which was held at Lyrique's school, was a big deal for the young girl. She had been practicing her trivia skills for weeks and was determined to win. But little did she know, her father had a surprise in store for her.

When Lyrique took the stage to compete in the final round, she was nervous but excited. The game's host, a teacher at the school, presented her with a puzzle to solve. Lyrique studied the puzzle carefully, her brow furrowed in concentration.

As she began to spell out the answer, the audience watched with bated breath. And then, in a moment that will be remembered for a lifetime, Lyrique spelled out the final message: 'Lyrique's Dad is Home.'

The audience erupted into cheers and applause as Lyrique looked up to see her father standing in the back of the room, a huge smile on his face. She was shocked and overjoyed, and tears of happiness streamed down her face as she rushed into her father's arms.

"It was amazing to see her reaction," Sgt. Altenus said in an interview. "I had been away from her for so long, and to see her so happy and excited to see me was just the best feeling in the world."

Lyrique's mother is not in the picture, and her father had been relying on his sister, Kinley, to care for their daughter while he was away. But he wanted to make sure that Lyrique knew that he was thinking of her every day, and that he was doing everything he could to come home to her.

"I wanted to do something special for her, something that would make her feel loved and appreciated," he said. "And I knew that if I could surprise her like this, it would be something she would never forget."

The surprise reunion was captured on camera by a school staff member, and it has since gone viral on social media. It's a heartwarming reminder of the sacrifices that military families make, and the joy that comes with being reunited after a long time apart.

Sgt. Altenus is currently on leave from the Air Force, and he plans to spend as much time as possible with his daughter. He said that he is grateful for the support of his family and friends, and for the opportunity to serve his country.

"I'm just grateful to be home with my daughter, and to have the chance to make up for lost time," he said.

For Lyrique, the surprise reunion was a dream come true. She said that she was happy to have her father home, and that she was looking forward to spending quality time with him.

"I'm so happy that my dad is home," she said. "I love him so much, and I'm glad that he's back where he belongs."

The surprise reunion has brought the community together, and it's a reminder of the importance of supporting our military families. It's a story that will be told and retold for years to come, and one that will bring a smile to the faces of everyone who hears it.

In the end, it's a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope and always a reason to be grateful. And for Sgt. Wil Altenas and his daughter Lyrique, their reunion is a testament to the power of love and the importance of family.

By . Associated Press Reporter . Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who had been a prisoner of
human_text: By . Associated Press Reporter . Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who had been a prisoner of war in Afghanistan for five years, has been shifted to outpatient care at a Texas military base, the U.S. Army said in a statement Sunday. Bergdahl, 28, had been receiving inpatient treatment at Brooke Army Medical Center at Fort Sam Houston. He is now receiving outpatient care on the base in San Antonio, according to the statement. The Army said his 'reintegration process' is proceeding with exposure to more people and a gradual increase in social interaction. The Idaho native was captured in June 2009 and freed by the Taliban on May 31 in a deal struck by the Obama administration in which five senior Taliban officials were released from detention at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Scroll down for video . Outpatient: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, seen in this undated file photo, has been shifted to outpatient care at a Texas military base . He arrived at the Texas medical center on June 13 after nearly two weeks recuperating at a U.S. military hospital in Germany. Army officials said then that Bergdahl was in stable condition and was working daily with health care providers to regain a sense of normalcy and move forward with his life. 'His reintegration process continues with exposure to more people and a gradual increase of social interactions,' The Army statement Sunday said. 'Debriefings and counseling from Survival, Evasion, Resistance and Escape (SERE) psychologists continue to ensure he progresses to the point where he can return to duty.' Treatment: Bergdahl previously was an inpatient at Brook Army Medical Center, pictured . The Army said specifics of Bergdahl's location would not be made public. Bergdahl disappeared from his post in Paktika province in eastern Afghanistan on June 30, 2009. Some former members of his unit have said that he left of his own accord. Bergdahl has not commented publicly on the circumstances of his disappearance, and the Army has made no charges against him. The Army said last week it is investigating Bergdahl's disappearance and capture. It says investigators will not interview Bergdahl until those helping him recover say it is all right to do so.

human_text: (CNN) -- The mother of a Virginia Tech junior who disappeared Saturday night during a Metallica concert says she helped her daughter choose an outfit for the show that same morning. Morgan Harrington, a 20-year-old Virginia Tech student, disappeared at a Metallica concert Saturday night. Morgan Harrington, a 20-year-old education major, went to the concert at the University of Virginia's John Paul Jones Arena in Charlottesville with several girlfriends but disappeared from their sight around 8:40 p.m., according to police, who are calling it a missing person case. "She was excited about the concert and she brought home three outfits that she tried on for me," Gil Harrington, said Tuesday on HLN's "Nancy Grace." "We chose one and she said, 'Mama, it is a rock concert so it is probably not what you would choose, but is this one OK?'" Harrington said she told her daughter, 'That will do fine.' "You know you have to give your kid wings," Harrington said.  Watch mom describe daughter's excitement » . Morgan Harrington had been so excited about the concert, according to her mother, that she posted the tickets on the refrigerator six months ahead of time. Metallica posted a message about Harrington's disappearance on their Web site under the heading "One of our fans is missing." "We are deeply concerned about the disappearance of 20-year-old Virginia Tech student Morgan Dana Harrington, who was last seen while attending our concert at the John Paul Jones Arena in Charlottesville, VA, on Saturday night," the message said. The message described Harrington and asked that anyone with information contact Virginia State Police or University of Virginia police. "Our thoughts are with Morgan and her family for her safe return," the message concluded." Harrington, who lives off-campus, was reported missing Sunday afternoon when she did not show up at her parents' home to study for a math exam with her father. "It's important to us as police officers to realize that people do come up missing," said Lieutenant Joe Rader of the Virginia State Police in a news conference on Monday. "However, it's very, very unusual that we have not heard anything, either, from her friends or from her family regarding her whereabouts. That is the biggest concern currently -- her whereabouts and her welfare." Harrington is 5'6", 120 pounds, has blond hair, blue eyes and was wearing a black Pantera T-shirt, black mini skirt, black tights and black boots.

The Hampton Police Department has launched an investigation into Harrington's disappearance and is urging anyone with information to come forward.
